business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9.00 a.m. and read prayers.

debateinfo.title: CRIMES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TELECOMMUNICATIONS OFFENCES AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL (NO. 2) 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Slipper, and read a first time.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The past decade has seen the rapid expansion of the Internet into our work, our homes and every aspect of our daily lives. Mobile telephones have likewise become a normal part of Australian life. In all areas of telecommunications, technology has become more advanced and more sophisticated.

The telecommunications environment has changed, and the Crimes Legislation Amendment (Telecommunications Offences and Other Measures) Bill (No. 2) 2004 will ensure that Commonwealth criminal offences remain effective in this changed environment.
This bill replaces a bill of a similar name which was introduced into the Senate on 24 June 2004, except that the suicide related material offences have been included in a separate bill.

This bill continues the Australian government's proactive approach to updating criminal laws in light of rapid technological change. For example, the government developed the Cybercrime Act 2001 to provide a solid platform of criminal offences to assist Australia meet the challenges posed by computer hackers and `denial of service' attacks. Importantly, the cybercrime offences are cast in technologically neutral terms. The same approach is adopted in many of these new and updated telecommunications offences.

The existing telecommunications offences in part VIIB of the Crimes Act 1914 were enacted in 1989. This bill will repeal existing outdated telecommunications offences and insert a package of revised and new telecommunications offences into the Criminal Code. Moving these offences from the Crimes Act to the Criminal Code continues the process of relocating all serious Commonwealth offences into the Criminal Code.
Among the offences included in the bill are a range of important new measures dealing with the use of the Internet to facilitate or exploit the sexual abuse of children.

The bill contains new offences dealing with use of the Internet to access, transmit and make available child pornography and child abuse material, as well as the possession or production of such material with intent to place it on the Internet. These offences complement existing offences prohibiting the importation of such material into Australia and will carry a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment.

Law enforcement agencies estimate that around 85 per cent of child pornography seized in Australia is distributed via the Internet. In September last year, German police cracked a global child pornography network involving over 26,000 Internet users. By focusing on the Internet, these new federal offences target the very heart of the abhorrent child pornography industry.

The new offences will also prohibit the use of a telecommunications service, including by means of the Internet, to procure or `groom' a person who is under 16 years of age for the purpose of engaging in sexual activity with that person or so that a third person can engage in sexual activity with that person. These offences carry penalties of 12 to 15 years imprisonment.

These new offences target adult offenders who exploit the anonymity of telecommunications services (for example, a `chat room' on the Internet) to win the trust of a child as a first step towards the future sexual abuse of that child. This abhorrent practice is known as `online grooming'.

The new `procurement' offences will also target situations where an offender, having won a child's trust, then uses a telecommunications service to orchestrate a meeting with the child so as to engage in sexual activity.

These new offences would provide a firm legal basis for proactive AFP policing of this disturbing practice. The underlying rationale for the new offences is to allow law enforcement to intervene before a child is actually abused. A typical investigation may involve an AFP officer or an investigator at the Australian High Tech Crime Centre assuming the identity of a fictitious child, interacting with potential predatory adults over the Internet and arresting a predatory adult before they have an opportunity to sexually abuse a real child that they are also `grooming'. A Queensland prosecution has been successful on this basis.
The parliament can take an important leadership role in this area. New federal offences will provide a springboard to a national approach to this issue.

Tough offences targeting sexual predators in this way align with the government's commitment to a nationally consistent child sex offender registration system and the CrimTrac Agency's work in this area.

The telecommunications offences package also contains new and updated offences dealing with interference with telecommunications and use of telecommunications to engage in inappropriate behaviour. Among these measures are:
new offences dealing with the `rebirthing' of stolen mobile phones and the copying of mobile phone SIM cards;
an updated version of the existing offence dealing with use of a telecommunications service to menace, harass or cause offence that is extended to cover Internet content that causes offence;
new offences dealing with the use of a telecommunications service to make threats or hoaxes; and
new offences dealing with improper use of emergency service numbers, including triple zero.
In addition to the telecommunications offences, this bill also introduces other significant offences, targeting credit card skimming and contamination of goods.

The personal financial information offences introduced into the Criminal Code by this bill are a key component of the Australian government's national strategy to crack down on credit card skimming and Internet banking fraud. Credit card skimming is the process by which legitimate credit and debit card data is illicitly captured or copied, frequently by means of an electronic skimming device.

These amendments will criminalise dishonestly obtaining or dealing with personal financial information without the consent of the person to whom the information relates. These amendments will also criminalise possession or importation of a device with the intention that the device be used to commit a personal financial information offence.

Internet banking fraud, including `phishing'—where online criminals use apparently legitimate emails to trick people into divulging banking details—will also be covered by the bill. Any person who uses a deception to obtain another person's financial information will be guilty of an offence.

The proposed laws will ensure that Australians can feel more confident about electronic, telephone and Internet banking, knowing that penalties of up to five years imprisonment apply to those who capture or misuse their confidential financial details.

Comprehensive new contamination of goods offences are also included in this bill. These offences—to be inserted into the Criminal Code—will apply to a person who contaminates goods intending to cause economic loss, public alarm or anxiety, and, in some cases, harm to public health.

These offences also extend to persons who threaten to contaminate goods or falsely claim to have contaminated goods. This recognises that the level of economic loss or public anxiety or alarm can be the same regardless of whether the contamination is real, threatened or fictitious. It also reflects that in each case the offender's intention is to cause economic loss, public alarm or anxiety.

The offences will overlap and complement existing state and territory offences. Importantly, the federal contamination offences will have some extraterritorial reach. For example, a threat to contaminate Australian goods which is made from outside Australia would be covered.

Finally, this bill will also make a number of amendments to a range of other criminal law and justice acts. These include simplifying some procedures under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 and amending the Crimes (Aviation) Act 1991 to outlaw child prostitution on board Australian registered aircraft outside Australia, ensuring that the application of Australia's criminal laws on board aircraft complies with the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the sale of children. It also includes amending chapter 2 of the Criminal Code and amending the Customs Act 1901 to make clear the elements of the serious drug offences in that act.

I believe that this bill represents a significant advance in upgrading the criminal law to ensure it meets the challenges posed by new technology and the opportunities which it provides to criminals. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Rudd) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: CRIMINAL CODE AMENDMENT (SUICIDE RELATED MATERIAL OFFENCES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Slipper, and read a first time.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The Criminal Code Amendment (Suicide Related Material Offences) Bill 2004 introduces important new measures that will criminalise use of the Internet where the intention of that use is to counsel or incite suicide, or promote or provide instruction on a particular method of committing suicide.

The offences will cover use of a carriage service, including the Internet, to access, transmit or make available material that counsels or incites suicide, or promotes or provides instruction on a particular method of committing suicide. The possession, production or supply of such material with intent to make it available on the Internet will also be covered.

Currently there are a range of easily accessible Internet sites and Internet chat rooms that provide explicit instructions on methods of committing suicide and, in the case of Internet chat rooms, sometimes contain actual discussions where one person or even a group of persons urge another to commit suicide. Studies have shown that in some cases such Internet chat room discussions have led to a person attempting suicide, sometimes successfully.

The proposed offences reflect the harm that can be done by those who use the Internet with destructive intent and they will assist in preventing the use of the Internet in this way to encourage vulnerable individuals to take their own lives.

Advocacy of, or debate about, law reform on voluntary euthanasia or suicide related issues that takes place on the Internet will in no way be affected by the proposed offences, because these types of communications would not carry the requisite intention. For the same reason, the offences are unlikely to capture material such as research papers dealing with suicide related issues or suicide prevention, or support material.

These offences are intended to complement existing Customs regulations prohibiting the physical importation and exportation of suicide kits and information related to those kits. They will carry the same maximum penalty as the Customs offences of $110,000 for an individual.

The offences will also complement the proposed new telecommunications offences in the Crimes Legislation Amendment (Telecommunications Offences and Other Measures) Bill (No. 2) 2004, the telecommunications offences bill (No. 2). Amongst the range of measures in the telecommunications offences bill (No. 2) are new offences addressing Internet child pornography, use of the Internet to `groom' or procure children for sexual activity, and menacing, harassing or offensive use of a carriage service.

This bill contains important measures that will protect our most vulnerable and help to prevent the Internet from being used for destructive purposes towards those individuals. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Rudd) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 June, on motion by Mr Downer:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Terrorism is not a new phenomenon in international affairs. Individuals, groups and states have committed, sponsored and supported terrorist acts for millennia. Terrorism, for the most part, stemmed from particular ethnic, sectarian and civil conflicts. Its consequences, although terrible, were largely confined to surrounding populations. As a global strategic phenomenon and shaper of international affairs, terrorism, until recently, did not loom large. The terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001 in New York and Washington DC underlined the emergence of a new type of terrorist threat. Al-Qaeda and their associated groups pose unprecedented challenges to Western and other countries. Their broad reach and loose network structure help them resist frontal assaults: it is the very definition of `asymmetric warfare'. Their skilled use of communications and information technology, their ability to tap into financial networks and other ideological networks and their willingness to employ weapons of mass destruction, if they gain access to them, give terrorist organisations global potency. The radical and undifferentiated nature of their demands puts them beyond the reach of negotiation and deterrence.

speech.para: Here in our own region, regional terrorist networks with strong links to al-Qaeda and other extremist Islamic groups represent a significant and growing threat to the region's security. This underscores the necessity of governments around the region taking strong action in support of effective border control measures and a range of other antiterrorism measures. Here in our own region, al-Qaeda and its associated terrorist organisations—Jemaah Islamiah and others—continue to represent a significant threat to Australian security interests across South-East Asia and within Australia itself. This organisation has not been eliminated; it continues. Based on reports by those who examine these organisations at a professional and academic level, these organisations continue to find grounds for recruitment and the continuation of their terrorist planning and contingency operations in the region.

The application of biometrics in passports has been around for a good number of years. It is noteworthy that this is not an isolated development but a truly global movement towards the development of advanced systems. In May 2003 the International Civil Aviation Organisation, ICAO, adopted a global harmonised blueprint for the integration of biometric identification to passports and other machine-readable travel documents. As far back as May 2003, ICAO determined that facial recognition rated highest in terms of compatibility with key operational considerations. Further, by February this year ICAO had adopted facial recognition as the global standard for biometric identifiers in passports.

While the United States has been leading the push for the global development and use of biometric passports, revising to October next year its original deadline of October 2004 for visa waiver program countries to adopt machine-readable passports with biometric identifiers, it is worth also briefly noting that at least 10 countries in addition to the US and Australia are looking at biometric identifiers for passports and travel documents.

The United Kingdom Passport Service conducted a six-month trial of biometric identifiers from January to June 2004 involving 10,000 people who volunteered to have their facial, iris and fingerprint identifiers `enrolled'—I believe that is the technical term for it. In December 2003 the Home Office stated that the UK Passport Service was planning to begin issuing passports containing a facial biometric in mid 2005 and will give consideration to including a secondary biometric—iris or fingerprint—in later versions. In a statement on 28 July 2004 welcoming the extension by the US of the 26 October 2004 deadline, the United Kingdom government stated that work is underway to implement a facial biometric in British passports from late 2005 or early 2006.

In May 2004, Belgium announced its intention to begin issuing biometric passports in 2005, with a pilot to start shortly. The passports will contain a facial biometric initially. In February 2004, Denmark announced its intention to issue to its citizens biometric passports including a facial identifier. It intends to issue the new passports in late 2004. In February 2004 the European Commission adopted a proposal for the inclusion of a facial biometric in EU passports. The EC's proposal was to go before the European Union and the European Parliament for consideration. In February 2004, Germany initiated a six-month trial of a biometric border control system based on iris scanning. In February 2004, Ireland announced that it was considering the introduction of biometric passports. In December 2003, Italy presented a prototype of its biometric passport, which contains three identifiers: a facial image and two fingerprints.

Here in our own region, in November 2002 the government in Tokyo announced it was commencing a trial of biometric technologies to facilitate check-in at Japanese airports. In January 2004, the Netherlands announced it would be conducting a six-month trial of a biometric passport containing facial and fingerprint scans. In our own region again—very close to home—in December 2003 the government of New Zealand was described as `moving at full steam' to implement microchip based biometric passports that can store a digitised version of a person's passport photo. The general manager of the identity services division of New Zealand's Department of Internal Affairs was reported as saying that the division is already developing the necessary systems and processes for implementation. Finally, in April 2003 it was reported that the French government was looking at using biometrics to improve border control by fingerprinting all applicants for tourist visas.

The purpose of rendering that long and detailed list of what is happening around the world—in particular in Europe but also here in our own region—is to indicate that an increasing number of governments are moving in the direction of the proposals outlined in the legislation before the House. This set of measures, aimed at tightening passport identification around the world, is a direct and credible response to the mounting threat of global and regional terrorism. There will be concerns, of course, about the ultimate impact of some of these measures in certain quarters, as far as civil liberties are concerned, and I will come to that later in my response to the legislation. But on balance, by the sheer depth and breadth of the global response to the terrorist problem and other associated law enforcement measures, it can be seen that what is being proposed in this country is not unique and reflects a challenge facing us all.

The Australian Passports Bill 2004 will repeal Australian passports provisions of the 1938 act. I note briefly in passing that the Australian Passports (Transitionals and Consequentials) Bill 2004 makes the necessary amendments to repeal provisions of the 1938 act that have been superseded and to rename that act the Foreign Passports (Law Enforcement and Security) Act 2004. Labor have been supportive from the outset of strengthening the technology aspects of the Australian passport system. We have been supportive of the government exploring the possibility of biometric measures for Australian passports and Australian passport holders. We have indicated our support on many occasions.

It has taken the government at the very least two years since first flagging the move to adopt biometric identifiers and subsequent changes to the Passports Act. While we welcome the move to tighten security around one of the most crucial personal identifiers, we remain critical of the government dragging its feet over efforts to protect the Australian people at a more general level. Of course, this should not come as a surprise even to the casual observer of many aspects of what the government has been engaged in. The government constantly talks about the threat of terrorism, but, if we look at a range of practical measures which have been adopted by the government in the intelligence and security fields, often there is a yawning gap between the government's rhetoric and the reality which is delivered on the ground.

We recall, of course, the affair of Willie Brigitte and his having been issued with a tourism visa 18 months after September 11 and six months after Bali—not under a false identity, not under a false name or a false passport but under his own name and under his own identity. This is the same Willie Brigitte who is alleged to be responsible for seeking to develop a terrorist cell here in Australia. From the public record we know that Brigitte had been followed by French intelligence since 1999 as a potential terrorist. The controller-general of France's coordinating unit for counter-terrorism had confirmed that Brigitte had been entered on France's national terrorism database, yet despite this the government issued Brigitte, travelling on his own passport and in his own name, a tourism visa to visit Australia, thereby allowing Brigitte to operate freely in this country between May and September of last year. Furthermore, we know that, regrettably, Brigitte was reissued with a French passport while he was here in this country.

Brigitte is not an isolated incident: the government allowed Abdul Rahim Ayub to leave Australia. To refresh this place's memory of who this individual is, he is alleged by Jack Roche to have been the national leader of JI in Australia. He fled Australia to Indonesia in early October 2002, leaving his family behind. On 30 October ASIO raided his house, and in December 2002 Abdul's family returned to Indonesia with the assistance of the Indonesian consulate, which did not inform Australian authorities of their departure. While the failure to detain, question and prosecute Abdul Rahim Ayub was a significant law enforcement failure, it was also a failure of the government's border protection efforts.

To not limit our critique to these two matters—those of Brigitte and Abdul Rahim Ayub—it is important also to look at how the government has gone about accounting for a good number of passports across the country which have been sent to various individuals subsequent to application. We know through questions on notice that, when it first came to office, this government introduced a revision to the passports delivery process. To quote the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 10 August 1999—almost five years ago to the day:

quote.para: Passports Australia ceased sending mailed passports by receipted mail on 31 December 1997 in order to reduce expenditure and to provide a more convenient delivery system to its clients.

speech.para: We know from that same question:

quote.para: 1,343 passports have been reported as missing in the mail in the 18 months since the new system was introduced. 355 of these have been recovered and returned for normal use. The remainder are still missing and have been replaced.

speech.para: I repeat: 988 are still missing—have not been recovered—and who knows where they are. That was in response to the minister proudly owning an initiative which was designed `to reduce expenditure and to provide a more convenient delivery system to its clients'.

When it comes to questions of national security, particularly as it relates to security of passports, which is the subject of this legislation before the House, I would have thought that that was one of the most foolhardy measures ever initiated by the government, the minister and the department. The consequences are there for us to see, and the figures I cite are those which the minister himself has delivered to the parliament through an answer to questions on notice. It does not take a large number of people using travel documents to bring about a terrorist event—it does not take a large number of people to plan a terrorist event; it does not take a large number of people to execute a terrorist event, as the horrific events in Bali have demonstrated. It is an extraordinary indictment of wrong priorities in an age of terrorism that this could have occurred, whereby we still today have 988 missing Australian passports, in large part a consequence of a system which was introduced by the government to save money.

If we fast forward to today, the government—in a decision that appears to recognise that having 1,000 passports unaccounted for is not in the national interest—has, thankfully, reversed the ludicrous decision to post passports through the unregistered mail. On 22 July 2002, registered mail for passports was reintroduced. That was virtually nine months after September 11, and the consequences in terms of the number of passports that have gone missing are quite acute. While a reduction in the overall number of lost passports has occurred, the number of passports reported missing in the mail during 2002-03 still totalled 700. While 252 of those were subsequently recovered, 171—an astounding 38 per cent of the lost total—remained unaccounted for in 2002-03.

There are, therefore, continued significant problems when it comes to how we best secure the sending out of passports to those who apply for them. The government has corrected the method by which it mails passports out, although belatedly, but plainly there is still a problem. Ensuring that passports simply do not go missing at the point at which they are dispatched to applicants should be a leading priority for the minister and the department. The total number of passports lost in the year 2002-03—that is, in the year following Bali—was 171, and that is a matter of grave concern to us all. The ongoing security risk associated with those lost or missing passports is something for which the government is directly responsible. It is a core matter of public administration.

We understand that there will always be limitations on what government can do. You cannot have a 100 per cent fail-safe system, but I do question, in this age of terrorism, whether we cannot do better in terms of the number of passports which simply go missing in the mail. Short-term cost-cutting measures such as that introduced when the government first came into office are unrealistic when we are dealing with a matter of such profound importance as the potential misuse of passports by terrorists and others concerned with creating mischief and committing illegal acts.

As far as the changes to the law governing Australian travel documents are concerned, we are satisfied that many of the changes involve clarification and restructuring of the language, with minimal substantive change. There are some key substantive changes, however, that should be noted. These involve (1) allowing the minister to adopt particular methods or technologies for identification or other purposes under the bill, (2) changes to the grounds and processes for refusal and cancellation of passports, (3) the addition of new offences and substantially increased penalties and (4) new measures concerning the use of information and the privacy procedures surrounding that.

Several new elements of Australian passports law and policy will be introduced with the Australian Passports Bill. In summary, these include for the first time a clear statement of the entitlement of Australian citizens to a passport, and that is something which we welcome. Further, penalties for passport fraud will be increased—to 10 years imprisonment or $110,000; a framework for the use of technology will be introduced; and the exceptions to the requirement for either both parents' consent or a court order for a child to travel internationally will make clear that disputes between parents should be dealt with by the courts. Other new elements will be: improvements to the mechanism for the refusal or cancellation of a passport on law enforcement grounds or if a person is likely to engage in harmful contact; measures to minimise the problems caused by lost and stolen passports; and privacy related measures, including a transparent mechanism for obtaining information to verify identity and citizenship and to regulate the disclosure of passport information for other limited purposes.

We in the opposition, as the alternative government of Australia, support these initiatives. They are in the main sensible and long overdue, updating as they do the important provisions of the Australian passport system. In particular, we support the strengthening of penalties for offences against the Passports Act. Part 4, division 2 outlines the offences and penalties under each of a number of categories: producing false or misleading documents in relation to Australian documents; improper use or possession of an Australian travel document; selling an Australian travel document; and a range of other provisions. Regrettably, these increased penalties reflect the new circumstances in which we live and the central importance of preserving the integrity of the passport system. These offences will also apply with extraterritorial jurisdiction—that is, relevant conduct that occurs abroad may be liable to criminal prosecution in Australia.

The bill also introduces penalties for officers issuing a passport contrary to the act and for officers issuing travel related documents contrary to the act or the minister's determination, as well as for any abuse of public office. For each of these offences, the Australian Passports Bill 2004 has introduced a penalty of 10 years imprisonment or $110,000 or both. This will bring the penalties for offences under the Passports Act into line with offences in related legislation, such as the Criminal Code, section 73—people smuggling and related offences—and the Migration Act 1958, section 234. Both these acts provide for penalties of 10 years imprisonment or fines of 1,000 penalty units—$110,000—or both.

We also welcome the clarification of the reasons the minister may refuse to issue an Australian passport. Under the 1938 act, the minister or an authorised officer may issue a passport to Australian citizens. The minister must not refuse to issue a passport unless a ground for refusal applies. This would remain the case under this bill, although the language would be changed so as to emphasise Australian citizens' entitlement to passports unless a good ground for refusal applies. Division 2 of the bill outlines the reasons under which the minister may refuse to issue an Australian passport. It breaks the reasons for refusal into two groupings: subdivision A focuses on the issuing of passports to children and subdivision B focuses on law enforcement and security.

Briefly, but importantly, we support the government's proposal to update the welfare and family crisis provisions of the 1938 act. The exception in clause 11(2)(d) will complement the requirement contained in the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction that a child who has been wrongfully removed for a period of less than 12 months should be returned without delay. The exception in the new act will not, however, require the commencement of proceedings or the existence of court orders relating to the custody of a child.

We also support the principal change in new subsection 11(3), which will ensure that, if parents or a child disagree about the child travelling internationally, the dispute will be dealt with by the courts and not under the passports law. Current arrangements for the resolution of disputes are revised because they are inadequate. Approximately 25 cases annually involve applicants seeking to resolve—through the administrative review process, under the 1938 act, rather than through the courts—disputes with the child's other parent about whether their child should travel internationally. This places an onus—and probably an unacceptable onus—on departmental officers to make decisions outside of the purview of the family law system. If the matter proceeds to the AAT, DFAT becomes the respondent rather than the parent who has refused or who is not represented. A new paragraph, 48(b), will ensure that decisions to refuse to issue an Australian travel document are not reviewable under the act's review regime.

I simply say to the government, however, that, given the sensitivity which these new provisions will involve, as far as families who will be affected by them are concerned, it is important that the department keep under close and serious review the operational implications which these provisions have after a 12-month period of being in effect. The intention which underpins these changes strikes the opposition as being correct and well balanced. However, from experience, we will be able to assess, hopefully, how effective the provisions have been in dealing with the real life consular circumstances which present themselves in terms of Australian families who find themselves involved in cases of disputed arrangements for the travel of a child.

In relation to biometrics, importantly, the passports bill includes for the first time an explicit reference to the application of different technologies in support of the integrity of the Australian passport. Such technology applications would include facial biometrics. Some concern has been expressed as to the personal invasiveness of that technology during the application process. In discussions with the department, we have been advised that the application process involves, in its current form, the current procedure of providing a photograph from which the relevant data is then obtained. Nonetheless, clause 47 of the bill would allow the minister to authorise through a determination that a particular method or technology may be used for the purpose of confirming the identity of an applicant or travel document holder, or for any other functions under the bill. The clause would allow any methods or technologies to be used which confirm the `validity of evidence of the identity' of applicants or travel document holders. Such technology includes facial biometrics—measurements of a person's face that can allow identification of that person by a computer.

Given the breadth of the language, we on this side of the House have some concerns that in its current form it could also include broader applications, including future fingerprinting or use of genetic information. It is not surprising that the issue of the use of private information arising from the application of new technologies therefore remains a contentious one. We are not prima facie opposed to new technologies being applied; we simply at this stage, however, register the legitimate concerns that some in the community have about the ultimate impact of some of these potential technologies on civil liberties in this country.

This is particularly so given the interaction of clause 47, `The Minister may authorise use of particular methods and technologies', and clause 42, `Disclosure of personal information for the purposes of this Act.' The bill may be broad enough to allow the creation of a large database of biometric or other personal information for uses beyond the immediate scope of the Passports Act. In its current form, the bill provides no rules governing how such information is to be collected, stored, protected or used. The minister's determination would decide the bulk of these under paragraph 2 of clause 47 and clause 46. The Privacy Act 1988 would also impose some limitations. In its current form, therefore, this clause would give the minister a very broad power indeed to make rules for the collection of information, including the adoption of controversial biometric technology, both in its current and prospective forms.

While the ministerial determination is a disallowable instrument, allowing for some level of parliamentary scrutiny, the broad ranging powers that could be invoked by the minister under this clause have led to the view that we should seek an amendment to it. These matters have been discussed with the minister's office and the department. While we appreciate that, in the absence of a particular provision for the management of information collected, the information would be governed by the information privacy principles of the Privacy Act, we believe that more can, and should, be done.

Given that the goal is to use biometric information, for example, to maintain the integrity of the passport/travel document system, we are seeking an amendment to impose specific limitations on the scope of ministerial discretion in relation to the use of such technology and/or methods of collection, storage and dissemination that could be provided under clause 47. The opposition would therefore support inserting defining language to reflect the purpose of the ministerial determination and the level and nature of the personal information being recorded and to time-limit the storage of such information. I understand that the government has indicated that it supports amending clause 47. We are grateful that the government agrees with our concerns. We will move in another place an amendment to limit subclause 47(2) along the following lines: `If the determination relates to the use of personal information, the nature of the personal information and the purpose for which it will be used must be specified.' A note to clause 47, in the same style as the one to the previous clause, shall be added along the following lines: `Information collected under this section must be dealt with in accordance with section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988, including information privacy principles 1 and 4.' These amendments will provide for greater security of personal information and will narrowly limit the minister's discretion over the dissemination and use of information collected for the purposes of passport scrutiny.

We on this side of the parliament fully recognise that difficult balances have to be achieved here. We do not adopt an irresponsible oppositionist approach to this for the sake of opposition itself. These are difficult questions which confront the decision maker, who is the minister, the department, which is responsible for administering this act, and, in addition, those in the wider community who are concerned about any long-term impact of a deleterious nature on this nation's long-cherished tradition of civil liberties. We believe, with the amendments that we have put forward responsibly—and I thank the government for its positive response to them—that we can achieve a somewhat better balance than is contained in the original draft.

Therefore, from the opposition's perspective, if these amendments are adopted by the government in the Senate, we find no cause to oppose the bill and would support it in its current terms. If we reflect again on our broader circumstances, practical measures such as this govern the physical administration of our passport and visa procedures—and how we run things at the coalface with those who enter this country and those who leave this country. These matters represent a fundamental contribution to the substance of maintaining and enhancing this nation's national security in an exceptionally difficult age. In this age of terrorism in which we live, passport security and the overall integrity of the border protection system are fundamental. When we are concerned more broadly about the war against terrorism, globally and in the region, it is practical matters of this nature which cause the country to realise that we who are involved in the decision-making processes here in Canberra have to take practical and often difficult decisions which may have an effect on some traditional freedoms that are being exercised.

I think all of us in this place need to reflect on what will happen when the new biometric passports come into effect in this country. Some Australians, when they have first contact with this system, may find some of the things which they encounter through the application and dispensing process unfamiliar and confronting. I think we need to begin to warn the Australian public that these things will occur. But, with appropriate and intelligent support from both sides of the parliament and a rational and dispassionate debate about it, we can achieve good things for the country and good things for the nation's security. However, to conclude on this, when it comes to what is still a fundamental and continuing element of national security—that is, how we best protect passports once issued and sent out to the Australian public—losing a few hundred a year and having lost several hundred in previous years is a practical problem which needs the department's urgent attention. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I listened with interest to the member for Griffith's contribution on the Australian Passports Bill 2004 and follow him once again in debate in this House. It is interesting that, despite the long rhetorical contribution by the member for Griffith that we have experienced, the bottom line is that he supports these measures and, with the amendments that the minister has indicated the government will support, we do have support from the opposition with regard to the key measures of the bill.

speech.para: In terms of the member for Griffith's key area of criticism, which was the number of passports lost each year—something he made quite a focus of in his criticism—I noticed that the total number lost last year in the mail was 355. Of course, we would rather there be no passports lost, but it should be borne in mind that one million passports are issued each year and these 355 that were lost in the post were subsequently cancelled. The member for Griffith is quite renowned for his rhetorical flourishes, but it is stretching the issue a little too much to say that these losses endanger Australia's security. They represent .03 per cent of the total number of passports issued, and the lost passports were immediately cancelled. Nevertheless, the government does appreciate the support by the opposition of these key measures which have been introduced into the House, because the integrity of the passport system is integral to the fight against terrorism on a global basis. The passport system is important to the protection of Australia's security and the protection of our borders. It is also crucial that we have an effective passport system in order to maintain the vitality of the Australian tourism industry.

The tourism industry is now Australia's largest supplier of foreign earnings, representing some $16.5 billion each year. It does employ 650,000 people on a direct basis and some 350,000 people on an indirect basis, so it is also the largest employer in the country. As passports remain an integral and significant part of travel activities, the consultation which has occurred with the tourism industry is important and significant, and there is considerable support from the tourism industry for these changes. The legislation we have now is 66 years old and should undoubtedly have been changed long ago to meet requirements, but the current focus on global terror means that these changes have become absolutely essential.

It is also important to recognise how many passports are issued each year—some one million—and how many Australians hold passports. Some 40 per cent of Australians hold passports. If you compare that to the United States, you will see that about 20 per cent of Americans hold passports. We are a community that travels extensively, and we certainly want to ensure that all Australians have the right to continue to travel. That enriches our country and our culture and also reflects the very multicultural nature of our community. So the changes to the act are important and significant on several grounds.

The main purposes of the bill are threefold. Firstly, it maintains Australian citizens' access to passports of the highest integrity that establish the bearer's identity and citizenship. Of course, this legislation enables biometric identification to be used in the future, and I noted with interest the outline given by the member for Griffith of the changes that have been made in various parts of the world—or research which has been undertaken. We are hoping that we will move in the long-term future to these biometric identification measures. The use of facial biometrics in passports would eliminate much of the fraud which currently exists, and the use of irises is one of the key ways that has been identified as a means of establishing identity.

I am aware that the government is undertaking research in this area to see where we can move to and to see what the experiences of two American airports that have introduced these biometric measures have been. We look forward to research and development in this area, because these measures do ensure greater integrity of our border protection measures and of Australian passports, and we look forward to research into and development of the usage of these measures in assessing those who come to our borders and establishing the veracity of their claims. We know that there are a number of people—and I have met refugee applicants in this category—who have used false passports and come into the country as a result. These measures are being tightened up, and the penalties which are included in this bill are important in that regard. This bill does not only improve checks, enabling biometric measures to be introduced; it also introduces penalties for those who use false Australian passports and someone else's identity to travel internationally. It is important that those penalties be established.

The penalties have increased from two years imprisonment or $5,000 to 10 years imprisonment or $110,000. Some might think that that is excessive. When you consider the vulnerability that we have for allowing people into the country who do have security risks associated with their backgrounds then you can see why these penalties are being imposed. That relates to the second aim of this bill, which is to ensure that the passports law complements national security, border protection, Australian law enforcement measures and international law enforcement cooperation. Certainly this bill will ensure greater accountability of agencies, such as police and ASIO, which are responsible for law enforcement and national security. It will ensure that all appropriate types of conduct will be covered.

The bill provides for the ability to cancel or refuse passports, with a requirement that reasons be given for that cancellation or refusal. That is significant: the new act will set out clear reasons for the refusal and cancellation of a passport and there will be a comprehensive regime for review of any decisions. Reasons for refusal or cancellation will include that a person is likely to engage in, be charged with or be sentenced for specified serious crimes including terrorism, child sex tourism, child abduction or sexual slavery, people smuggling and drug trafficking. We regard all of those as being serious crimes and the cancellation of a passport for those reasons would seem highly appropriate.

The third aspect of this bill is to introduce a legal structure which will ensure consistency with family law, privacy and administrative law principles. There are some questions about the greater difficulty in getting children's passports and whether or not that is necessary. In the past, what has been required in getting a passport for a child is the signature of both parents. But we have had experiences of children being abducted and we need to protect the rights of both parents. I am sure we have all read heart-rending stories of abduction of a child by one parent, making it impossible for the parent based in Australia to have access to that child. Often the child will disappear. The standard requirement is for a court order. The new act will make it clear that disputes between parents should be dealt with by the courts. So it is not simply a matter of going along to the passport office to sort the matter out. There is a requirement that it go back to the court to decide whether the passport will be issued and whether one parent can take the child overseas. Special circumstances, such as where one parent cannot be located, in which exceptions to the requirements can be made will be set out clearly under the new act. We all want to ensure that parents have rights in the issuing of passports and that they do not experience the enormous difficulties and heart-rending problems that occur when a child disappears offshore.

So those are the three key aspects of this bill. The first is maintaining Australian passports of the highest integrity which establish the bearer's identity and citizenship. The bill does include a clear statement of the entitlement of an Australian to a passport. I am sure we all would agree with that. Secondly, this bill ensures that the passports law complements the national security objectives that all of us in this House would support. I was very interested to hear that continuing support from the member for Griffith, who supported the key provisions and objectives of this bill. The penalties that are imposed are in line with the threats that the false use of passports would incur.

There is also the important development of the new technology. As this is a fast-moving field it is being experimented with overseas. I believe that we should really concentrate our resources to be the leader in technology internationally. With 20 million Australians, some 40 per cent of whom hold passports, and with five million international visitors each year, we do have the ability to provide leadership internationally. We are seen as one of the leading tourism countries in the world. You need only look at some of the international publications. Travel and Leisure has just awarded Sydney the top travel destination in the world for the ninth year in a row. Australia is usually in the top five of any international listing of preferred tourism destinations. That is why we should get it right and why we can be at the vanguard of new technology.

There is a problem with lost and stolen passports. There are those who seem to have a habit of continually losing their passport. The member for Griffith mentioned passports that are lost in the mail. More significant are those which people simply lose. Some people have lost their passport two, three, four and five times. Last year a total of 32,479 passports were recorded as lost or stolen. This, to my mind, is the more significant occurrence. The ones that are lost by Australia Post are immediately cancelled, whereas it often takes some time before an individual is aware that their passport has been lost or stolen.

This legislation enables the minister to determine the penalties involved. The length of time of the validity of the passport can be limited. A significantly increased fee can also be imposed as a penalty for the loss of a passport. There are those who hold passports and continually lose them. The question could be raised as to whether some of those passports are finding their way into the hands of people smugglers or the hands of those who want to use them for global terrorism. Of course that is one of the very reasons why these penalties are being introduced and why there is such concern—32,479 is a lot of lost passports. Concentration on those factors is important. There are questions in relation to privacy and identity issues, as well as the involvement of biometrics in the privacy issues. I believe the more important national security questions override those issues in this case. Nevertheless, the need to maintain privacy is an ongoing issue.

One of the problems with the fee structure in the past has been whether the fee related to passports is regarded as a cost recovery measure or a tax. The way it has been handled in the past, under the old 1938 bill, has caused questions concerning the raising of the costs involved. The actual costs each year amount to some $100 million, so it is significant in terms of cost recovery. This bill allows the passport office to establish the increased fees. Nevertheless, I am sure that the tourism industry would want to ensure that, with departure taxes and airport levies et cetera, we do not have excessive passport costs providing a further penalty on the tourism industry. But I am sure that, from what we have seen in the past, there will be modest increases in this area.

There are a range of measures in this new legislation that we welcome and, of course, after 66 years it is appropriate that we have these significant changes. There are important changes there. The legislation maintains the right of every Australian to hold a passport, but the new measures ensure greater integrity for our passports, greater protection of our borders and greater protection against terrorism. These measures complement our national security measures, border protection measures and law enforcement measures. The measures included in the bill in relation to biometric measuring devices for passports are welcome. The penalties established in this bill—the two years imprisonment—are important antiterrorism measures. The penalties against those who needlessly or recklessly do not safeguard the security of their passports are also important, not so much as a penalty for their tardiness but rather to prevent the potential for the passports to get into the wrong hands and be used for illegal travel and passport fraud. Of course, the darker side of it all is the possibility of the passports being used for terrorism purposes.

Australians are extensive travellers. We do have a viable tourism industry, and the passport is central to it. On this side of the House we welcome the opposition's support for the legislation, and we have listened to their proposed amendment in relation to the biometrics. It is legislation which should be supported because of its support for the tourism industry, its support of border protection in this country, its support of the fight against global terrorism, its support of the use of new technology in border protection, its support of the protection of parents and its penalties for those who abuse our passports. It is a well thought out measure. I congratulate those in the passport office who have been involved in the development of the legislation, as well as those involved from the minister's office and the department. I certainly commend the legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: —I support the Australian Passports Bill 2004 and I associate myself with the general remarks of my colleague the shadow minister for foreign affairs. I propose to make some brief remarks in my capacity as the shadow minister for immigration. Passports are of course essential to the movement of people. In our passport system and in our immigration system, we need to ensure the integrity of the movement of people. In the modern day, that is absolutely important. In the modern day, taking sensible precautions based on modern technology against passport fraud and identity fraud are absolutely essential. In recent times, we have had some very bad examples of identity fraud, passport fraud or lax procedures so far as passports, movement of people and visa arrangements are concerned. The Willie Brigitte example is but one—perhaps the best or the worst as the case may be. So it is absolutely essential that our passport system and our movement-of-people system and their administration have integrity. If we have confidence in the integrity of those systems, then we can not only proceed confidently for our own part but also require and ask the same high standards of others when it comes to their systems and the integrity of their people movement procedures.

speech.para: These measures are sensible in my view. The most important aspects of them, in very many respects, and the areas where I wish to focus my remarks are biometrics and the use of modern-day technology to ensure integrity of movement of people and integrity of passport and travel arrangements. With biometrics we see the use of, for example, fingerprint, facial or iris—eye—screening. Not only do we need to be at the forefront of international developments and use of this technology, we also need to make sure we are keeping up.

Look at some of the recent international developments. In the first half of 2003 the International Civil Aviation Organisation, ICAO, adopted what they described as a `global harmonized blueprint for the integration of biometric identification into passports' and other machine-readable travel documents or MRTDs, as they are known in the trade. ICAO referred to the use of various available biometric techniques: face, fingers and eyes.

The United States, an important trading partner and an important country with whom we have many people-movement exchanges, had until recently a deadline of October this year for machine-readable passports with biometric identifiers. The deadline was extended to October 2005 to enable other jurisdictions to make the necessary technological developments. For some time the United States has had a number of pilot posts for biometric visa programs.

In the UK, another important country so far as people movement to and from Australia is concerned, the UK Passport Service conducted a six-month trial of biometric identifiers in the first half of this year. In December 2003 the UK Home Office stated that the UK Passport Service was planning to begin issuing in the middle of next year passports which included facial biometrics and was also giving consideration to secondary biometrics—iris and fingerprint—in subsequent versions.

Other European countries, such as Belgium and Denmark, and the European Union itself are proceeding along comparable or similar lines. In February of this year the European Commission adopted a proposal for the inclusion of facial biometrics in European Union passports. In February of this year, Germany initiated a trial of iris scanning at some of their border posts. The list goes on. So, not only is it important for the integrity of our own system that we proceed to adopt, adapt and apply these modern-day scientific and technological techniques, it is also important that we keep up with developments in relevant jurisdictions.

Recently the minister for immigration officially opened a Biometrics Testing Facility in Canberra, which she described as being `designed to enhance Australia's efforts in border security' and to operate against identity fraud. The Biometric Testing Facility in Canberra is described as using `practical applications of new technologies such as facial recognition, fingerprint and iris scanning to assess how these technologies could be integrated into DIMIA's existing processes'. DIMIA staff are actively involved in applying the technology to identity and border management.

At the time I welcomed that. I think that is an important facility. The minister in her remarks at the opening of the facility made the point that she regarded the use of biometrics as being an important tool for entry. I made the point at the time that that is a limited view because you can use biometrics not just for entry requirements but also for compliance.

On the same day as the minister opened the biometric testing laboratory in Canberra she released the department's immigration compliance report, Managing the border: immigration compliance, 2002-03 edition. Those familiar with the compliance report will be aware that it covers a four-year period. In terms of compliance, my point is that we need to be thinking of using biometrics not just for entry requirements but also for compliance.

If you have a look at the report you will find that it again confirms that, at any point in time, we will have in Australia up to 60,000 illegal foreign, non-Australian citizens present. Of those 60,000, up to half will be working. Those people will be in Australia illegally—non-Australian citizens illegally in Australia—either because they have overstayed the time period of their visa or because they are in breach of a particular visa condition. These people are here illegally, in contradistinction to those people who might come here as unauthorised arrivals and claim our protection under the refugee convention.

The report also makes it crystal clear that, in this area, neither the government nor the department has done anything over a four-year period. I remember in November or December of 2000 the former minister for immigration indicating that the government would introduce legislation to impose sanctions on employers who knowingly employed illegal foreign workers. A month or two ago the current minister issued the same statement. There is only one problem: over four years, nothing has occurred. So there is a serious deficiency here in the government's administration. There is a neglect of policy. There is a seriously limited long-term view that biometrics cannot be applied or utilised for compliance as well as entry.

Labor has a proposal for an illegal foreign worker's card which would mean a simple `no card, no work'. We propose to link that card in the future to biometric information, so that the biometric information contained in the illegal foreign worker's card would be linked to the information contained in the department of immigration, the visa office and the Australian Taxation Office. So it would be an effective method of compliance.

So there are 60,000 non-Australian citizens illegally present in Australia at any point in time. The government have done nothing about that for at least four years. Up to 30,000 of them are working illegally at any point in time. Four years ago the government promised legislation to impose sanctions on employers who knowingly employ illegal foreign workers. They have done nothing. Now, regrettably, at that point in the cycle when we should be embracing the use of biometrics across the board, the government say, through the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, that they are not interested in utilising biometric information for compliance purposes. This, to my mind, is very short-sighted.

In the course of making his remarks on the bill on behalf of the opposition, the member for Griffith, the shadow minister for foreign affairs, made the point that he had raised with the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs a privacy concern, to which the government had responded sensibly and, in general terms, favourably. I think that point is right. On my reading of the legislation, in terms of the use of biometrics, it would be possible under the legislation to embed the biometric material in the passport itself—a machine-readable travel document which I referred to earlier—or to keep it in a central database, which is one of the models that the United States is looking at or intending to use in its own visit scheme. In either model there is a privacy concern.

Earlier this year the House and the parliament considered the Migration Legislation Amendment (Identification and Authentication) Bill 2004. That piece of migration legislation was looking at the future use of biometrics for identity and document fraud so far as non-Australian citizens were concerned. Both in this House and in the other place questions of privacy were raised. That bill was referred to the relevant Senate committee and the government sensibly responded favourably to some of the privacy suggestions made in respect of that bill, including about the use of biometrics for identification and authentication of non-Australian citizens in terms of people movement and border protection.

If we can accord that approach to non-Australian citizens then it is obviously sensible that we accord the same general approach to Australian citizens so far as passport data is concerned. Whilst I am not suggesting that the particular measures in that legislation necessarily need to be applied here, I am pleased that the issue has been raised, that the government seems to have responded favourably in general terms and that it seems happy to incorporate some details on how personal information can be utilised—requiring specification of detail when that personal information is proposed to be obtained or utilised and generally bringing the matter under the umbrella of the Privacy Act 1988. I think that is a sensible concern that has been raised and a sensible response from the government in general terms.

These are important measures in very many respects. I suspect that at the moment they will be underappreciated by the Australian community. As the procedures and requirements come to be adopted and Australian citizens, when they obtain their passports, are faced with what they will no doubt regard as higher standards and higher requirements on them, we may, in our electorate offices and ministerial offices, get the odd criticism, query or complaint. Whilst there may well be some administrative teething problems, I think it will be incumbent on all of us at the time to make the point that it is absolutely essential in the modern day that our passport system is one of integrity, that our immigration and border controls have integrity and that we ensure that we utilise modern-day technology that includes, in particular and especially, biometric information.

The modern day will demand, warrant and require that biometric information be contained in travel documents, in my view, not just for entry purposes but also for compliance purposes. In that context, these are sensible measures which the parliament should embrace and which I am sure our colleagues in the Senate will also embrace. While they might look at the privacy point in detail, I am sure that will be resolved amicably and sensibly, as the adoption generally of these measures will enhance our capacity for integrity in our passport arrangements and integrity in our people-movement arrangements.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
Mr BILLSON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Griffith, the member for Cook and also the member for Perth for their contributions to this debate. It is an important package of legislation. As the member for Perth was alluding to, it might not be immediately obvious to some citizens, but this is an important package of legislation, comprising the Australian Passports Bill 2004, the Australian Passports (Application Fees) Bill 2004 and the Australian Passports (Transitionals and Consequentials) Bill 2004. I particularly thank the member for Griffith and the member for Perth for indicating the opposition's support for the legislation.

speech.para: I would like to draw attention to the member for Cook's contribution. As an ardent advocate of the tourism industry, he would no doubt be aware that the Herald Sun in Melbourne has reported, in an article headed `Resurgence in new passports', that Australians are flocking overseas. The article talked about Australian travellers thumbing their noses at terrorists and applying for passports in record numbers. The number of passports issued by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was up 17 per cent last financial year. The department's division of consular and passport services does an outstanding job. It is a key friend and ally and part of team Australia, looking after international travellers from this country. The only thing the member for Cook did not do was to encourage travellers to look at smartraveller.gov.au for the latest information on travel destinations and some really practical, helpful hints on how to make their travel a success and as enjoyable as it can be.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs said when introducing these bills, the government wants to ensure that Australians can continue to rely on a travel document of the highest integrity which clearly establishes their identity and their citizenship. To do this, the government has brought to the parliament a legal structure for Australia's world-class passport system, based on three core themes: modernisation, clarification and enhancement. These themes are addressed in a number of ways throughout the package of bills before the House, and I would like to highlight some of the key elements: identity fraud, national security, law enforcement and children's passports.

Penalties for passport fraud would be increased up to $110,000 or a 10-year jail term from the current $5,000 or two-year jail term that the present act provides. These penalties are the same as those for comparable offences for people smuggling. A set of measures aimed at reducing the number of lost and stolen passports are also included in the legislation. The government's policy approach is twofold: to emphasise the importance of protecting passports and to stop the misuse of lost or stolen passports.

It is worth reflecting on some of the comments from the member for Griffith. The integrity and security of our passports and the passport system is not simply about the point of delivery. It is about the application process, with the supporting evidence, which is verified; processing procedures; the detection of fraud through that process; production—we have a secure production facility that produces tamper-proof passports; the issuing of passports, which was a point the member for Griffith chose to focus on; and also their use. That whole system goes to the question of the security of our passports.

The member for Griffith alluded to the 343 passports reported as missing in the mail in the 18 months since the new initiative was introduced. The member for Griffith failed to convey that all passports lost are cancelled and cannot be used to leave or return to Australia. Efforts are also continuing through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to enhance the partnership with Australia Post to get the number of lost passports down to zero. But, as I think the member for Cook pointed out, the number of passports that are not reaching their destination equates to 0.3 per cent, so we need to get this in context. Efforts are also being made to exchange information on lost and stolen passports with other countries. Again to enforce the fact that a lost or stolen passport becomes inoperable, we are working with other countries to ensure that our systems are as complementary as they can be.

One million passports are issued each year. Fraud related activity is also being given greater attention within the department of foreign affairs with the recent creation of a new section within DFAT, with this goal as its express purpose. I mentioned that the passport itself has in-built integrity measures. The Australian passport—a world-class document, a secure document—is virtually tamper proof. Laser cuts in the paper and other security features mean that the data page will tear away if there is an attempt to remove the laminate. So people who watch CSI and see things happening there—a photo slipping into an identification document—and then try to relate them to the Australian passport ignore some of the tamper-proof features that are embedded as a feature of the world-class Australian passport. The document has been tested widely and has been internationally commended for its tamper-evident features. That is, if someone messes with it, one can tell. That is an important issue, putting in context some of the points of the member for Griffith.

The new act will enable us to combat identity fraud through the use of emerging technologies such as biometrics. The use of biometric technology has attracted some attention over the past few years. The Australian Passports Bill 2004 sets out a framework for the use of that technology at clause 47. As indicated by the opposition, the government is receptive to some refining and finetuning of that provision in the other place. The government will continue in consultation processes as far as possible with its research and development program for the introduction of facial biometric technology. Some of the speakers spoke about iris biometric technologies. The algorithms that can go into a biometric feature may take into account a range of other facial features—facial structure and things of that kind. Again, there is work in progress there, and Australia is at the forefront of that work.

If this technology is adopted, the details of its use in passports will be set out in a ministerial determination which will be subject to parliamentary approval. The minister has consistently emphasised the need to introduce these technologies in a manner which maintains community confidence in the protection of people's privacy but which is also complementary to the integrity and security of our passport system. Accordingly, the determination would detail the nature of the information to be collected—in the case we are working to, a photograph—and the purpose for which it is to be used to assist in identifying fraudulent passport applications and detecting fraudulent use of a passport.

It is worth reflecting on some of the comments by the opposition. Whilst the government is happy to work cooperatively with the opposition on finetuning the specific provisions of clause 47, we should not miss the apparent contradiction in some of the points that have been made by the opposition. The provisions in this bill which the opposition seeks to elaborate further go to limiting the application of this technology and being clear about the privacy concerns that are a part of it and therefore, through that declaration, being quite specific about the material to be collected and its application. That is quite consistent with the government's aims for this package of legislation. But, in the next breath, the opposition is arguing that we are not using biometric technologies and systems for other applications. You have heard some of the examples put forward by the opposition. It is an interesting debating point, but the inconsistency in those two thoughts—arguing that there is a need to constrain the application and then seeking to score a political point against the government for not broadening the application of that very same data—is something that I will leave others to reflect upon. But, in specific relation to this bill, the government is prepared to accommodate clause 47 refinements that the opposition has suggested.

Clause 47 relates to the future application of technology, but the current issue for us is biometrics. In the case of the passport system, this means facial biometrics such as photographs and the metrics applying to facial structure and facial features. The Australian passport system has a reputation for being a world leader in the use of cutting edge technology. As I mentioned, we should not overlook the great credit that successive governments and DFAT have gained over the years.

There was also some criticism by the member for Griffith that the government was, in his words, dragging its feet. Again, it might be a cheap debating point but it is one that needs to be looked at in the context of what has actually been going on. Australia has been leading the world in the development of this technology. Australia is in the vanguard—it is leading the world in the development and application of this technology. Other countries have not been able to provide environments which would guarantee international interoperability. There is no point in us functioning solely as an island. To achieve the potential of this technology and to fulfil the purpose for which we are investigating it, this technology needs to work in conjunction with other jurisdictions. We cannot blindly trot off into the sunset and do our own thing and then find that the world-class technology in our passports can only be used here. A passport is a travel document so there is another destination involved.

Australia will be in a position to introduce biometrics when others are providing it and can support the infrastructure. The investment of around $6 million to date is focused on research and development to justify what the full implementation outlay would involve. That is in the order of $150 million to $160 million. It makes some sense to hasten with care but be very much at the leading edge of the development of this technology. The government is doing that. It is patently unreasonable to suggest that the government has been dragging its feet. We are not aware of any other country which is using biometric technology in passports as yet. There is a need to distinguish what others are doing in the visa area from the application of this emerging technology in passports. We are not aware of any country more advanced in the development of the use of biometrics for passports than our own.

The new act will explicitly allow for refusal or cancellation of a passport if an Australian is likely to engage in, is charged with or has been sentenced for specific serious crimes. These crimes will include child sex tourism, child abduction, sexual slavery, drug trafficking, people smuggling and terrorism. The existing powers to cancel a passport are also incorporated. They relate to the prospect of prejudicing national security. That feature of the current act has been retained in this bill. The administration of these provisions will be clarified, with the act making clear that it is the responsibility of the law enforcement or security agencies to assess that a person should be prevented from travelling. A person's passport would then be refused or cancelled to complement the national security or law enforcement objective.

In the tricky area of children's passports, the basic requirement for the issuing of a passport for children—that both parents' consent or a court order be obtained—has been retained. Some flexibility is necessary, with the complexity of modern travel and relationships, and the regime for applying exceptions is set out in the bill and explanatory memorandum. However, an important new element has been included, and that is when the department is asked to apply these exceptions in circumstances where there is a dispute between the parents about whether their child can travel internationally. A declaration may be made that the matter should be dealt with by a court. DFAT has many gifted people, but resolving family disputes is not a core competency of the department. Currently, in these cases, difficult, heart-wrenching and often conflict-ridden administrative decisions are made in that environment by passport officers outside the formal policy and legislative framework established under the family law system. Obtaining a passport should not trump a family law outcome.

These amendments seek to ensure that the family law related issues are resolved first, prior to a decision being made about the issuing of a passport. I should stress that the government is committed to the smooth operation of these family law related issues. The bill does not limit which court should resolve these disputes: the Family Court of Australia, the Federal Magistrates Court and, in some cases, state and territory courts have jurisdiction to do so.
