The choice of a court is a matter for the parents and not mandated by the department. In addition, the department will maintain its close consultation with the courts to ensure that this process operates as smoothly as possible. I should emphasise that the overall policy objective of these provisions is to protect children from abduction and to protect the rights of parents.

In conclusion, I should note the broad impact of this legislative package. Eight million Australians hold passports, and it is important that the passport system reflects their needs. We have a world-class passport system. I mentioned earlier that one million passports are issued per year, each being issued in an average of less than 10 days. We use leading edge work-flow systems and other technologies. We have a record of using the latest technologies and being in the vanguard of the development of new and emerging technologies. We were one of the first to introduce machine readable zones and digitised images on our passports. Australia was the first country to use a unique floating image—a jumping kangaroo—in the laminate. Clients are well serviced by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, with nine passport offices in Australia. Applicants can apply at over 100 locations overseas and there are 1,700 Australia Post outlets around Australia ready to assist people with the passport application process. These three bills will strengthen the capacity and integrity of an already world-class Australian passport system and I am delighted to commend them to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

debateinfo.title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (2004 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 June, on motion by Mr Pyne:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Budget Measures) Bill 2004 implements two of the 2004 budget measures in the FaCS portfolio. On the face of it the measures are positive but, as always with this government, whenever you scratch the surface they always have an agenda to claw benefits back. The bill gives effect to two 2004 FaCS budget measures. Schedule 1 amends the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to exempt the fee waiver and fee pay scholarships from the income test for income support payments. Schedule 2 amends the Social Security Act 1991 to expand the eligibility criteria for the carer allowance by allowing a new group of carers to be qualify for carer allowance if they provide certain care for an adult with a disability, even if they do not live with that adult. Under this measure the required care must be provided on a daily basis for at least 20 hours per week. Both measures are beneficial and will be supported. However, they need to be seen in the light of the government's previous treatment of carers.

speech.para: Last year the government axed 30,000 families with disabled children from the carer allowance, something that the opposition drew attention to at the time. At the time we also drew attention to the fact that there were leaked budget proposals from the FaCS portfolio in a 62-page cabinet-in-confidence letter to the Prime Minister. The letter from the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, outlined her budget strategy and bid for 23 key budget measures. Among those measures were some for carers, including this small beneficial measure before us today, but the government at that stage intended to pay for it by cutting payments to those who apply for benefits in the future. This cold-hearted measure proposed cutting $30 million from the carer allowance by restricting backdating provisions. Families waiting for the diagnosis of serious conditions would no longer be allowed to backdate claims when loved ones fall ill. It really does give you an insight into the priorities of the Howard government: they are interested only in their own re-election—so they will deliver a small expansion of carer allowance before the election, while in their bottom drawer are plans to cut that benefit afterwards.

This is central to the government's whole political strategy. It pretends to be Father Christmas on the eve of the election, but after the election it behaves like Scrooge. We have seen this across the board in this budget: additional benefits for families that could not be provided in the previous three or nine years, and suddenly a river of gold flows to the people and they are expected to believe that this government has a generous heart. But when you go to the core documents from which this government operates, such as the cabinet-in-confidence submission from Senator Patterson from around November last year, you see how cold-hearted the Howard government is and what it would do if it were re-elected for a further three years.

On page 7 of this cabinet-in-confidence document are the nasty proposals that the government is not talking about prior to the election but would implement if it were re-elected in one or two months time. I will quote from the document. It says that the `proposals in the package are linked, and most require changes to legislation'. It continues, `The fourth proposal is a savings proposal that would reduce the period for backdating payment of carer allowance to 12 weeks for both adults and children from the current 26 weeks for adults and the 52 weeks for children, and would substantially offset over four years the costs of the additional assistance proposal.' What was the additional assistance proposal? We are seeing that today—that is here, all right. The additional assistance proposal—which is overdue and welcome—was going to be paid for by the nasty hidden proposal revealed in this document which, strangely enough, did not see the light of day in the budget but is there for after the election.

You can see the extent that it is there for after the election when you get to attachment A10 in the cabinet-in-confidence document. A10 sets out this measure that I have described before which commences early next year. This measure, where the government say, `We've finally recognised the needs of people receiving carer allowance. There was an anomaly whereby if someone wasn't living in the same residence they couldn't get their carer allowance. Well, now they can. Aren't we jolly good fellows?' is to be funded after the election with cutbacks which will hit a large number of people. That is what the government's documentation indicates.

If there was ever a bill that demonstrated the failure of the Howard government to grasp and face up to the big challenges—the big ideas and solutions that are required to meet our social challenges in this country—it is this one. This bill, as I said, extends the carer allowance to a small group who have previously been excluded, and that is welcome. But it is an initiative which has been built on the back not just of the cutbacks that are coming after the election if the government are re-elected but of the cutbacks from knocking 30,000 carers off carer allowance in the last 18 months—they ripped it away! It was the political backlash that flowed from their attack on those 30,000 families that made this government come forward with their one-off $600 payment in the budget—they were so on the nose amongst the hard-pressed carers of our community.

What do we get in this bill? Another short-term fix, no long-term plan for carers and one-off $600 payments. Fix the small anomaly here which will help a small group of people, hide the nasty proposals in the cabinet submission until after the election and then claw the $600 back by other means afterwards—that is the approach of this government. And all of that is built on the other fundamental attack that remains in the system and that is held up by Labor in the Senate, which is the attempt by the government to cut the disability support pension by $70 a fortnight for a large number of disability support pensioners. This is something that is going to receive a fair bit of attention in the coming debate about the future of our country: the government's proposals to cut the disability support pension by $70 a fortnight, and their ultimate goal to attack the indexation method of pensions and take them down for not only working age pension recipients but the whole lot. That is the ultimate objective of the Howard government.

This measure that we are looking at today is another short-term fix. It is a short-term fix which comes in the middle of a sea of attacks. I see the member for Herbert is present in the chamber. I wonder what he has had to say to those local families in his electorate who were knocked off the carer allowance. What did he say to them? And what is he going to say to them if he is re-elected when the government comes back with its plans in those cabinet submissions which will further attack those people who are seeking to access a future carer allowance? What is he going to say to all those people who may have their disability support pension cut—the thousands of them in the federal electorate of Herbert who may have their disability support pension cut by $70 a fortnight—if the government is re-elected and is successful in getting that measure through the parliament? All of this illustrates the determination of the Howard government simply to play politics—short-term politics—whilst it has a long-term plan hidden in the bottom drawer to punch some very big holes in our social safety net.

After nine years of playing Scrooge, it is suddenly Christmas, and the government are lavishing new benefits on people—no amount of money is too big. Last year they could not fund the pneumococcal vaccine; this year rivers of gold are flowing. But do you know what will happen? After the election they will come and steal it all back. Do you know why we know that? Because that is exactly what they did after the last election. It is Groundhog Day now, because just before the last election there were $300 payments to seniors on the eve of the election and $1,000 family payment debt waivers—all was flowing. There was no need to do anything else about the family payment system, because it would all go away into the future; it was all just a minor administrative problem. And now what do we have in the family payment system? Debts of $1.6 billion for 1.5 million people over the past three years—debts that the government said would never happen and would simply go away. The government have had nine years in office playing Scrooge, and suddenly it is Christmas and benefits are flowing.

We all know what will happen if this government are re-elected. They will be there to steal it all back, because at the end of the day this is a government which is full of small-time political connivers. That is essentially what they are up to. They are small-time political connivers. They are not creative thinkers. They are not facing up to the big social challenges in this country. They are just small-time political connivers. There is not a statesman among them, particularly when it comes to our social security system.

The other measure in this bill deals with scholarships. Currently, scholarships are required to be taken into account as income unless specifically exempted from the income test for income support payments. As announced in the 2004 budget, all fee waived and fee paying scholarships will no longer be included as income under the social security test for income support payments under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The exemptions will apply to scholarships offered in the secondary vocational, education training and higher education sectors. The government has estimated that the exemption will benefit approximately 1,550 students at the present time, increasing to 2,220 students.

I now come to the small carer allowance initiative in the bill—an initiative well overdue. The Social Security Act currently requires a carer to live with the person for whom they are providing care to qualify for the carer allowance. This co-residency requirement departed from the practice under the former domiciliary nursing care benefit which the carer allowance replaced from July 1999. That old benefit allowed some discretion for payment in situations where there was no co-residence. So this measure rectifies that problem. But it takes place in an environment where the government is simply attacking the living standards of an enormous number of families. It is hiding significant information that the Australian public need to have placed before them so they can evaluate the record of this government.

It is now 2½ months since the budget. It is two months since the Senate estimates hearings, where we asked this government a lot of questions about a lot of these budget measures. For the first time in history in this budget area and for this department, the government are simply refusing to supply the answers that we have requested about the carer allowance, about all of those that were removed and the circumstances of their removal. They are refusing to supply that. They are refusing to come back and answer with regard to the Labor analysis that shows that the $600 one-off family payment, which the government claim is built into the family payment system forever, disappears in five to seven years. They are refusing to come back on that. And, by their refusal to come back with information on that, they have confirmed that it does disappear. This is unprecedented—we have not had a situation ever in this portfolio where the department have simply refused to supply the answers. They have a lot to hide; they have an enormous amount to hide. What they are hiding is the fact that the $600 payment, through the swindle that they have perpetrated on indexation arrangements and family payments, is eroded in five to seven years. This is always the way the Howard government do it. They put forward an increase which exists on a temporary basis and then they come and claw it all back. That is what is going to happen to the $600 increase which they are pretending exists. That is one of the reasons that they will not answer the questions which have been put to them.

On top of that, we have the extraordinary situation where the government, in their rush to shovel the cash out of the window—they are driving down the main streets of suburban electorates just shovelling $100 bills out of the window to anyone who wants them—paid the $600 family payment to families who were not entitled to it. Some people received two payments. They were ringing up members of parliament saying, `We're not entitled to this money—we're only entitled to one, but we got two.' Suddenly, the government once again was a river to its people. Minister Patterson said: `Keep the money even if you are not entitled to it. Keep the money.' Isn't this extraordinary! After the vilification and the campaign that the government has conducted with the 30,000 families that were knocked off the carer allowance and the way in which it has denigrated people on disability support pensions, suddenly, if there is an overpayment, they are no longer cheats; they are worthy citizens.

Australians can understand that double standard and, of course, they were appalled. To begin with, all of those 34,000 families out there with pensioner concession cards who just had them ripped up were particularly appalled. During this period the government was doing a review of people who were entitled to concession cards. Suddenly, 34,000 people received a letter saying, `You are no longer entitled to your concession card—it is gone,' and not a reason was given to those people. So they understand the double standard. What they want is one standard for all, not a special standard for election bribes, where people who are overpaid $600 can suddenly keep it and other people are hunted down, have their tax returns stripped and have the debt collectors set upon them. These are double standards—one for the election and one for after the election. There is a lot more of that to come.

A week and half ago we stumbled across what is perhaps one of the biggest bungles that we have seen from this government. It usually tries to blame Centrelink for them, but it is not the fault of the people who work in Centrelink or any of the officials who administer the policy; it is the fault of the government. We suddenly find out that the government has not been telling families about the 27 family payment paydays and, in fact, people are now being overpaid. The government is refusing to tell families who are getting the additional $600 payment what their debts may be under the existing system until September and possibly later, thereby encouraging them to spend their additional moneys unaware of how much the government may be requesting back. On top of that fraud that the government has perpetrated on families, we suddenly find that the government has not taken into account the fact that there are 27 paydays so that, in this financial year in addition to the average $900 debt, these families are going to incur another $400 to $800 debt. The member for Herbert votes for this system in the House—a system that has an inbuilt debt trap which gives families on average a $900 a year debt.

And now we suddenly find that, in the next financial year, added to that debt—because of the failure of the government to tell families about the additional payday—there will be an additional debt of $400 to $800. So the minimum debt in the current financial year, which people will not find out about until after the election, is going to be $1,300.

talk.start.para: —Absolute rubbish!

—Your minister admitted it on radio. And you are so ignorant of this fact—so absolutely unaware of the problem in the family payment system—that you can say it is rubbish. He has actually said it is true. So the average debt this year, which people will not find out about until after next June, is going to be $1,300 per family.

speech.para: When we exposed this debacle and bungle, the minister said, `We told them about it, because we put it up on the web site.' About a week before we exposed the bungle, it did go up on the web site, but it went up on the web site that nobody uses. It did not go up on the Centrelink web site; it went up on the FaCS web site: in a small note down the bottom, as always—it is always in the fine print with the Howard government, never in the headline.

People should have been told about this in May, when Centrelink wrote to them telling them to put in their income estimates. The government would then have been perfectly entitled to say, `It is something we have done something about.' If people had been notified of this in May, the government would have had a defence, but they did not do that. Why didn't they do that? I will tell you why they did not do it: because they did not want to draw attention to the debt trap in their family payment system. That is why. What happened was this: they took a deliberate decision not to tell people about the 27 paydays, because that would have raised the spectre of average debts going from $900 to $1,300. That is why they did not do it.

That is why, when we look at the record of this government, I say we are simply dealing with small-time connivers, rather than creative thinkers, statesmen or people who have a vision for a family payment system and a social security system that deal with the big issues in our society and look after the long-term interests of families. They only have a vision for a short-term political fix. That is why in the budget they did not take the opportunity to fix the debt trap in the family payment system—and they should have. They took the decision to create a short-term political fix which would paper over the cracks in it. In effect, they took the decision to slosh money all over it so that people might temporarily forget about all the problems in the system.

What did that produce? It produced Australia's biggest ever pork barrel. I suppose that will be the Treasurer's legacy. I will never forget budget night, when he was giving his speech and I was sitting over there, and 50 words into the speech the Treasurer said, `This is a huge spending budget.' I nearly fell off the front bench. That is what the government accuse the Labor Party of. And huge spending it was: an extra $2 billion pumped out there in the $600 payments, hoping people would forget about the average debt of $900, which they are not going to tell them about until at least after September, and hoping they would all forget about the 27 paydays—not telling the families, so that would add to the debt. They just threw a bit of cash around and hoped people would forget about the long term—the financial headache that is coming after the election, if the government are re-elected, and the need to reform the system so that families can get their payments accurately on a fortnightly basis.

All of this demonstrates one very important point: this government have not had a third-term agenda at all, except an agenda of giving payments when they want to get re-elected and of clawing those back afterwards. Of course, work and family was supposed to be the third-term agenda. If this is work and family—making the debt trap in the family payment system bigger and only giving income tax cuts to everyone who earns over $52,000—this is a very twisted set of people. This government do not have a third-term agenda, and they certainly do not have a fourth-term agenda, except for all of the things that we have seen in their cabinet documents—such as their proposals to go after carers after the election—which they will implement after the election, if they are re-elected.

I will just go through that proposal again, because I think the carers of Australia need to be very familiar with the government's plans for them after the election. The fourth proposal is a savings proposal that would reduce the period of backdating payment of carer allowance to 12 weeks for both adults and children—currently it is 26 weeks for adults and 52 weeks for children—and would substantially offset over four years the costs of additional proposals. Just sitting there in the bottom drawer, this is another one of those clawbacks—just in the carer area. It is just like the financial headache that is going to come from the fact that the government did not notify families about the phenomenon of 27 payment periods and the additional debts coming from that after 30 June. It is just like the government's failure to fix the family payment system in this budget by trying to paper over the cracks. There will simply be debt after debt.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 81. The debate that we are hearing at the moment is not relevant at all to what is being put forward in the bill.
(Mr Hawker) —I ask the member for Lilley to come back to the bill.

—Of course, it is very relevant to the electors of Herbert—and to all those people who will receive a family payment debt and all those carers who are going to be caught in this clawback. It is very relevant to the measure in this bill which does extend a benefit to a few people, and it is very relevant to the fact that, to fund it, if you are re-elected, you are going to take more from carers overall. That is what it is very relevant to, and that is why your electors will be very interested to know your future plans for them. It is very relevant. You intend to fund this measure with bigger cutbacks after the election. That is the point. Nothing could be more relevant to this bill than that. The funding plans for this measure are in your cabinet submission, to start next year, if you are re-elected.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Lilley is indicating that the Deputy Speaker intends to fund these things and, as they are cabinet submissions, I do not think that is correct.
—Yes, I think that is a fair point of order.

—I am pleased that the member for Herbert has provided a further opportunity for me to read from Senator Patterson's submission about the proposals in the bill we are debating here. Senator Patterson, in November last year wrote to the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and put forward the measure in this bill that allows people to still receive carer allowance where there is not co-residence. I welcome that initiative. But what is not in the bill but is going to fund the proposal—as Senator Patterson's correspondence to the Prime Minister makes absolutely clear—are further cutbacks for people wanting to receive carer allowance in the future. The member for Herbert is all in favour of that, but I am sure that the carers in Townsville will be absolutely horrified to realise that he and his government are sitting on this measure, which they are not telling them about prior to the election. We will just go through that measure again. The fourth proposal, which appears on page 7 of the cabinet-in-confidence document, says:

quote.para: The fourth proposal is a savings proposal that would reduce the period of backdating payment of carer allowance to 12 weeks for both adults and children.

speech.para: That would be down from the current 26 weeks for adults and 52 weeks for children and would:

quote.para: ... substantially offset over four years the costs of the additional assistance proposals.

speech.para: That is, the additional assistance proposal which is in this bill is funded in their advance plans—which the minister submitted to the Prime Minister—by expenditure cuts that the government have not put forward to the Australian people and will only do so if they are re-elected. That is how they intend to really fund this additional measure in the budget.

The carers of Australia are awake to this government. They are aware that every time John Howard gives them something the claw comes out after the election to pull it all back. That is what this document demonstrates: that the government have the claw waiting. It is in the bottom drawer, and if they are re-elected that is how they intend to fund this measure. That is why the Australian people are sick of these small time political connivers—like the member for Herbert—who are engaged in these sorts of political games. They want a Latham Labor government, which has some positive plans for the future, which will have a fair approach to the administration of social security benefits and which will ensure that those people who are vulnerable are not the subject of these political fixes and political tricks. That is why they want a family payment system which is accurate and timely, and that is what they will get from a Latham Labor government.

talk.start.para: —I would like to start on a positive note and recognise the people who, on behalf of the government and the people of Australia, deliver benefits to those who very much need the support that the government provides—that is, I would like to recognise the good people of Centrelink. I am pleased to tell the House that, in the last measured month when an independent organisation measured the customer satisfaction rating of Centrelink, in the CNQ area of Australia—which includes the electorates of Capricornia, Dawson, Leichhardt, Herbert and Kennedy—Centrelink achieved the highest level of customer satisfaction ever recorded by any Centrelink area in the history of Centrelink. That is a fantastic achievement and just shows that, under the leadership of Peter Doutre, who is based in Townsville, Centrelink is getting better and better. I think that is recognised by its customers. It is certainly recognised by the government, but it is not recognised by the member for Lilley. Every time he makes a statement he has something sinister and nasty to say about the good people who work in Centrelink—the people who these days are doing so well at looking after those who need the assistance that the government provides.

speech.para: In relation to the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Budget Measures) Bill 2004, I would like to address a couple of matters that the member for Lilley raised in his contribution. The first matter concerns what he said that the government are doing to the disability support pension—that we are going to cut $70 a fortnight from the pension. That is just not true. We have not cut the DSP by $70 this year. We have not and will not cut the DSP in the future. End of story. Yet the member for Lilley said in the Australian parliament today, in this scare campaign, that we are going to cut the disability support pension. It is just not true; it is a nonsense.

What we are doing is proposing to take people who can work off the disability support pension and to transfer them to Newstart. That is sensible. It is sensible for a couple of reasons. I have people in my electorate who are on the disability support pension while running concreting businesses. How can they get the disability support pension and run a concreting business? I am talking about people who go out there and lay concrete. It is true; it happens. The government are not in the business of providing income support for people who run concreting businesses on disability support pensions. Secondly, for those more genuine cases who are currently on a DSP but who in fact can work, it gives them greater dignity not to be on a disability support pension. It encourages them to get out and have a go—and so they should. The member for Lilley does not seem to understand that.

In relation to the member for Lilley's claim that we are knocking 30,000 people off the carer allowance, you really need to understand what is actually happening. First of all, the Howard government very much recognise the vital role that carers play in our society, and we will continue to support them. They deserve our support. Indeed, currently we are providing carers with direct payments of almost $1.8 billion each year—that is, $1.8 billion goes to carers in direct payments. That is the kind of support that the Howard government are prepared to give to these people who provide such a good service in the community. That amount of money is a 135 per cent increase since 1999. That does not sound like a cut to me. The carer payment is provided to about 84,000 customers, and they very much appreciate the government assistance that they are given. Carer allowance is provided to over 300,000 customers. That was at a cost of $770 million in 2003-04.

With regard to the claim that 30,000 customers are being stripped of benefits or kicked off benefits, let me tell you what has actually happened. There has been a regular review process of Centrelink. It is part of the proper, businesslike approach that you would expect of a government that manages taxpayers' money properly. In this instance, 67,000 customers have been reviewed. In that review, only 2,742 carers of children with a disability failed to achieve a qualifying score. About 6,500 people contacted Centrelink and they themselves advised Centrelink that they were no longer eligible. Another 8,300 people did not respond to the review. Even though Centrelink wrote three times to those customers—and telephoned them—they did not respond. The take out of that is that more than half of the people that made up the figure claimed by the member for Lilley either acknowledged they were no longer eligible or failed to reply. Of the remainder, almost 7,000 customers continued to receive their health-care cards.

Is the member for Lilley saying to this parliament and to the Australian people that Centrelink should not review entitlements? Is he saying that the people who were getting the benefits and admitted that they were not entitled to them should continue to receive them? If that is what he is saying, what sort of management is that? It is classic Australian Labor Party rhetoric. I reject it, the government rejects it and I think the people of Australia will reject that view as well.

With regard to the measure on carer allowance in the bill before the House today, I have seen cases—as all members of parliament have—where people come to you and say, `We'd like to get a carer allowance because we are caring for an elderly relative,' and you find that in the fence between the property of, perhaps, their elderly parents—or of a next-door neighbour with whom they may have no family relationship—and their own property there is a gate and they provide care for those people next door. Yet they cannot get a carer allowance, even though they are providing the care. I have even seen cases where the carers were living in the same building but, because there was some independence for the person being cared for—that is, because there was no connecting door between the two residences and, to get from the carer's residence to where the person being cared for was living, you had to walk out the front door, go around the corner and walk up the stairs in the same building, they were not entitled to a carer's allowance. That is clearly silly and the government has recognised that. I am pleased to see that the Australian Labor Party recognises that this is a sensible measure that it will support. It is a measure that the government is pleased to put before the parliament.

I also note the rhetoric used by the member for Lilley with regard to the government's `long-term plan hidden in the bottom drawer' and the government's `cold-hearted approach' and all that sort of thing. Perhaps the member for Lilley ought to explain to the Australian people why the Australian Labor Party wants to get rid of the Medicare safety net. How can that be? Already more than half a million Australians are taking advantage of the Medicare safety net. The Medicare safety net is the mechanism whereby, if you are in receipt of some sort of concession card, if you are a child under 16 or if your medical expenses exceed $300 in one year, the government will rebate 80 per cent of your medical costs. Why would the Australian Labor Party want to take away that safety net? Remember that in relation to out-of-pocket expenses all of those people who are on the one Medicare card count, if they are all in the one family. If you are a family that does not qualify for a concession card, after an expenditure of $700 you get 80 per cent of your medical costs rebated. You can do that in one operation at a hospital these days. But the Australian Labor Party wants to dump that. Bring on the election! Let us put that to the Australian people and see what they think of the Australian Labor Party when that happens—and also the weird claims from the member for Lilley about Centrelink operations and this bill.

The government have also indicated that we are going to exempt all scholarships that pay tuition fees on a student's behalf or waive from the social security and veterans' affairs income tests all or part of such a student's tuition fee. A couple of thousand students are going to benefit from that, and so they should. I am pleased to see that the Australian Labor Party have said that they are going to support that measure as well. Make no mistake about it: the opposition will support this government legislation. They will say a number of things about the government's mean-spiritedness and then support the legislation. There is a message in that for the Australian people. I am very pleased to see these measures going through parliament this morning, and I will be pleased to see the Australian Labor Party's support for them.

talk.start.para: —The member for Herbert is right. We on this side of the House will be supporting the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Budget Measures) Bill 2004. We believe it is long overdue and I will talk about that in my speech. The government's record is appalling when it comes to supporting Australian families and Australian people in need, who rely on the government to give them support. It has a philosophy that if you need assistance from the government you are a second-class citizen. This has been reflected in various pieces of legislation that have gone through this parliament, through various statements made by ministers and through various actions that this government has taken during the time that it has been in power.

speech.para: Under the Howard government, the divide between those who have and those who have not has grown. In Australia today there are those who are extremely wealthy, who can afford to have the best of everything, and then there are those who struggle just to put bread on the table. In a country like Australia that is appalling. When a situation like that develops, it means that the government has failed. The Howard government has failed many hundreds of thousands of people in Australia and I think that is sad. Real people's lives are being affected; real people do not have the opportunities that they deserve and should expect.

This government has actively campaigned to make the lives of struggling Australian families, pensioners and the unemployed harder, with some of the most draconian measures that you can imagine. When we are faced with an election, this government seeks to buy the votes of Australian people. It has been a hallmark of the Howard government administration that throughout its term in government it has taken. After an election, it takes everything it can. It makes the lives of Australian people so hard. When an election is looming, it starts throwing little bribes at the Australian people and hoping that they will forget that it has made their lives so intolerable.

This bill is once again a last-minute attempt to turn the tide. It should have happened a lot earlier; it is something that you would have to welcome. The bill gives effect to the 2004 budget measures for the Department of Family and Community Services, which were detailed by the Treasurer when he presented the budget to this House. The bill amends schedule 1 of the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to exempt fee waivers and fee-paying scholarships from the income tests for income support payments. Schedule 2 amends the Social Security Act 1991 to expand the eligibility criteria for carer allowance by allowing a new group of carers to qualify for carer allowance. This is something that will be welcomed by carers and something that has, once again, been long overdue. I will talk a little more about that in just a moment.

Currently, scholarships are required to be taken into account as income unless there is specific exemption from the income test for income support payments. The new measures introduced in the bill make the system a lot more workable and remove any penalty to those people who are receiving scholarships. It is my understanding that the exemption will benefit about 1,550 students at present, increasing to 2,200 students per year by 2008.

At present, to qualify for the carer allowance a carer is required to live with the person for whom they are providing care. I know that members on both sides of this House would have been approached by constituents who are providing full-time care for a relative or even a neighbour but who are not living in the same house. This has been a matter on which I have lobbied the government on many occasions. I know that my colleagues on this side of the House have also thought that this was something that needed to be changed.

As recently as last Friday I was visited by a constituent whose wife provides 12 hours of care a day to her elderly mother, who has not left her bedroom for two years. She has been confined to her bedroom for two years. She baths her; she feeds her; she also cares for her father. Yet she has been ineligible to receive the carer allowance. This measure will benefit her and it will benefit both her mother and father. In recent times her father has also become very frail and has developed dementia. He relies on his daughter for the support and care that will enable both him and his wife to live in their own home within the community.

Let us face it: that is what this is about. This is about ensuring that elderly people can remain in their homes rather than have to move into a residential facility. Without those carers who are prepared to visit, to cook, to care for people on a daily basis, elderly people would be forced to live in a residential facility. That would be a lot more expensive and it would be of greater cost to the Australian people than extending the carer allowance, as this legislation does. That is the reason that I believe this should have happened a long time ago.

Carers need a lot more than just the carer allowance. They need ongoing support. They need more community aged care packages. Currently there is a chronic shortage of community aged care packages. The government made an announcement recently of additional packages. These will not even touch the edges of what is needed in the area that I represent in this parliament. They are inadequate. If the government were serious about supporting carers it would ensure that there were enough of these packages and it would ensure that there were enough respite places.

Once again in the budget the government extended the period in which people could access respite. However, in my area you could extend respite to six months and people would still be unable to access it because the respite beds are not available. Whilst this is good legislation that demands support because it is going to benefit the Australian people, I feel that it does not go far enough. It does not really recognise the needs of those carers who rely on this government for support.

The member for Lilley mentioned the Centrelink review of the entitlement to carer allowance for parents of disabled children. Like most members of this House, I have been visited by constituents whose carer allowance has been stopped. A number of parents have been to see me who have children who suffer from intellectual disabilities and who are totally dependent on their parents. Their carer allowance was stopped. In some cases, after vigorous representation by my office we were able to turn that decision around, but the anxiety this caused families was enormous—anxiety and a process that they did not need to go through.

Recently I met a lady whose daughter is extremely disabled. Since the time she was born, this girl has gone through operation after operation. She requires daily assistance from her mother. She attends a normal high school, but without the medical and caring assistance she gets from her mother she would not be able to lead a normal life. The review form arrived and the boxes to tick did not correspond with this girl's disability. Therefore, the disability allowance was stopped. This lady is a single mother whose marriage broke up simply because of the stress placed on it by the disability this young girl has. This is a mother who is coping just to survive on a daily basis. She would probably fall into that group of 8,300 people mentioned by the member for Herbert who did not respond to the review. After receiving the letter, this lady was in such a total state of depression that she felt that she could not continue to fight to get this allowance. This lady spends more on aids for her daughter than she receives from the carer allowance.

There are some real issues affecting real people that this government is not facing up to. It is an absolute disgrace that, heading to an election, the government, finally, after eight years of inflicting pain on the Australian people, has decided to throw some pittances to carers, pittances such as $600, $1,000—one-off payments—which carers will willingly take because they know how hard their lives are. But the government really needs to provide ongoing, everyday—daily, weekly, monthly, yearly—support, not election-time bribes and election-time supports.

We have had the fiasco where families who incurred family tax benefit debts had $600 thrown at them in June by the government, with another $600 to be thrown at them after June. That will not fix the problem. The family tax benefit debts will continue to accumulate and families will continue to hurt. But we are heading to an election and they will not hurt until after the election. The government is throwing goodies at them now and will hurt them after the election. I do not think that that is the way a government should treat the people of Australia. I think the people of Australia deserve respect; they deserve a government that will provide them with ongoing support all of the time, not just at election time.

The member for Herbert mentioned the Medicare safety net. The Labor Party do not believe that there is a need for a Medicare safety net. We believe that Medicare should be strengthened, and we believe that all doctors should bulk-bill their patients. If doctors bulk-bill, you do not need a safety net. We are committed to Medicare and we are committed to all Australian people. The member for Herbert talked at some length about the disability pension. He went on to talk about people receiving the disability support pension and working as concreters. This only goes to denigrate all the people who receive disability support pensions. Before coming to this parliament, I used to work with people with disabilities—people who received the disability support pension—and there was nothing that they wanted more than to get back into the work force. You do not help people with disabilities return to the work force by denigrating them. You help people with disabilities return to the work force by putting in place the proper programs and supports they need to be able to find employment and maintain employment. I think the comments by the member for Herbert demonstrate the philosophy of this government. If somebody is down and out, if somebody is doing it hard, what do you do? You denigrate them. That is not good enough.

I go back to the question I asked at the beginning of my comments: why is the government introducing this legislation now? Why did it not introduce the legislation after the last election? The answer is simple. The government is introducing this legislation now to buy votes, just as it was trying to buy votes when it gave the $600 to people in receipt of family tax benefits and just as it was trying to buy votes with the $1,000 payments for people in receipt of the carer allowance and carer payments.

The Australian people want certainty and ongoing assistance, not election bribes that are given to them today and taken from them tomorrow. This is one of the most mean-spirited governments in Australia's history—a government that takes Australians for granted at all times other than when there is an election. The only time that this government really looks to the needs of average Australian people, people who are doing it hard, is when it wants them to vote for it. I have news for the government: Australians are beginning to understand how the Howard government works. They are beginning to understand that it is a government that gives to them before the election and takes from them after the election. I call on the government to make real changes for carers, to ensure that carers get the ongoing support that they need and not just stopgap, money-throwing bribes when there is going to be an election. Carers deserve better. All Australians deserve better. We want an Australian government that delivers to the Australian people all of the time, not just when an election is about to be called.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to offer my very strong support for the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Budget Measures) Bill 2004. The measures contained in this bill are for two very important sectors of our community—sectors that were overlooked by Labor as they simply could not afford to provide them with these options due to their poor economic management and the huge Labor Party debt. The Howard government is pleased to be able to offer these changes to carers and students eligible for scholarships. I encourage Labor to pass these changes and to at least allow these groups options that were never afforded to them under the Labor Party government. Whilst they could not offer these options when in government, Labor now have the opportunity to make amends by simply passing this bill and recognising that these groups deserve this assistance.

speech.para: There are two schedules in this bill. The first, relating to scholarships, will exempt all scholarships that pay tuition fees on a student's behalf or waive all or part of a student's tuition fees from the social security and veterans' affairs income tests. Schedule 2 relates to the carer allowance and will expand the eligibility criteria for carer allowance by allowing a carer to be qualified if they provide certain care and attention for an adult with a disability even if they do not live with that adult.

One of the issues under the scholarships schedule is that currently some scholarships that pay part or all of student tuition fees are not exempt from social security or veterans' affairs income tests. This unfairly excludes a significant number of people from applying for this assistance and means that many are otherwise unable to pursue this study due to lack of financial assistance. This measure would exempt all scholarships that pay part or all of student tuition fees from social security and veterans' affairs income tests. It would allow more people the option of attending secondary education, vocational education and training, as well as higher education. This bill extends exemptions announced in December 2003 in which the Commonwealth learning scholarships and full fee-waiver scholarships provided by higher education institutions were made exempt from social security and veterans' affairs income tests. Measures will apply to secondary education, vocational education and training, and higher education sector scholarships. They will only apply to scholarships where fees or charges associated with courses are waived or institutions pay the fees on behalf of students. In both of these circumstances, the student has no discretion over the use of these funds. They will not apply to cash scholarships, which will still be assessed as income. If the government exempted all scholarships, then it would be possible for students with discretionary cash scholarships to be considerably better off than students earning the same amount of income from working.

Up to 1,550 students are expected to benefit from this measure, building up to 2,200 per year by 2008. This measure will encourage students who could not afford study without this assistance to continue or re-enter education programs. Students who receive this assistance may still work to pay for other costs associated with study. This will not hinder them from doing that. It will, however, substantially assist the majority of the financial burden associated with studies in the form of tuition fees.

The issues I want to discuss today under the carer allowance schedule are as follows. Firstly, currently carers must live with the person for whom they are providing care in order to receive the carer allowance. This measure is intended to recognise that people have different living arrangements, so it is not always possible or appropriate for the carer to live with the disabled adult. Secondly, it seeks to recognise that these carers still make a valuable and significant contribution to our community. Under this schedule, required care and attention is to be provided by the carer on a daily basis for a total of at least 20 hours per week. `Care and attention' relates to the provision of personal care and can include activities such as assisting the disabled adult with showering, dressing, feeding and mobility. These new measures for non co-resident carers mirror as closely as possible the arrangements currently in place for co-resident carers of adults with a disability. They do not apply to carers of children with a disability because requirements that a child with a disability be a dependent child of the carer would in almost all cases require the carer and the child to live together in a private home.

Co-resident carers currently caring for either an adult or a child with a disability will not be affected by these amendments. It is expected that approximately 13,270 non co-resident carers will benefit from this measure. The measure recognises that these carers take an unnecessary burden off other health care services and that if people are willing to undertake this responsibility the government quite rightly should provide them with assistance, as they are essentially helping the government by reducing numbers in other health care facilities.

The Howard government recognises the vital role that carers play in our society and will continue to support them. The Australian government provided carers with direct payments, including bonuses, that totalled over $1.8 billion in 2003-04. It is incredible when you recognise that that is an increase of 135 per cent since 1999-2000. Carer payments were provided to approximately 84,000 customers, at a cost of nearly $830 million, over the financial year 2003-04. Carer allowance was provided to nearly 300,000 customers, at a cost of almost three-quarters of a billion dollars, in 2003-04.

As part of this debate it is important to concentrate more specifically on some of the carer initiatives in the budget. This budget is no different from some of the previous budgets under this government where we have supported carers very directly. In this budget the government will spend an additional $461 million on carers. The budget's carer package recognises the wide diversity of carers, their various care situations, the range of care needs and the long-term commitment of many carers. The government have been working hard to bring forward the changes to the carer allowance announced in the budget. These changes were originally to take effect from 1 April next year but will now commence, subject to the passage of this legislation, from 1 September 2004. This will ensure that carers can benefit from these changes at the earliest possible date. The changes will mean that from 1 September 2004 the carer allowance will be available to eligible carers who do not live with the person for whom they provide substantial levels of personal care on a daily basis. Over 13,000 carers will benefit from this measure, at an estimated cost of almost $107 million over four years.

What of the previous carer initiatives under the Howard government? The National Respite for Carers Program is a Howard government initiative. Funding for this program has increased more than fivefold since 1996-97 to an estimated $105 million in 2004-05. It is a very important point to make. It is an important distinction to make as part of this debate because, despite the ramblings of some of those members opposite about their care for people who are in many cases in very desperate circumstances, this government is the one that has proven—in stark contrast to the benefits that were provided under the previous Labor government—that it cares very sincerely for carers and for people suffering from disabilities and will continue to make its commitment to those people. The National Respite for Carers Program now funds over 90 Commonwealth carer respite centres and other outlets around the nation. There are over 100 respite services specifically targeted at carers of people with dementia, over 300 other respite services to help carers and a Commonwealth carer resource centre in every state and territory capital city to help carers obtain the information and support that they need.

The 2002-03 budget provided carers with an additional $80 million over four years. That was for respite care and other assistance, including assistance with dementia care. Since 1996 the Howard government have made significant beneficial legislative changes to carer payments and the carer allowance which include: extending carer payment eligibility to carers of profoundly disabled children under 16 years of age; extending carer payment eligibility to carers of two or more disabled children who together require a level of care that is at least equivalent to the level of care required by a single child with a profound disability; and increasing the permitted hours of work and educational training et cetera from 10 to 20 hours per week, without the loss of carer payment eligibility. We have extended carer allowance eligibility to carers who do not live with the person for whom they provide substantial levels of personal care on a daily basis. Importantly, we have introduced two new, simpler and more objective assessment tools—firstly, the adult disability assessment tool, to assess eligibility for carer payment and carer allowance in respect of adults and, secondly, the child disability assessment tool, to assess eligibility for carer allowance in relation to children.

The lists of recognised disabilities for children under 16 years of age were introduced in July 1998. They are important because they have helped to assess eligibility for carer allowance in relation to children. If a child has a disability cited on these lists, their parent or carer will receive carer allowance, without the need for further assessment, until the child is aged 16 years. The National Family Carers Voice was established in August 2003, for two years, to provide the government with advice on family carer issues. The National Family Carers Voice will provide more detailed information about the needs of carers and the types of assistance they require to make their caring role more effective and more sustainable.

Since coming to office this government have provided a significant boost to funding support for carers. In the 2004-05 budget we have further demonstrated our commitment to carers. We are, as is a matter of public record, only a matter of weeks or months away from the general election for 2004. It is important, as part of all debates on Commonwealth expenditure, to examine the record of this government and how it stands in complete contrast to the financial mishaps of the Labor Party—not just when they were in government but when the current Leader of the Opposition was the mayor of Liverpool. Both of the measures that we have discussed today are possible only because of the excellent financial management shown by this government over the last 8½ years. This government have continually delivered surpluses and at the same time have continued to reduce the substantial debt which Labor left the Australian taxpayer.

When we came to government in 1996, there was $96 billion in government debt—Labor Party debt of $96 billion. With the excellent financial management of this government, we have successfully reduced it to around $25 billion. The important take-out of all that is the fact that this government now save, on a per annum basis, approximately $6 billion a year in interest payments that Labor would otherwise be making and that we can now make to services such as education and health and to carers. It is important to note today—and the Australian people should realise the significance of these figures—that, as a debt per person, each Australian was left with a debt of about $5,200 under Labor when we came to government in 1996. Remarkably, over the last nine years, because of the sound financial management of the Howard government, we have been able to reduce that to around $1,200 per person. It is a significant effort, and it is one that the government should be commended on and that every Australian should recognise.

It is also important to note that the reduction in this debt has not been at the expense of services to the Australian public, because the Howard government have also delivered record unemployment levels, maintained at under six per cent. In my own electorate of Dickson unemployment is now at 3.2 per cent—an incredible low. National unemployment levels are at 23-year lows. We have delivered to the Australian people home loan interest rates which have been reduced to 30-year lows. Inflation is now at 2.6 per cent. It was double that under Labor at 5.2 per cent, which provided upward pressure on interest rates. We have helped increase all sorts of benefit and support to small business. Most significantly, we have cut overdraft rates from 20½ per cent and higher under Labor to under nine per cent under this government. Overall economic management has meant that economic growth in this country has averaged 3.6 per cent.

Measures provided under this bill are possible because of this government's successful financial management. These measures are assisting groups in our community that, because of their huge debt, Labor could never afford to help and never did help. I ask the opposition to show support for this very important legislation today, to provide support to those most in need of it and to support this government in its ongoing reform of the Australian economy, which has delivered so much to the Australian people. For those reasons, I commend this bill to the House.

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
Mr PYNE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I thank those members of the House who have taken part in the debate on the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Budget Measures) Bill 2004, with varying degrees of success: the member for Lilley, with his usual style; the member for Shortland; and the members for Herbert and Dickson on the government side, who were both erudite and lucid in their support for the government legislation, which does two things. This bill gives effect to two beneficial family and community services and veterans' affairs 2004 budget measures that require legislation. One is the scholarship measure; the second is the carer allowance.

speech.para: The scholarships measure exempts all fee-pay and fee-waiver scholarships from the social security and veterans' affairs income tests. This measure will assist students receiving those scholarships in the secondary, vocational education and training and higher education sectors. Approximately 1,550 students are already benefiting from this measure through ex gratia payments, and it is expected that this number will increase to 2,200 students per year by 2008.

The carer allowance measure allows a carer to be qualified for the carer allowance if they provide certain care for an adult with a disability, even if they do not live with that adult. This beneficial measure allows carers and the people they care for to choose the living arrangements that best suit their particular circumstances, without requiring them to live in the same home. This measure recognises the valuable and significant contribution that these carers make to the community and is expected to assist over 13,000 additional carers from September 2004.

On a personal note, I particularly recommend the second aspect of this bill, which is of course to allow carers to no longer reside with the person for whom they are caring. Many members, particularly those from Tasmania, may well remember the case of Shirley Jordan and Harry Belbin. Harry Belbin is a disabled person. Shirley Jordan is his sister, who continues to care for him and has since 1984. In 1984, the then Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, gave her an ex gratia pension. Under the review of carer allowances, that pension was taken away from her about three years ago. She applied for an ex gratia payment. That matter came to me as the parliamentary secretary responsible for family and community services, who deals with ex gratia payments. Looking at the case, I determined that she should have an ex gratia payment made to her because of what was almost a case of estoppel that had been created through the 18 or 20 years that she had been paid a pension, only to have it taken away from her. I think that case highlighted the anomaly that had existed in the law for a long time about carers who were doing all the things that carers do to look after a particular individual but who, because they did not reside with that particular individual, were not able to access the carer allowance.

I travelled to Burnie in Tasmania to see Shirley Jordan and Harry Belbin. I went with Senator Richard Colbeck, the very fine Liberal senator from Tasmania who represents the north-west of that great state. I met with Shirley Jordan and Harry Belbin in their homes some months before the government announced this measure in the budget. I was delighted to have been able to help Shirley Jordan and Harry Belbin. I believe that the case that Shirley Jordan pressed for some time was one of the main word pictures that demonstrated to people that a system in which a carer lived with the person they were caring for might in many cases be appropriate but was not the only system that was capable of being good for the person who was being cared for and the person who was doing the caring. I am particularly delighted with that measure. I commend the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Budget Measures) Bill 2004 to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

subdebate.1.para: Mr PYNE (Sturt—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services) (12.00 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 June, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Attorney-General for coming into the House. I will be brief in terms of my comments on this bill, which reproduces what were formerly schedules 1, 2 and 5 of the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004, which was brought into the House shortly before the last recess. The House will recall that schedule 1 dealt with foreign travel documents, schedule 2 dealt with the surrender of passports and the restriction of movement of persons in the context of ASIO issuing a questioning warrant under ASIO's powers to investigate potential terrorist situations, and schedule 5 dealt with forensic identification of victims of mass casualty incidents. I have already spoken in some detail on the provisions of these measures as contained in the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004 when I made my contribution to the second reading debate on the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004. As I said, my remarks will be relatively brief with respect to these measures, which not essentially although in actuality replicate what was in the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004.

speech.para: Since the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004was introduced into the House, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has had an opportunity to receive submissions and hear evidence on these provisions which are now included in the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004 as well. I understand that the committee is due to report tomorrow. It is worth noting that the committee received around 93 submissions, which is indicative of the high level of community interest in applying scrutiny to legislation of this kind. I commented on this previously.

It is worth noting that, while schedules 1 and 2 attracted significant comment and scrutiny in a large number of submissions, only three submissions were received in respect of schedule 5, which deals with the forensic information in the event of a catastrophe occurring in Australia. Those three submissions were brief emails and their comments were essentially bland statements such as, `Concerns about schedule 5 intruding into the privacy of citizens.'

With respect to those who made such submissions, it is appropriate that they read the background to schedule 5 and in particular its recommendation that these measures were necessary to deal with an event which none of us wants to occur on Australian shores but which was identified in the Sherman report as a matter of urgency. Indeed, concerns about intrusion into the privacy of citizens have been firmly rebutted by the former Federal Privacy Commissioner, who is active in his protection of the interests of the privacy of Australian citizens. He, in fact, joined in the urgent recommendation of the Sherman committee for the amendments in schedule 5 to be made as soon as possible.

Again, without overly gloating, the way these submissions and concerns have been relayed to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee does suggest that Labor was correct in suggesting that schedule 5 be hived off into a separate bill so that it could have been passed expeditiously in the last parliament—certainly prior to the intrusion of any election. As it has turned out, that should be achieved should this legislation proceed speedily, as we are prepared to cooperate during the course of these two weeks.

I should comment, in fairness to him, on the commentator in the Daily Telegraph who wrote an article in the Sunday Telegraph—that famous or infamous political commentator, Piers Akerman. He got stuck into me as well as others about supporting the reference of these sorts of matters to the committee process. But when you are talking about concerns and the whole matrix of the need for tighter security measures and the impact that they have on civil liberties, it is just better all round if people have the opportunity to voice their concerns and those concerns are addressed by a parliamentary committee—or at least noted by a parliamentary committee—recommending, if appropriate, measures to address those concerns. If they find those concerns are without substance they note that fact but, when it comes to the balance between the need for tighter security in the community and concerns of civil liberties, you cannot go past the whole concept of participatory democracy that our committee system facilitates. Insofar as I respond to Piers Akerman and probably regret giving his name notoriety in regard to some matters raised by him, I thought I should put a countervailing argument to the one which he advanced last Sunday.

In fact, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has been a first-rate committee of the parliament. I congratulate all members of that committee from both sides of the House. They genuinely approach complex and at times emotive issues in a very balanced and constructive way. I believe they genuinely seek to achieve an outcome that is in the national interest rather than to pursue any party political agenda. I believe it has provided tremendous service to the Australian people in how it has incorporated the appropriate balance that is often needed when we are addressing bills of this nature.

Finally, I should note that when the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004, which I have referred to, was introduced into the House the Minister for Foreign Affairs introduced the Australian Passports Bill 2004 and the Australian Passports (Transitionals and Consequentials) Bill 2004 at about the same time. Those bills clearly interact with the passport provisions in the current bill, particularly in schedule 1, but they raise somewhat different issues. In fact, the passports bill introduced by the foreign minister has been supported by both sides of parliament during the course of debate this morning. As a result of a mechanism in the consequential provisions, and with its passage and the passage of the Australian Passports Bill, I understand that schedule 1 will be automatically hived off into a separate piece of legislation. That mechanism seems to be effective and innovative and it is a measure that the opposition can support.

In summary, we are supporting the passage of the measures contained in the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3). We expect, at least with respect to some aspects of schedules 1 or 2, that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee may make recommendations when it hands down its report tomorrow. Given the praise that I have bestowed on that committee, we will certainly look closely at any recommendations that it may make on areas in which the bill could potentially be improved or enhanced. We will have the opportunity to address those matters in the Senate, but I can again indicate to the Attorney-General and the parliament that the opposition will cooperate with the expeditious passage of these measures.

talk.start.para: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to strongly support the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004 before the House. At the outset I acknowledge the very gracious comments of the member for Barton about the wise counsel offered to him by Piers Akerman and heeded by him. It is always good to see a little bit of recognition of the right way of thinking in this country and it certainly could not go astray in deliberations by the Australian Labor Party on some of the important measures before the House at the moment. Piers Akerman has plenty to say about the Labor Party in relation to these matters. It is no wonder that the member for Barton is sensitive about some of the writings of Mr Akerman, because I think Piers Akerman in many ways provides an objective outlook and review of the Australian Labor Party's ideological opposition to some of these very wise provisions put forward by the government. It is only right that the member for Barton has acknowledged the areas from which he has drawn inspiration in arriving at his decision to support this bill today.

speech.para: I am very proud to be a member of this strong Howard government. The Howard government remain willing and ready to stand up to terrorists. We are a government that will not be blackmailed or coerced into backing down in our ongoing fight against terrorism. As a government we must remain committed in our fight towards making Australia a safer place for all Australians for generations to come. Following the horrific events of September 11 and, closer to home, the Bali tragedy, our security has been under threat like never before from terrorist organisations for no reason other than the fact that we enjoy a Western way of life—a way of life that enables us to express our religious beliefs without persecution, a way of life that encourages all citizens to work in their chosen profession, regardless of race, sex or age, and a way of life that this government must protect for future generations. It is a way of life that this government strongly believe all Australians are entitled to and a way of life that we must seek to guard from terrorists at any cost. The recent heightened terror alert for key financial institutions in the United States is a stark reminder that the threat of terrorism is constant and very real in our society, and makes it even more important to Australia's national security that this bill is passed. This government will do whatever is necessary to prevent terrorism from reaching our shores, and I ask that the opposition join us today in this endeavour by voting for this bill.

The purpose of this bill is to revise Australia's counterterrorism framework through amending three Commonwealth statutes: firstly, the Passports Act 1938, which will give authorities certain powers to demand, confiscate and seize foreign passports; secondly, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979, which will give ASIO powers to demand the surrender of Australian and foreign passports in certain circumstances; and, thirdly, the Crimes Act 1914, which will be amended to facilitate effective disaster victim identification and criminal investigation in the event of a mass casualty incident within this country.

Since 2001 this government has pledged more than $3.1 billion for national security. In this year's budget alone the government provided an additional $775 million over five years to further counter the threat of terrorism in Australia. Inclusive in this is $270 million to increase our ability to gather intelligence and identify possible threats to our country; $207 million to upgrade protective security, including air security officers at airports; $150 million to help secure Australia's borders; and $87 million to develop our Australian Federal Police presence outside Australia, in surrounding regions. As a government we are committed to making Australia safer for all and we will spend the necessary amount of money to do this effectively.

I want first to turn to the issues under the Passports Act 1938 and the reason for the government moving to make amendments. The misuse of foreign travel documents is often associated with terrorist and criminal activity. At present, many people hold both Australian and foreign passports. As the law currently stands, authorities are only entitled to confiscate Australian passports. It is therefore essential that law enforcement and security authorities have the power to seize all documents that would facilitate a person's departure from Australia's jurisdiction. It would be ridiculous for someone to get out of the country where authorities have confiscated the Australian passport but not the foreign passport. That is a loophole that this bill seeks to amend.

These new provisions will also assist with international law enforcement and security cooperation. These amendments relating to foreign travel documents do not have extraterritorial jurisdiction—that is, competent authorities and the minister will have power to act only in circumstances where the person is in Australia. In addition, in circumstances where a person's foreign travel documents are seized, there is nothing to prevent the country that issued those documents from requesting their return.

The second issue I want to discuss relates to the amendments sought to the ASIO Act 1979. It is important that persons who have vital information in relation to terrorist activity are not able to leave this country before being questioned by the appropriate security authorities. Amendments under this bill will give ASIO the power to demand that a person surrender their Australian and foreign passports if the person is subject to a request for consent to apply for a questioning warrant. This will prevent a person who may have vital information about a planned terrorist attack from fleeing this country before being questioned. However, this power to demand the surrender of a person's passports and for them to be questioned will only be available where it is reasonably believed that the person might have vital information in relation to terrorist activity. It would only be exercised if the person attempts to leave Australia or there is a concern that the person may attempt to leave the country.

This bill will also create new offences under the ASIO Act for failure to comply with a demand for the surrender of a person's passport and for leaving Australia when a person is subject to a request for consent to apply for a questioning warrant. Such measures would enable ASIO to better protect Australian citizens from terrorism but would still protect the rights of the individual.

The third area that we seek amendment to is the Crimes Act 1914.
