The amendments to the Crimes Act are being made to address concerns that existing forensic legislation may be inadequate to facilitate effective disaster victim identification if, tragically, a mass casualty incident were to occur within Australia. Our experience from the Bali disaster shows that in mass casualty incidents the forensic services of the Commonwealth, states and territories will need to work together to ensure that disaster victim identification occurs as quickly as possible. This bill would extend the operation of laws that were passed to deal with the Bali disaster so that they can be applied to a wide variety of potential incidents that may occur within Australia. Should such a tragedy ever occur on Australian soil it is imperative that measures are in place for Commonwealth, state and territory authorities to be able to work together effectively. This will make the process more efficient and less traumatic for victims' families.

I want to turn now to some comments that were made by the Labor Party's member for Barton yesterday about the Attorney-General's announcement of some very important funding. It was humorous to see some of the comments made by the member for Barton in his press release regarding the government's alleged `phoney announcement', as he calls it, of over $6 million as our commitment to the national security hotline. The member for Barton knows—he is not a stupid person; he must know and surely he would know, if he had taken the time to read the budget appropriation statements for the past two years—that this is new money.

The Labor Party should be the one to speak with conviction about dressing up old policies as new initiatives, because we on this side of the House know the famous policy of the Labor Party in relation to the coastguard! It is not something that the Labor Party like to talk about, despite the fact that they have reannounced the policy on no fewer than four separate occasions now. They do not like to go into the detail of it, because they know that as a policy it is an insult to the Australian people, it is an insult to the Australian Navy, it is an insult to the Australian Customs Service and it is an insult to anybody who has any legitimate concern as part of this debate.

When their coastguard policy was first announced in 2001, Labor estimated that it would cost $895 million. After the election, the ever incredibly successful Simon Crean announced the revised, cheaper version at $612 million over four years—a snappy reduction of $280-odd million. Mark Latham—the champion of flip-flop policy, one of the most incapable leaders the Labor Party have ever put forward and a person incapable of making a decisive decision in this country's national interest, as we see now on a daily basis—has again changed this policy. Since then, the homeland security spokesman has announced that it has had a further revised estimate, to now cost just $450 million. It must be put on the public record today that the Labor Party have no idea about the issues of homeland security, national security and border protection when they put forward this joke of a policy.

We see at the moment that the Leader of the Opposition is incapable of making a decision in the national economic interest of this country in the procrastination he shows on a daily basis concerning the free trade agreement. It is a demonstration of how dangerous Mark Latham would be as Prime Minister of this country, and it does not stop there. If you look at the track record of the member for Werriwa, now the Leader of the Opposition and the possible alternative to the Prime Minister for the leadership of this country, it does not stop there. It does not stop at Latham's threat to economic security; it certainly extends to Labor's threat to national security.

Labor have shown in recent years how weak they have been in relation to border protection. They have shown, through both their public comment and certainly their private deliberations with the left who have a stranglehold on the Labor Party, the fact that they have not been able to commit to good strong policies that this government has committed to, legislated for and fought hard to protect, not just in this place but also in the other place, to ensure that the long-term interests of the Australian people are protected. This debate today demonstrates that all of the threat that exists at the moment—all of the serious threat that faces our country and Western civilisation—can never be contemplated by the Labor Party because they are incapable of dealing with the issues and putting forward the measures that would protect the interests of this country.

Over the last seven years this government has sought to provide Australia, as I said, with national security, economic strength and social stability. When the Howard government came to power, Australia's national security had been left in a neglected state by the Labor Party, with a run-down Defence Force. Since 1996 a plan has been in place to rebuild our Defence Force, initially protecting defence from budget cuts in 1996 and since then providing the biggest sustained increase in defence funding in 20 years. Inclusive in this was the government's swift actions to decisively strengthen Australia's counterterrorism capabilities after terror attacks in the US and Bali. Since September 11 new resources and capabilities have been provided across government. An additional $3.2 billion has been committed to national security and border protection. As I said before, importantly, it includes $870 million for our intelligence agencies. The Howard government's record of achievement in security measures is second to none. It has doubled ASIO's budget since September 11, with more than $131 million over four years. More than $50 million over four years has been provided for the protection of critical infrastructure, and more than $29 million of that is for security. More than $50 million over five years was announced prior to the last budget to establish the national threat assessment, bringing together agencies in assessing terror threat intelligence.

The Howard government have secured our borders against terrorist suspects as best we can. We must recognise that that is a vital weapon in our fight against terrorism and has both domestic and international implications. The government are not interested in letting terrorists enter Australia and we are also not interested in exporting terrorists who are then free to pursue their deadly ambitions in other countries. This bill provides practical measures that will further enhance the capacity of our intelligence and security agencies to investigate and hopefully prevent any tragic terrorist activity in this country. These measures are also non-controversial amendments that should be passed as a matter of priority. This bill is the first security bill not to be referred to a Senate committee and I would encourage the opposition not to delay it. It is time for the opposition to recognise that Australia's security is a priority over party politics. It is a priority over the loony left of the Labor Party dictating on these matters. I urge the Leader of the Opposition to use this as an opportunity to show that he may have some indication of strength of leadership. I urge him on that basis to pass this bill. On that basis I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for Barton has outlined with great clarity the opposition's position on the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004. Since the events of 11 September 2001 and the Bali bombings of October 2002, Labor have consistently supported security related legislation on a bipartisan basis because we believe that these issues should not be a matter of party politics. I hope the previous speaker, the member for Dickson, notes what is actually done rather than his own rhetoric.

speech.para: That is why I found it a bit disappointing to see the Attorney-General adopting what I considered a bit of a high-handed tone when referring to the opposition's position on this bill. In his second reading speech the Attorney-General said of the honourable member for Barton:

quote.para: ... I caution him that the importance or urgency of national security matters is not dependent on the Labor Party's assessment of what is important or urgent.
I take my advice on what is in the national interest from our intelligence and law enforcement agencies.

speech.para: Labor have not disputed that these bills are based on the advice which the minister gets from the security services. We support them for that reason, despite what is widely perceived across the Western world as the informed misperception of the security agencies—as Ken Pollack has called it—about the war in Iraq as evidenced by the Flood inquiry, the Butler inquiry and the US Senate inquiry. We support, as I have said, the contents of this bill for the reason that it is suggested by the experts in the security services, not because the minister tells us to.

We are the opposition. We are in a different position and have different political views from him and the government. We will work in the national interests of Australia, but we simply cannot be asked to take on trust what the Attorney-General says. We prefer the advice of security professionals. Advice from the government that brought us the children overboard scandal et cetera might be considered political advice and no-one in their right mind would expect any opposition to accept it. It is the right and responsibility of the opposition to make its own judgments on all legislation before this parliament, and that is what we continue to do. Since the minister spent 13 years in opposition, I am sure he understands that quite well. We have taken some criticism from some people on the left over our stance on this terrorism bill and from the loony right. In my electorate there have been quite laughable attacks on me from the loony LaRouchites because of Labor's support for this bill. We have not budged.

A Labor government will continue to take a stand against terrorism and those who cooperate with terrorists, as I am sure the Australian public noticed when the Leader of the Opposition gave his response about how Australia under a Latham government would react if it found itself in a similar situation to that of the Philippines, with hostages taken in Iraq. I think that was the appropriate way to respond, without denigrating what other countries—which are allies and regional neighbours of Australia—do. I am sure that in the future the government, if it remains in government, will have the support of opposition parties, and I hope that we would have their support in dealing with these matters.

Labor will also of course maintain its longstanding concern for the civil liberties of all Australians. With these bills and with antiterrorist legislation so far—and there is a great deal of work that has been put into this, particularly by Senator Faulkner and people in the Senate—we do not believe that civil liberties and security are incompatible. However, in the wake of the Bali bombing, Australians understand the nature of the threat that we face from terrorism and accept that bills such as the one we have before us—provided they are based on professional advice and are given careful parliamentary scrutiny—are in their interests.

Today I want to discuss some of the events and individuals that lie behind this legislation and that, unfortunately, make these bills necessary. In October 2002, the Indonesia-based terrorist organisation Jemaah Islamiah, the local franchise of al-Qaeda, carried out the Bali bombings, killing 88 Australians amongst the 202 victims. Two of those killed lived in my electorate. We now know that the mastermind and instigator of this atrocity was Abu Bakar Bashir, the Indonesian Islamic cleric. Bashir received a short prison sentence for plotting to overthrow the Indonesian government but has never been charged in relation to the Bali bombing.

I have previously praised General Pastika, the Indonesian police and courts—as I think all sensible Australians have—for the speed with which they captured those actually responsible for that murderous attack on our countrymen and women. It is unfortunate that the Indonesian authorities under President Megawati have shown little enthusiasm for prosecuting the man who actually ordered the bombing. The evidence we have of that is very interesting testimony in the trial of Jack Roche, which I urge all people who are seriously interested in this issue to have a look at.

It is pleasing to see that Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, who resigned from the cabinets of both Wahid and Megawati because he believed that their response to the terrorist threat to Indonesian democracy was not strong enough, is now the frontrunner for the Indonesian presidential election. It is up to the Indonesian people, obviously, who they elect, but—to quote in another context the famous words of Margaret Thatcher about Mikhail Gorbachev—Mr Yudhoyono is a man who Australia can do business with. His prospects give us some hope that some time in the near future we may see Abu Bakar Bashir brought to justice. That would greatly benefit the long-suffering people of Indonesia, who do not want to see these horrors take place in their country, which is economically reviving at the moment. The Bashir gang are the worst thing possible for the future of Indonesia.

It is not just a matter for Indonesia, however. In the Perth criminal court in May, Australians were given absolutely undeniable evidence that terrorist attacks in Australia had been planned and that Abu Bakar Bashir is the man who had been planning them. This evidence has come from an unimpeachable source, namely one of Bashir's Australian operatives, Mr Jack Roche, known to his friends as Jihad Jack. Halfway through his trial on charges that he conspired with others to blow up the Israeli embassy here in Canberra, Roche changed his plea to guilty. He also acknowledged that he planned to assassinate a leading Australian businessman who lives in my electorate, Joseph Gutnick. I was at the wedding of the daughter of Mr and Mrs Gutnick on Monday night, and there was still a great deal of alarm about the kinds of attacks that these kinds of people were proposing to make in Australia and at the fact that they could attract a light sentence. Roche was sentenced to nine years imprisonment, with a non-parole period of 4½ years. I thought this was an inadequate sentence for a man who voluntarily entered into a conspiracy to destroy an embassy in the heart of Canberra with a truck bomb. Therefore, I wrote in measured terms to the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Damian Bugg QC, asking him to consider an appeal against this sentence. I am pleased that he has now done so and is appealing Roche's light sentence.

Unfortunately, Roche is not the only Australian who has been foolish enough to travel to Pakistan or Afghanistan to be trained in how to carry out terrorist attacks. We also have the cases of David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib, two Australians who are currently paying for their folly at Guantanamo Bay. I do not believe that most Australians sympathise with the current attempts to glamorise Hicks or to portray him as a martyr or a political prisoner, as some of his lawyers and media boosters have sought to do. The documentary The President versus David Hicks that screened on SBS television recently sought to glamorise Hicks. I am sure that the relatives or friends of the 88 Australians killed in Bali do not share the sentiments of that film.

It is important for this House to understand that Hicks, in my view, was no naive innocent who was duped into travelling to Afghanistan. He said in letters to his father, quoted in the film, that his reason for training with al-Qaeda was so that `the Western-Jewish domination is finished, so we can live under Muslim law again'. It would appear from his own words that he has a very hardline position and is opposed to the kind of pluralist democracy we have in Australia.

Let me make it clear that I believe that, as Australian citizens, Hicks and Habib are entitled to justice—not the kind of fundamentalist justice that al-Qaeda would inflict on Australia if it had the chance—but they are not entitled also to be lionised as heroes and martyrs. They are entitled to be treated in a humane way at Guantanamo Bay. We want their trials to be brought forward as quickly as possible. We must ensure that the Australian government sees that they are treated in a humane way. However, in my view, no Australian who values the pluralist, tolerant democracy that we have built in this country, which al-Qaeda would like to destroy, should have any sympathy for them.

We have a number of other recent cases of people who have been accused of being foolishly involved with terrorist activities. One is Bilal Khazal of Sydney, who is wanted in Lebanon for allegedly financing a terrorist attack in a north Lebanese town and blowing up a McDonald's outlet in that town. It has also been suggested by credible sources that he is a high-level al-Qaeda sympathiser and in contact with their operatives overseas. Recently, Faheem Khalid Lodhi has been charged in Sydney with planning a terrorist attack on what has been named only as `a major infrastructure facility'. He is apparently linked to the man who left Australia, Willie Brigitte, who is from Lashkar-e-Taiba, another organisation that the opposition has joined with the government in proscribing as a terrorist organisation. In passing, I am sure I do not need to remind the Attorney-General—who should understand that the opposition has been supportive of his government over security matters—that it was his government that allowed Brigitte to leave Australia, when in my view he should be on trial in this country for planning terrorist attacks here. In Perth we also had the brothers Abdul Rahman Ayub and Abdur Ahaman Ayub, who operated a terrorist support organisation called Darul Islam and who apparently invited Abu Bakar Bashir to Australia. The Ayub brothers, originally from Lakemba in Sydney, have fled Australia.

It is obvious that all these people are `Islamists'. I use that word very carefully. These are people who misuse a great monotheistic religion for political purposes. This is no criticism of the great religion of Islam. With the exceptions of Roche and Hicks, they are immigrants to Australia from Islamic countries. We are frequently told that we must not scapegoat the Arab and Islamic communities in Australia by associating them with terrorism in an indiscriminate way. This is of course true, and in my view neither I nor anyone else on this side of the House has been guilty of doing so and, to the best of my knowledge, I have not observed people on the government side doing so to date. We should all be very careful to distinguish between Islamists—people who misuse Islam for political purposes and for their fanatical ends—and the vast majority of Muslims, including Australian Muslims. The great majority of Australians who have migrated here from Islamic countries are peaceful and law-abiding people who have no desire but to live in peace, practise their religion and enjoy the same rights and freedoms as other Australians.

I have to say, however, that certain statements have tended to foster suspicions in the minds of non-Muslim Australians, giving ammunition to ignorant people who wish to scapegoat Australian Muslims. Those statements are the ones made by one particular self-appointed leader of the Australian Islamic community, and he is Sheikh Taj el-Din Al Hilaly, the Imam of the Lakemba Mosque in Sydney. He has a long record of statements which appear to be bigoted and condone terrorism. In February this year, Sheikh Hilaly gave a sermon at a mosque in Sidon, Lebanon, in which, according to a translation supplied by the Australian Embassy in Beirut—the Australian Embassy, not some other organisation—he said:

quote.para: Sons of Islam, there is a war of infidels taking place everywhere. The true man is the boy who opposes Israeli tanks with strength and faith. The boy who, despite his mother's objections, goes out to war to become a martyr like his elder brother. The boy who tells his mother: `Oh mother, don't cry for me if I die. Oh mother, Jihad has been imposed on me and I want to become a martyr.'

speech.para: In that statement Sheikh Hilaly is praising organisations like al-Qaeda, Hamas and Hezbollah, which promote and carry out suicide bombings in Iraq, Israel and recently Turkey. They send out teenagers and children of other people, not their own children, to blow themselves up with explosives, and in doing so they kill large numbers of innocent civilians.

If young Australian Muslims like the deluded young man Zak Mallah hear their religious leaders speaking in these terms, is it surprising that a few of them may be sufficiently influenced to want to go down the same path as suicide bombers in other parts of the world? We do not want this kind of incitement here in Australia. Sheikh Hilaly said:

quote.para: Don't be surprised if one day you hear the Muezzin calling for prayer ... from the top of the White House. September 11 is God's work against oppressors. Some of the things that happen in the world cannot be explained; a civilian airplane whose secrets cannot be explained if we ask its pilot who reached his objective without error, who led your steps? Or if we ask the giant that fell, who humiliated you? Or if we ask the President, who made you cry? God is the answer.

speech.para: So here we have a man who should be much more responsible. He puts himself forward as a spiritual leader in Australia's largest city, at the head of a fast growing community of Australians—a community which runs schools in which young Australians are educated—and he thinks that the terrorist massacre of September 11 was God's work against oppressors. I think it was a political act by a deluded group of fanatics, and I do not think that any spiritual leader of any denomination should apologise for or incite on behalf of these people. I would like Sheikh Hilaly to explain these inflammatory remarks to the families of the Bangladeshi Muslim kitchen workers who were killed in the World Trade Centre on September 11.

I contrast Sheikh Hilaly's words with the conciliatory words of many Muslim leaders in Australia, including Yasser Soliman of the Islamic Council of Victoria, Sheikh Fehmi of the Preston mosque and other people in the Muslim community in Australia who take a much more responsible stand. They do not want to be stereotyped or scapegoated as sympathisers with terrorism, but they have a dilemma and, with great respect, I point out to them that, if the words and actions of Sheikh Hilaly continue, they tend to embarrass their entire community. I have noticed that when Sheikh Hilaly has been interviewed by Four Corners or other programs he speaks much more moderately, but you cannot say one thing overseas and another thing in Australia about these matters. They are too serious, and we hold you to account in this country for words that you say overseas.

This has been a rather long digression from the contents of this bill, but since the opposition are not opposing this legislation I thought it important that the House be given some background which puts the measures of this bill into their proper context. The honourable member for Barton has set out our attitude to the details of this bill. As I said earlier, we on this side of the House will continue to support sensible and well-judged measures which enhance Australia's security. As an opposition we will continue to give those measures proper scrutiny. I suggest to the Attorney-General that he will have no let-up in that area. In government, we will continue to uphold Australia's national interests and ensure that this country is secure against terrorism, as I am sure that the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition during the recent hostage taking in Iraq have clearly illuminated. I suggest that the Australian public pay very clear attention to those remarks.

talk.start.para: —The Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004 has three main objectives. They are quite simple, and they add to a whole raft of initiatives taken by this government to amend our security laws and to make a legal framework which is adequate for Australia's needs in this day and age. This series of amendments seems to be one of the salami slices the Attorney-General needs to take in order to get some of the anti-terrorism and protective measures through the parliament. We are dependent on the support of the Australian Labor Party in the Senate to make changes which are critical to Australia's security. It amazes me that the Australian Labor Party appear to be putting themselves in a position to be held culpable if our systems fail and if we cannot achieve the outcomes that are necessary to protect Australian lives. They seem to think that that sort of activity within the Senate is responsible and will produce good results for them politically and on the ground in Australia. I cannot agree with this approach, because I think that that sort of playing with national security is something that should not be done. National security should be approached with a sense of deep responsibility and concern for the wellbeing of Australian citizens. There does not seem to be any evidence of that at the moment.

speech.para: The first objective of this bill is to amend the Passports Act so that, where people carry two passports and their Australian passport is confiscated or withdrawn, they cannot use a second passport to exit Australia. It brings into effect a provision that the international force of their overseas passport can, through Commonwealth law, be held to not be a sufficient reason for someone to travel if it is a condition of their parole that they remain in Australia or if, because they are suspected of being likely to engage in harmful conduct, such as terrorist activity, they should be prevented from leaving Australia on a foreign passport. The second objective of this legislation is to ensure that those subject to a request by the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to the minister for consent to apply for a questioning warrant be prevented from leaving Australia. I am pleased that the Australian Labor Party are supporting this provision. It is one that they had doubts about over a long period of time. If the Director-General of ASIO says to the minister that a certain individual should be questioned and should be prevented from leaving Australia, this bill enables that process to be undertaken.

The third objective is to amend the forensic procedure provisions of the Crimes Act to facilitate effective disaster victim identification in the event of a disaster causing mass casualties—if a terrorist attack or an aircraft disaster were to occur within Australia, for instance. The DNA profiles of individuals who are casualties of a disaster of that type can be used for the purposes of identification. That is perfectly reasonable and it is all within the framework of the need to ensure Australia's security and safety.

I notice that the Australian Labor Party as supporters of the bill have adopted a broad approach to the legislation, and I intend to do the same. I need to say a few things about the Australian Labor Party's position as it compares with where the government is going on these measures. I want to set out pretty clearly for the House some of the initiatives adopted by the government and some of the responses from the Australian Labor Party to what are sensible measures. These started with the Australian Olympics and were then pursued more intensively following September 11 and the Bali bombings. In that situation, we have reacted as a government to the needs of the day, but the Australian Labor Party's reactions to the government's initiatives have on many occasions appeared to be confused.

Some of the government's initiatives are wide-reaching and move into an area of legislation that we have not dealt with before in Australia. To list some of the changes to legislation, one has to go through a raft of provisions. Among the legislative initiatives adopted by the government there have been changes to: the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation legislation; the border security legislation of 2002; the Crimes Amendment Act, allowing forensics to be used to identify victims—the issue that we are dealing with today; the anti-hoax and other measures under the Crimes Act; espionage and related matters under the Criminal Code; offences against Australians under the Criminal Code; the suppression of terrorist bombings, making it an offence under the Criminal Code to place bombs or other lethal devices in proscribed places with the intention of causing death or serious harm; the terrorism and criminal act; the constitutional reference of powers; and the creation of a package of counter-terrorism legislation, which was passed by the Commonwealth on 27 June 2000, which received royal assent on 5 July 2000 and which states and territories have also mirrored in legislation they have enacted.

That removes the constitutional limitations so that Australian authorities can work together on counter-terrorism activities to protect Australian lives. Further, there is the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002, which removes the requirement for ASIO or for the Attorney-General to be satisfied by a decision in the United Nations Security Council relating to terrorism before making an organisation proscribable. Other government initiatives include: the 2003 Hezbollah amendment to the Criminal Code, the Hamas bill of 2003, the 2002 suppression of financing of terrorism and the Telecommunications Interception Legislation Amendment Act 2002. There we have a whole range of legislative initiatives—I have mentioned only some of them—that have been enacted by successive Attorney-Generals, particularly the current one, to draw together the legal framework for us to take security protection against those that would seek to harm Australians.

Terrorism as it is being expressed around the world is not a matter of making a military statement; it is a statement against the Australian way of life, against Western values. It is as simple as that. Terrorists want to disrupt and cause fear in order to drag down the current Western way of life. In the past three federal budgets the Howard government has allocated more than $3 billion over five years to enhance Australia's security. That applies to our capabilities and our arrangements with other governments and it is a unique and coordinated national approach.

I would like to list some of our achievements over this period. We have seen increased intelligence sharing and cooperation between government agencies—something that the Americans have struggled with; it is coming to light that there is now a coordinated approach being adopted in that country. We have seen a comprehensive new series of laws and technologies aimed at keeping ahead of organised crime syndicates in the new digital age to make sure that we have appropriate tracking and identification devices available to our law enforcement agencies. There has been a strengthening of our defence forces. It is essential that they are involved. We have seen the establishment of a new special operations command, a tactical assault group and a 300-strong instant response regiment with specialist skills.

Based overseas, we have new joint federal, state and territory police counter-terrorism investigation teams, which are at the cutting edge of taking charge of an incident should it occur or having in place preventative measures if such an incident were identified. We have extensive new resources to help the AFP fight terrorism, including additional investigators based overseas. That ensures essential intelligence and information-gathering processes in our near neighbourhood, where drug lords have moved without too much trouble. We need information on terrorist activities. It is essential that we work with our neighbours—our friends who are living in the region—and their governments to make sure that we all take charge of this situation.

There is tighter security in airports, along with armed plain-clothes air security officers on selected flights. We have state-of-the-art surveillance systems on Coastwatch planes, and more air and sea patrols to protect our borders. We have seen an upgrade in emergency services, with new equipment and specialist training. We have a more effective capacity to deal with chemical, biological and radiological threats. The implementation of the national counter-terrorism plan ensures that detailed strategic arrangements are in place for governments and security agents to prevent and respond to terrorism.

We have, step after step, logical, coordinated services in Australia, both state and federal. They are drawn together and matched with our security and intelligence-gathering processes and our defence systems and are related internationally to our friends and allies. We have seen the opening of the National Threat Assessment Centre—marking its transition to a 24-hours-a-day, seven-days-a-week operation—a full month ahead of when it was scheduled to commence operation.

We are working with the Pacific islands. I saw dismissive remarks from the Leader of the Opposition about Australia's role with the Pacific forum and our relationship with its members. I think that is a critical part of our approach and it is foundational. We do not want to be imposing our systems on them, but we need to be able to understand where the risks lie and which systems are likely to expose us to threat should they be used. We have seen the establishment of unprecedented cooperative working arrangements between the AFP and its counterparts in our region, particularly in Indonesia. Despite what the previous speaker said, I think it is critical that we have that relationship and cooperation with Indonesia.

We have entered into nine memorandums of understanding in counter-terrorism cooperation with key partners in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Fiji, Cambodia, East Timor, India and Papua New Guinea. All are in place, all are bilateral and give us an understanding of how we work together. The framework of working together is underscored with hard words of cooperation, of binding trust and of working together. A trusted information sharing network of critical infrastructure protection was established in April 2003 to link Australian state and territory governments and business in the sharing of information on security threats and vulnerabilities. The business-to-government ministerial forum on national security was held in Canberra in June this year. All of these measures are drawn together in a cohesive way.

In light of that activity it is really strange to find that the package of counter-terrorism legislation that was passed by the Commonwealth on 27 June 2002 was played with by the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party wanted the United Nations, in the first place, to be the key instrumentality in deciding whether we listed terrorist bodies in Australia. How ridiculous was that and how ridiculous has it been proven to be? The Labor Party originally voted against giving the Attorney-General the power to list terrorist organisations. It just would not cop that. In early 2004 the opposition changed its position on that issue. It took two years to think the thing through, during which period we could not list the organisations that were a threat to the nation. The Australian Labor Party was prepared to stand between our security and a sensible listing process. In a press release, the opposition has claimed that, if elected, it would repeal the provisions it agreed to. Has that been retracted, or does the Australian Labor Party still have a policy that it would prefer to have the United Nations list the terrorist organisations which are a threat to Australia rather than place that in Australian hands?

While we have been putting together all the steps I have listed to make Australia safe and building up the resources to do so, the Australian Labor Party failed the Australian community when it rejected the ASIO bill at the end of the 2002 parliamentary sittings, showing complete disregard for protecting the community. It passed the ASIO bill early in 2003 while at the same time indicating it was going to wind back some of ASIO's powers. Thanks to Labor, ASIO's powers to detain and question people with information about possible terrorists attacks and to gather details we need to prevent these attacks have been seriously diminished. That shows a half-hearted appreciation of what lies before us.

A more subtle and equally concerning example of this approach was the Leader of the Opposition's suggestion that the Australian Labor Party would support retrospective criminal laws to facilitate the return of Hicks and Habib from Guantanamo Bay, with no apparent consideration of how such an amendment could possibly work. How would you do that? Nobody has ever thought of doing it before. Australian nationals took possible action of a terrorist type, and they need to be brought to trial under the processes under which they were first apprehended. To change the criminal law retrospectively is just crazy.

I thank a journalist with the Australian for bringing our attention once more to the material prepared by Katharine Betts, professor of sociology at Swinburne, in the journal People and Place. She draws attention to the fact that the standards and values of the Australian Labor Party are quite different to those of the community. I give a couple of examples that Janet Albrechtsen uses. She points to the fact that on a range of social and economic factors the Australian Labor Party elected person holds quite a different view to that held by Labor Party voters. For instance, she found that more than half of all voters, including Labor voters, think that the American alliance is very important to Australia, yet less than one-quarter of Labor candidates agreed. Only one-quarter of the Labor Party candidates agreed that the American alliance is important but half the voters think it is important.

Another issue which is important is that one-third of Labor Party voters have a great deal of trust that the US would come to Australia's defence but just 12½ per cent of Labor representatives or candidates do. So, on every issue of major relationship with the United States and on these security issues, it appears that the Australian Labor Party candidates and members are more suspicious of America, more anti-American and less prone to want Australia to be secure than those people who vote Labor. It is no wonder that there is a deep concern out there amongst the Australian people that the Australian Labor Party really does not understand the urgency of the situation and the need for actions such as the amendments we are dealing with today. I welcome the Attorney-General and thank him for his careful application to some of these needs of Australia, for his consistency and for his preparedness to keep fighting on small issue after small issue, building block after building block, to put together over two years a very comprehensive package. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004 does a series of things. It amends the Passports Act 1938, it amends the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 and it amends the Crimes Act 1914. It does all of these in a manner so as to assist the Australian government in providing the foundations for protecting and preserving the maintenance of security within Australia and for Australian citizens. It does so against a background of a series of legislative acts over the last three years. Legislation to amend the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002, the Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism Act 2002, the Criminal Code Amendment (Suppression of Terrorist Bombings) Act 2002 and many other actions taken by this government are part of the package.

speech.para: In speaking to the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004, I want to look most importantly at the global context, the challenge we face, the reasons for our actions and the purpose which guides the steps that we now take. The proposition I present to the House is a simple one: we face a different type of challenge to any that we have faced before as an Australian society or as a global community—that is, the challenge of international terrorism capable, armed and equipped to act in such a way to bring violence as a means of carrying out political objectives across the world. It is not limited to Western, Christian, Jewish or Islamic societies; it is aimed at all societies which get in the way of the primary objective of al-Qaeda, its associates and its affiliates.

In that context, I want to address the three great challenges which Australia faces in dealing with antiterrorism: firstly, al-Qaeda; secondly, establishing a sound democratic society in the Middle East in Iraq; and, thirdly, terrorism within our own region. In looking at the question of al-Qaeda, it is important to understand three key things: its ideology, its strategy and its methods. The ideology of al-Qaeda is a simple one in many ways. It is to create an Islamic caliphate across the globe. Over a 100-year vision, it seeks to develop a world which replicates the society we saw in Afghanistan under the Taliban. It seeks a Taliban style globe. That is its express, clear and unequivocal objective.

What is that society? It is a perversion of Islam. It has as much connection to Islam as the Oklahoma City bombers had to Christianity. That was a perversion of Christianity. Al-Qaeda is a perversion of Islam. It breaches all of the fundamental tenets of that great religion and it seeks to do so for the benefit of those who carry a particular ideology. That is what we face: a clear world view.

Its strategy, which is also well known, is to break down Western engagement with the Islamic world, as a first stage. Its strategy is to drive out Western engagement so as to seek to capture over the next 30 years one of the four great Islamic countries—Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan or Indonesia—within our own area. Whether it is the Muslim brotherhood in Egypt, al-Qaeda or its affiliates in Saudi Arabia or in Pakistan, or Jemaah Islamiah in Indonesia, what we see in each of those countries is an attempt to destabilise the governments, to cause either the countries to fragment or their governments to be replaced by a Taliban style, ultraextremist Islamic government. It is not about Islam—that is a false debate; it is about a sliver of extremists who are willing to use any actions, anywhere, to achieve their outcomes. Their outcomes are, very simply, a worldwide Islamic caliphate; that is what they seek to achieve. Their strategy is very clear: to break off and drive out Western links so as to establish a toehold or a base. In the same way that, from the poorest country in the world, Afghanistan, when they effectively had control of the government through the Taliban, they were able to launch attacks upon different parts of the world, now they seek to do that with the resources of a major state.

Let me quote from the Australian government's recent white paper on terrorism, because it is very important to understand the scope, desire and brutality which underpins al-Qaeda's objectives. In their 1998 fatwa—or message of Islamic jihad—bin Laden, al-Zawahiri and other key members of al-Qaeda said that their objective and exhortation to others is:

quote.para: ... to kill Americans and their allies—civilians and military—is an individual duty for every Muslim who can do it in any country in which it is possible to do it, in order to liberate the Al-Aqsa Mosque and the holy mosque [in Mecca] from their grip, and in order for their armies to move out of all the lands of Islam, defeated and unable to threaten any Muslim.

speech.para: In June 2002, through an al-Qaeda spokesman, they go on to say:

quote.para: ... we have the right to kill four million Americans, including one million children, displace double that figure and injure and cripple hundreds of thousands. We have the right to fight them by chemical and biological weapons ...

speech.para: The first quote was in 1998. The second quote was before any activity was undertaken in Iraq. It is a mind-set which predated any current administration. It is a mind-set which was developed during the 1980s in Afghanistan. It is a mind-set which is deep and enduring and which, I say again to this House, is an utter perversion of the great and noble religion of Islam and does not represent Islam. It is, first and foremost, a civil war and an attack upon mainstream Islam.

Against that background, we also see that al-Qaeda are willing to and seek to carry out acts of large-scale violence which cause mass human suffering and which have mostly been associated with firepower and explosive capability. Whether it was September 11, Madrid, Tanzania, Tunisia, Kenya or, closer to home, the tragedy in Bali, we see the combination of heat and fire and the destruction of human lives on a mass scale. That is what they are willing to do and that is why it is a different kind of threat. There is no doubt that the Australian mainland is a target—of course it is a target—as are all Western cities and all cities of any faith or denomination around the world where it might conceivably help al-Qaeda's objectives. That is the nature of the threat. We will see more assassinations, more beheadings and more large-scale terror activities. The nature of the threat is great.

That leads me to the second great challenge that we have: the question of securing peace in Iraq. Very simply, what is occurring there is an attempt to take the world's most dictatorial and brutal society—a Stalinist society, which would carry out systematic rape and brutality against its own people, which had a history and practice of using and developing chemical and biological weapons and capability; from the Butler report, David Kay's report and the Flood report, there is no doubt that that capability existed and was being worked on; there is also no doubt, to the best of my knowledge, that Iraq is the only state in the last 50 years to have used such weapons in conflict, both internationally and against its own civilian population—and replace it with a fledgling democratic society. Democracy, as we know, is the enemy of al-Qaeda. In one of the statements, al-Zawahiri characterises democracy as a false religion. Of al-Zawahiri, the white paper says:

quote.para: For him, people who live in democracies, particularly in Muslim countries, are therefore legitimate targets because, by voting and paying taxes, they participate in the `idolatrous' democratic process. Similarly, those who seek to promote democracy in Muslim countries are also deemed to be targets.

speech.para: Very simply, what we see is an attack upon the very possibility that an Islamic society might become democratic. To me, that is an outrageous thing, and it is something which we have to resist.

It was always going to be a difficult process—a difficult challenge—in Iraq. But, if it is not a worthwhile purpose to take on the challenge of transforming a society that lived in terror, that was in the thrall of a dictator and where women could be taken at the whim of senior officials and used for their own purposes, then I am sadly mistaken. To me, that is a courageous and noble activity. Yes, it has been controversial, but it has been fundamental to what we are, what we believe and what we seek to become as a society. It represents the goals of promoting democracy, providing to people a basic life that is free of terror and providing to people choice over their own personal futures. That is what is occurring in Iraq.

Against that, there are two forces. There are the remnants of Saddam Hussein's Baathist regime who seek to recapture what they have lost, and there are those who take up the words of al-Zawahiri, Qutb and bin Laden. They seek to destroy any hope for a free society—if that were to come about—because they see in their failed society the seeds of their own growth and of their own extremist version of an Islamic caliphate. That is why Australia is involved in Iraq. That is why we take the difficult steps. As I said before, there will be more assassinations, beheadings and mass explosions targeted at civilian populations so as to create terror.

We face these things closer to home as well. We see them within our own region. Jemaah Islamiah brought about the horror of the Bali bombings, in which 202 lives were lost, 88 of them Australian. In that situation, their goal is very clear: it is to bring down the Indonesian government, to cause Indonesia to fragment, to cause Australia and other Western nations to break ranks with Indonesia—which now works as a new, secular and democratic country—and to set about creating a pan South-East Asian caliphate across the southern parts of the Philippines and through Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei. That is the stated goal of Jemaah Islamiah. Our job is simple. Our job is to recognise that we have to take steps to resist and prevent the triumph of these types of activities. It is a battle on the ground, and it is a battle of ideas. There are four great steps we must take. Firstly, we must be involved in development and providing economic opportunities. Secondly, we have to be involved in education. Thirdly, we have to be involved in joint policing. Fourthly, we have to be involved in security within the region, internationally—which is what we are involved in with Afghanistan and particularly Iraq—and at home. This bill helps complement the armoury in terms of our homeland protection.

For those reasons, I support completely the measures contained within the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004. I commend the bill to the House and urge all members of this House to be ever vigilant to the fact that we face a challenge to our security at home, to our Australian people abroad and to our way of life. It is a challenge from people who care nothing for it but simply seek to impose a world that is anathema to everything we believe. For that reason, our task as legislators and Australian citizens is to say with unbending will that we will defend, protect and do everything we can to ensure that Australia plays a constructive role in the world as we see it in the first part of the 21st century.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I would like to thank the honourable members for Barton and Melbourne Ports, from the opposition, and my colleagues the members for Dickson, Mitchell and Flinders for their contributions to this debate on the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 3) 2004. I appreciate my colleagues' very perceptive speeches. They covered the broad range of issues that we have to deal with in this scourge of terrorism that we face. They have certainly outlined the breadth of measures that we have taken, but they have also made some very incisive speeches on the nature of the threat. I thank them very much for their contributions to this debate.

speech.para: I think it is important to understand that the opposition's contribution and support, while appreciated, should be understood for what it is. This is the lowest common denominator result. We have a bill that has been introduced to enable us to legislate, hopefully during this fortnight, to deal with two aspects of the government's agenda in relation to counter-terrorism but excluding two others that were part of the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004, which remains before a Senate committee. While I welcome the support for these measures, I suspect that any opposition would be very hard put to oppose the reasonableness of what is intended here. They are two very important practical issues that are of significance to the security of this country as well as going some way to dealing with the consequences of a terrorist attack or a national disaster, were they to occur. The procedures in schedules 1 and 2 for the surrender of passports will play a vital role in enabling Australian authorities to effectively seal the border to escaping terrorists. There is not much point in having a sophisticated system for the surrender of Australian passports if the suspect can avoid that system just by using a foreign passport. What opposition would say they are happy enough to have people stopped from using their Australian passport but `ta-ta' if they want to use a foreign passport? They could not do it. It would be totally irresponsible and they would be held up to ridicule. For that reason, they have to support it.

The amendments concerning foreign travel documents will also enable authorities to take them from those suspected of other serious crimes such as child sex offences. All countries need to work together to impede the movement of criminals across the globe as well as those who are terrorists or suspected of terrorism. I am pleased to see that members understand the need for these amendments. They will make a difference in our effort to prevent a terrorist attack. The provisions in schedule 3, which would enable authorities to use forensic procedures laws to identify the victims of a mass casualty incident, are, sadly, a lesson that we have learnt from Bali. No longer can this country rely on myriad state laws to deal with such incidents.

Following Bali, the parliament met the challenge by enacting a federal law. What we want to avoid is the necessity, if there is such a tragic event again, of having to introduce a single enactment in the shadow of such a tragedy. We need to act now in preparation for a possible domestic incident. It is pleasing to see that there will be support for this measure, but I say again it is not a measure that I would suspect that any opposition could oppose. I think these are the lowest common denominator results, and I make that clear—I want to say that to the shadow Attorney-General to his face rather than behind his back, and I welcome him back to the chamber. May I also record my thanks to Tom Sherman, whose review of the provisions enacted immediately following the Bali attack identified the need for forensic amendments. The review was made up of officers of the Privacy Commissioner, the Ombudsman, the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Federal Police.

Let me say, back in June it was certainly my hope to have these reasonable amendments in place, and it is fortunate that there has not been an incident of some sort that might have led us to believe that we have been found wanting in relation to our own duties by not having had it passed in the earlier session. But I do want to make the point, and it is a very important point, that the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2004, from which these provisions have been abstracted, is nevertheless a very important piece of legislation and is deserving of support in the same way as this bill is deserving of support.

Let me deal with the issues that remain. The first is in relation to association with terrorist organisations. This proposed offence would enable authorities to prosecute those who, through their relationships with the directors, promoters and members of terrorist organisations, assist them to expand or continue to exist. I might just say—and I will continue to say this in the days and weeks ahead—that this measure is important. The measures that we have dealing with terrorists at the moment require us to first establish as an essential element that they are engaged in planning a terrorist act. It is a quite significant limitation. It is the starting point, and it is a difficult starting point from which to be able to proceed to prosecute. The provisions that we have sought here are provisions that have been requested, and I am sure the shadow Attorney-General noticed recently the remarks of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police in support of a measure of this sort to give us a more complete set of legislative provisions.

The other matter that was excluded is something that I thought state premiers had sought. I noticed recently that they have wanted to raise questions about consultation. I have no problems about consultation or sitting down and working out better arrangements, but the provisions that were included in the Anti-terrorism Bill (No. 2) included the transfer of prisoners who, for national security reasons, ought to be able to be moved from a jail in one state to a more appropriate facility either within that state or elsewhere. It has been criticised, I gather, as a proposal which is moving a little too quickly, but let me just say that the idea of such transfers was raised over six months ago by state officials with Commonwealth officials and we were trying to respond quickly to that. As I said, I have no problem about our officials working through with the states to be conscious of their requirements as well, but I think you do need to be in a position where for national security purposes people can be shifted between one centre and another—sometimes for their own safety and protection; sometimes to protect the broader community.

I think those measures remain important. I very much regret that, with the way in which the Senate deals with these matters, it takes time. I suspect that the measures that ought to be dealt with in relation to association with terrorists and the transfer of prisoners will be delayed by many months simply because these matters have been referred to a committee. That is a regrettable outcome. I think the matters remain urgent and I will continue to press the importance of those. So, while welcoming the support of the opposition for the lowest common denominator result, and I do, let me encourage them to be more proactive in these matters and to join the government in implementing those measures which have been recommended to us—advanced by the officers who have the expertise, knowledge and experience in these matters—and which are important for enabling us to deal with the antiterrorism issues in a comprehensive way. I again thank my colleagues for their contributions during the debate. I hope the Senate can deal with the matter during the course of this week.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay—Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (1.30 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That notice No. 3, government business, be postponed until a later hour this day.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 June, on motion by Mr Costello:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 is the government's response to the Dawson review, an inquiry which in fact reported 15 months ago—and someone has to be answerable as to why it has taken so long to respond to it. The reality is that the Dawson response at the time was widely criticised as inadequate. As a consequence, a process was set up in the Senate to consider and report on further alterations to strengthen competition in the economy and to consider further amendments to the Trade Practices Act. That Senate process reported in June and made some 17 recommendations, only one of which is picked up in this bill. It is the one aspect of the bill which we believe is important, an aspect, also recommended by Dawson, that goes to collective bargaining opportunities for small business. But the rest of this legislation is inadequate and a disappointing response both to Dawson and to the Senate deliberations.

speech.para: With the other aspect of this legislation, the new tribunal, there are some serious concerns which we believe require further consideration and analysis. Also there is the failure by this legislation to respond to any of the other 16 recommendations made by the Senate process that I have alluded to, despite the fact that two of those recommendations were adopted and recommended unanimously by the Senate.
It is against that background that I move:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading in order not to block the passage of the collective bargaining provisions for small business, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) combining important small business reforms and highly contentious changes to the merger approval regime in the same Bill; and
(2) not adopting all the recommendations of the Report of the Senate Inquiry into “The effectiveness of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in protecting small business” ”.
We believe that is the desired way this should go and obviously that opportunity will present itself in the Senate.

So I indicate that we move that amendment and seek to have the House determine that approach. But in the Senate it is our intention to seek to have the bill split so that the aspect of it that we believe does deserve carriage can be carried and the concerns about the new tribunal sent to a Senate committee of inquiry. We will also move amendments to seek to have adopted those recommendations made by the Senate to strengthen the trade practices legislation to strengthen competition in this economy.

This bill, as I said, is a very disappointing attempt at improving the trade practices law. I made the point before that the Dawson review actually reported 15 months ago. Little wonder this government is getting the reputation of being seriously out of puff. What sort of a government is it that commissions a review into an important area like this, gets that review and then 15 months down the track brings forward this inadequate response? We have heard this government criticising Labor for wanting a Senate review into the free trade agreement—a review which took something like two or three months—and our being criticised for dithering. What sort of dithering is it when you have a Treasurer who has been sitting on a report for 15 months who only then brings legislation before the parliament just before an election? The gall of the government: to be critical of the opposition for taking time to insist on important reviews of the free trade agreement, one dimension of which the government immediately picked up yesterday—that is, the protection of local content. Within two hours of Labor proposing its approach, the government picked it up—we hope they do the same with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. This shows the importance of inquiry and scrutiny. But in the circumstances where that scrutiny has occurred in relation to the Trade Practices Act, the government has ignored all but one of the recommendations coming from that process.

Just on the specifics of the collective bargaining provisions, which Labor supports and wants to see go through, Labor supported that measure 12 months ago. Yet it is only today, on the eve of an election, that the government pick it up. Why does it take them so long to adopt what Labor has flagged its support for, which could have been adopted through bipartisan agreement? Why does it take the government so long to act on these things? It was not until June 2004 that we saw this legislative response. In my view, it is the lateness and inadequacy of the government's response which demonstrates that there is no serious commitment by this government to a procompetitive reform agenda in this economy. They talk the words, but they do not implement the acts. They pretend to be in favour of competition, but they do not put in place the regime or legislative structure that guarantees it.

In the end, it was Labor's proposals that it put out for strengthening the Trade Practices Act that forced the government's hand. So here we are, 15 months late and with an inadequate response, despite the fact that the Senate has given great deliberation to this and made some important recommendations. Labor in office will put those recommendations into place. I thought the parliamentary secretary at the table had fallen asleep a moment ago. She was snoring away there. I think that is the government's approach in terms of dealing with the competition reform in this economy—they are asleep at the wheel.

talk.start.para: —There she is, snoring again! This government are asleep at the wheel, and it demonstrates itself on every occasion. They are given the way forward by Labor, but they do not know what to do with it. They sit around, they dither and they do nothing, yet small businesses in this country that really need these important reforms are the ones that suffer. But when we talk about this reform that took 15 months, it was not much of a response at all. Although in our view the Dawson review of the Trade Practices Act gave the government an ideal opportunity to take the big leap forward, they squibbed it. After all this time, they have come up with this mediocre reform.

speech.para: The bill is notable for what it does not include. I will mention some important areas. It does not include any strengthening of the act to stop the misuse of market power; nor does it do anything to stop the creeping acquisitions that erode market power by stealth while the ACCC is effectively unable to do anything to stop them. The pro small business reforms that are contained in this bill do not go far enough. Whilst Labor does support the introduction of a notification procedure that allows small business speedy and cheaper access to collective bargaining with big business, the government has oversold the importance of this measure. That is because, as the ACCC has repeatedly stated, the notification is just a procedural change. It is important, but it is only a partial response to the more complex problem of the abuse of market power, about which the government proposes to do nothing.

I will come in a minute to the details of what Labor proposes in this area to really strengthen competition and support small business in the community. Before that, I want to underpin the importance of competition for a dynamic economy. Competition is vital to driving a higher capacity for economic growth, lifting the growth rate of the nation and sharing the benefits. We all know the reforms that Labor undertook during the eighties—the reforms which opened up and internationalised the economy. Labor did this by taking tough decisions to reduce tariff levels, float the dollar and liberalise the banking system. Labor also embarked on a very strong procompetition set of policies. A lot has been done in that area, and I give credit to the government. They have done some important things too. But the truth is that a lot more needs to be done, and the major piece of unfinished business on the agenda is the cutting back of the abuse of market power. This is one of the fundamental pillars upon which the ACCC and its precursors were formed. On the face of it, it was to ensure that there was no abuse of market power, but we are continuing to see examples of how that is being whittled away. We have to continue to push the reform agenda to set the nation on that higher growth path. It occurs by creating the efficiency gains that will drive productivity. That is the only reliable way to increase living standards in the long term.

The story goes something like this: productivity growth is not just about liberalising tariffs and cutting costs. Productivity growth flows from improved economic efficiency, but this depends on getting the price mechanism right. There is no surer way to restrict efficiency than to undermine the capacity of prices to signal the efficient allocation of economic resources in an economy. The thing that most undermines efficient price setting is monopoly behaviour—the abuse of market power. If we constrain this abuse, we will get greater efficiency as an economy. As a consequence of that, we will get greater productivity, higher growth and better living standards. It is good for the economy. It makes sense. But for Labor it is about more than just expanding the wealth cake. It is also about fairness. What Labor has always argued is: you have to invest in the drivers of economic growth and you have to lift economic growth, but you have to seek prosperity for a purpose.

Through tough competition laws you not only guarantee higher overall returns but you create greater balance between small business, or the consumer, and the powerful vested interests of the wealthy elite who control corporate Australia. Competition policy is about creating a fairer playing field, not just an even one. It is about defending the rights of average Australians—the little people—which strong financial power and pressure could be used to undermine.

But this is not the government's vision. On the contrary: their competition policy seems to work from the opposite pole. It gives concessions, it supports this continuing abuse of market power by big business. Labor is concerned that the proposed merger arrangements may be providing a very significant concession to big business. The new authorisation process means that proponents of a merger who believe they will fail the competition test can apply to this new tribunal to have their merger considered on public interest grounds. Labor's fear is that the merger changes appear to be designed to make it easier to get larger merger proposals approved. That is why we believe the intent of this legislation needs greater scrutiny.

The former head of the ACCC, Professor Alan Fels, is strongly opposed to the merger authorisation process, embodied in this legislation, which bypasses the ACCC and goes straight to the Competition Tribunal. He suggested that there will be significant mechanical difficulties associated with the tribunal. This is because it is not an investigative body but primarily a judicial one. He also notes that there will be no rights of appeal for consumers, the people for whom the competition laws are structured to give a better go and fairer prices.

Labor is open to all measures to maximise the efficiency and effectiveness of the merger authorisation process. If there have been delays in the authorisation process these can be dealt with by reforming the current arrangements. But the current arrangements are still functional, even if they could be improved. Last year, the ACCC considered 191 merger proposals. Of these, it objected to nine because they were likely to substantially lessen competition, and two of these proceeded following enforceable undertakings being provided.

In light of these concerns, a Labor government will seek to have these new merger provisions carved out of the bill in the Senate and sent to a Senate committee for review. Failing this, Labor commits to review the whole mechanism in government. We will ensure that the interests of consumers and small business are considered in any merger authorisation process. Labor's policy promises more substantial reform and will deliver a more efficient pricing regime. It will, as a consequence, produce improved productivity gains and growth.

Labor has already announced a seven-point plan to ensure that this happens in the area of competition reform. We have proposed that section 46 of the Trade Practices Act be strengthened and that predatory pricing be explicitly banned. The ACCC will be given the power to issue `cease and desist orders' to provide immediate relief against market abuse and anticompetitive conduct. Courts will be granted a new power to order the divestiture of assets to tackle the worst cases of market abuse or cartel behaviour. The Trade Practices Act will be amended to put a brake on large companies accumulating smaller enterprises in a way that lessens competition. Labor will also restore some balance to the relationship between franchisees and parent companies by allowing the ACCC to bundle up complaints against a parent company.

The sixth point of that seven-point plan ensures that the ACCC's independence will be preserved by building into the Trade Practices Act a formal statutory review of the act, and ensuring all appointments to the ACCC are made on the basis of independence and expertise. The final point of Labor's plan is that greater transparency will be applied to the ACCC's merger undertaking process by forcing the ACCC to report on firms' compliance with their undertakings.

Labor has also participated in a comprehensive Senate inquiry—the inquiry that I referred to at the beginning of this speech. `The effectiveness of the Trade Practises Act 1974 in protecting small business,' was the title and the consideration of that Senate process. Seventeen recommendations came from that process. Labor supports all 17 of the recommendations of the committee. The government has only acted on one of these recommendations, the collective bargaining notification for small business. Although three others are uncontroversial, the government has not even bothered to include them in the bill. You have to ask yourself, `Where is the serious commitment to reform by this government when it will not even include the uncontroversial issues, let alone those other recommendations I talked about?' It also shows how the government is not seriously seeking to reform the Trade Practices Act.

We call on the government to work with the opposition to bring into law all the committee's recommendations where possible. It is a genuine offer in terms of bipartisan support from us. This has been the subject of review and deliberation. Recommendations have been made. They have been made on the basis of the evidence presented. This is a genuine offer on Labor's part to work with the government to implement them. What we will do in the Senate is move amendments to give effect to the committee's recommendations, including strengthening provisions relating to unconscionable conduct, enhancing the ACCC's ability to seek injunctions to quickly tackle anticompetitive conduct and improving access to justice for small business by expanding the jurisdiction of the Federal Magistrates Court.

For some time Labor has been highlighting the problems with section 46 of the Trade Practices Act. It is true that the High Court's decisions in the Boral case and the Rural Press case have narrowed the scope of section 46. The ACCC has pleaded with the government to strengthen the law. Only last month, its chairman stated that the commission regards section 46, as presently drafted, as being reasonably ineffective. Why then isn't the government seeking to do something in this legislation to strengthen the hand of the ACCC, to address the concerns and the deficiencies established and identified through the court processes and in response to the chairman saying that the current provisions are reasonably ineffective? One would have thought that that would be the signal for the government to act. But where is the action? All that has happened is that the government has gone missing in action because it does not believe in real support for small business, in strengthening their hand and in ensuring true competition and true effective market power.

Under the competition principles agreement, the Commonwealth agreed to amend part 4 of the act only after consultation with the states. Therefore, in this bill we will not move amendments to section 46, but we really believe that the government needs to take action in this regard. Labor will, however, be seeking to further amend section 46 in the Senate as a priority on coming to government. Those amendments to section 46 will clarify the scope of some of the competition tests under section 46, further define the meaning of predatory pricing, make the financial power of `entity' a relevant consideration in considering market power, ensure that the scope of the competition tests extend beyond individual markets and clarify that companies can be seen to have substantial market power by acting in concert with other companies.

In conclusion, we have a government that is missing in action in terms of competition law reform; a government that has been sent the signals not only by the chairman of the ACCC—as a consequence of the whittling down of the effectiveness of the intent of the act by various cases in the courts—but also by recommendations of a Senate committee after taking submissions. What we have before the House today is weak policy. It is weak policy because it is limited in its approach. It is limited to enabling the collective bargaining operations of small business—which we welcome and want to support. But this legislation should have gone much further. Just like so many other things that this government talks about and says it believes in, it fails the test when it comes to the real activity and the real amendments.

This legislation highlights a government without a vision for this country, a government that is out of puff, a government that talks the words of competition and fairness in the marketplace but does not enact legislation and take steps to ensure that that happens. We believe it is time for a change. The Australian people will have the opportunity to make that change in the not too distant future. In relation to this legislation, we want the government to work with us now, in the time available, to implement the Senate recommendations. We could get bipartisan support and bring the strengthened trade practices legislation before this parliament. The government stands condemned for its failure to do so. Labor's commitment is to do it on attaining office. I commend the second reading amendment to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hotham has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

—I am very pleased to rise to speak this afternoon on the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. Whilst I intend to dive into some of the more substantial matters that are contained within this bill, I will take the very short period of time available to me prior to question time today to address and respond to some of the arguments that were raised by the shadow Treasurer. I was bemused to hear the shadow Treasurer claim in this chamber that the ALP is a friend to small business. It is hilarious that the Australian Labor Party would come into this chamber at a time when, as part of its policy platform, it is proposing the introduction of a new federal payroll tax of 0.1 per cent and claim that it is the Labor Party that is the friend of the Australian small business sector. Nothing could be further from the truth.

speech.para: I heard the shadow Treasurer make all sorts of claims along these lines. Among his claims was that, as part of the ALP's policy, there are seven key points that the ALP would like to see introduced to help business and consumers in the Australian economy. I guess that some of those key policy platforms that the ALP is adopting to help small business must have been forgotten by the shadow Treasurer. The payroll tax was not mentioned. Perhaps the shadow Treasurer forgot that.
