debate.para: Debate (on motion by Ms Gillard) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable Leader of the Opposition proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The Government's failure to adequately protect the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and Australian cultural content rules in its Free Trade Agreement enabling legislation.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Over the last two days, we have seen the validation of Labor's approach to the trade agreement with the United States. It was indeed a complex agreement. It was 1,100 pages long and stacked with detail, so we said at the beginning of this year that we owed it to the Australian people to examine it in a thorough way and we also owed it to the Australian people to let them have their say about the FTA. This is what I have described as the new politics—more public participation and more involvement in the decisions of government. Of course, it took a long time for the Howard government to deliver all the information about the FTA. The final appeal mechanism for the PBS, for example, was only delivered to the public arena 10 days ago.

speech.para: We know, of course, that at the beginning of this year the government rushed in and left sugar out. At one time, the Deputy Prime Minister said that it would be un-Australian to leave sugar out of this agreement, but that is exactly what they did. By the definition of the Leader of the National Party, the government did an un-Australian thing. By contrast, the Labor Party were determined to get it right and, despite the Prime Minister's bagging of the Senate committee and his bagging of the process by which these matters were considered, we thought it was the right thing to look at it in a thorough and considered way.

Already I can report a dividend on our approach, with the Prime Minister giving ground on the question of cultural content. Would it have happened if not for the Senate committee and the Labor Party amendments? No way in the world. There is no way in the world that this Prime Minister would have given ground on the issue of cultural content, if the Labor Party had not raised the issue, if it had not been considered by the Senate report and if strong Senate recommendations had not been made on this subject. The current rules would have been inadequate. The current rules would have left the matter of this nation's great cultural content to the Australian Broadcasting Authority—that is, a David Flint type flunkey in the future would have been the custodian of the local content rules and it would have taken a resolution of both houses of parliament to disallow a weakening of those cultural content rules.

If it had been left to the Prime Minister and the government, we would have had a hopelessly inadequate situation, with no practical safeguards against someone like David Flint down at the ABA weakening away the local content rules and then, under the trade agreement with the United States, the ratchet provisions ensuring that they could never be lifted again in the future. The Labor Party have a different approach. We have suggested amendments that would write the current local content rules into the schedule of the trade agreement and into the enabling legislation of the trade agreement. Then any attempt to water things down would require the approval of both houses: that is, it would not happen—it would not happen in the future. Only Labor are bringing forward recommendations to ensure that those content rules cannot be watered down in the future. We want to enshrine them in the schedule of the enabling legislation to the FTA. That way it would require both houses to water them down, and that would not happen in practical terms.

But the Prime Minister says he is now considering Labor's amendment. Well, it is long overdue. If he had not rushed into the agreement, if he had a thorough respect for the Senate process, it would have happened before now. Of course we saw his remarkable comments. It is a real road to Damascus conversion on this question of local content. Due to the Labor Party and the Senate committee, we had the Prime Minister on the Mike Carlton program this morning saying:

quote.para: ... I am very concerned about local content, don't anybody think I want this country swamped by American material, there's a lot of American stuff on television I don't care for at all ...

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Grayndler has been warned!

—No-one would have heard those comments—those comments would never have been made—if not for Labor's decision to have a Senate process, to have public and expert examination of the FTA, to come up with relevant recommendations for the future. So the Prime Minister has had a road to Damascus conversion, but it has only happened because of the work of the Senate committee. It is only through Labor that we have now got the Prime Minister headed in the right direction—a direction which will ensure, under our amendments, that we have still got Australian faces on Australian TV, that we have still got Australian voices on Australian radio.

speech.para: We say that we in this country should be proud of our culture. We respect the culture of other nations right around the world, but there is something special about Australian culture. There is something distinctive about the Australian way of expressing ourselves, of relating to other people. Whether we call it the larrikin spirit, Australian mateship or any other description, we all know as proud Australians on this side of the House that there is something special about Australian culture. There is something special about the Australian way of expressing ourselves in the media. That is why we support the local content rules. That is why we would never tolerate a situation where in the future, someone like David Flint down at the ABA—a Flint type flunky—could erode the local content rules and where, in practical terms, there would be nothing the Australian parliament could do about it.

We have seen already, through the deliberations and the decisions of the Labor Party, a dividend on the Senate committee process. The Prime Minister is moving in the right direction. We do not know if that means enshrining these rules in regulation or putting them into the schedule of the enabling legislation, which is Labor's preferred approach. But we have got the first sign of a dividend coming through on the deliberative, considered process that we embarked on at the beginning of this year.

Now the Labor Party is looking for a second dividend, given the major public concern about evergreening and the impact on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. The new notification system, whereby generics are required to tell patent companies, will of course have an incentive, an encouragement, for patent companies to evergreen—that is, to lodge bodgie applications not based on the chemical content of the particular product but rather on commercial considerations; it is what is described as the `different coloured pill scenario'. These bodgie applications would be designed to delay the entry of new generic drugs into the Australian market—generic drugs that would be cheaper for the PBS, cheaper for the Australian people.

There are, of course, sensible Senate recommendations. The Labor senators have put forward recommendation No. 25 to create fines and offences for spurious patent claims. Of course, the government is doing exactly the same thing under the Therapeutic Goods Act for false patent certificates lodged by generic companies. The government, for these certificates that are not valid relating to patents, is planning to impose $110,000 fines plus criminal offences. The government is writing these things into the FTA enabling legislation. It is there in black and white—an amendment to the Therapeutic Goods Act so that the generic companies would face fines of $110,000 and, indeed, criminal offences. We make the simple proposition: why not the same set of fines for the patent companies? The concerns are well known. They have been well aired in the public arena. Why take a risk with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme? Why take the risk of delaying the entry of generic drugs onto the Australian market when there is a recommendation that provides a safeguard—a guarantee, a peace of mind—for the Australian people?

In this area the stakes are high. The generics can produce a price decrease of 30 per cent—so valuable to the Australian people, so valuable to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so valuable to Australian pharmaceutical consumers. Just have a look at the impact of generics in the area of Prozac, used for the treatment of depression. The generics drive down the cost of a packet by $20—a really significant impact for the benefit of consumers. So too the impact on Zantac, for the treatment of ulcers and reflux, with generics driving down the price per packet by $20. For Australian consumers over time, and given that the FTA is forever, these are genuine concerns. If we can get the generics onto the market faster—certainly with no delay—there are enormous cost-of-living benefits to the Australian people, particularly the low-income earners who most need that assistance.

I say to the Howard government: why not provide the safeguard amendments to ensure these benefits are available? Why not provide the safeguard amendments to ensure these benefits are available now and into the future? The government has a few firewall excuses, a few things it has put up. Firstly, Minister Vaile has said that the government regard it as unnecessary. That is what he said in his press release yesterday: `The government rejects as unnecessary a second condition on Labor's FTA support.' If they regard it as unnecessary, if the Prime Minister is saying that these bodgie applications will not be lodged in the future, what has he to fear from Labor's amendments? If he is saying that these are penalties that will never be imposed, what has he got to fear from Labor's amendment, passing it through and getting his FTA?

I fear that this is a case of the Prime Minister yet again not being honest with the Australian people. We know the Prime Minister is under pressure from the pharmaceutical companies. And so far he is supporting their side of the argument. If the Prime Minister has nothing to fear, if the minister thinks it is unnecessary, pass Labor's amendment. Pass Labor's amendment as a safeguard for the future of pharmaceutical prices in this country. This is an example of the Prime Minister not being honest and frank with the Australian people. We say he should not take the risk. He should reject the arguments from the pharmaceutical companies and side with the Australian consumers.

The second argument the government have put forward—and this is their new argument today—is that the Labor amendments would be unworkable. Why then is the government amending the Therapeutic Goods Act to fine generic companies that lodge false applications and certificates with regard to patents?

talk.start.para: —Why don't they do the same with regard to spurious patent applications from the major companies?
—The member for Hotham has been warned!

—Labor's Senate amendments are sound. The government are actually going down this path of new fines, new criminal offences and new penalties in the FTA enabling legislation, but they are only doing it on one side of the street. They are only doing it to the generic companies instead of targeting the problem of potentially spurious patent applications. Why have one set of rules—one set of fines for the generic companies? Why not apply those fines and penalties across the board and ensure that the safeguards are in place for the benefit of the Australian people?

speech.para: I hear the Minister for Foreign Affairs scoffing away about all this. What does he say? What does he say to the Australian Medical Association about their support for Labor's amendment? If he will not take the word of the Labor Party, he should take the word of the AMA, because the AMA have welcomed the decision of the federal Labor Party to support the FTA, subject to the legislative amendments that safeguard the PBS. Let me read from the AMA press release:

quote.para: ... the right of generic pharmaceuticals to be marketed as soon as the originator patent expires must be guaranteed.

speech.para: That is what the Australian Medical Association are saying. It is a sad day for health policy in this country when the Minister for Trade, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Health and Ageing and the Prime Minister himself are not willing to listen to the Australian Medical Association on a matter as important as this. The AMA say:

quote.para: This legislation should ensure that the FTA does not undermine the PBS ...

speech.para: They say that these safeguards must be in place before Australia signs off on the FTA. It is not just the AMA who have flagged these concerns. The JSCOT report, from the inquiry which was chaired by the member for Boothby, raises concerns about the impact of the FTA on the generics. JSCOT made some observations and recommendations that flagged a very similar concern to the one now being raised by the Labor Party. It is the AMA, the Senate report and the JSCOT report making all these recommendations, but the government is not listening to commonsense. The government is not listening to what it would otherwise regard as its own interests. It says that it wants the trade agreement passed through the Senate. It has given ground on the cultural content rules. If it is good enough to do it on Labor's first amendment, it should be done on both amendments. It should be done on both amendments because it is our determination to fight for these amendments. We insisted on the review process in the first place, and that has raised valid concerns on behalf of the Australian people.

There are two matters outstanding that need to be addressed in the legislative process. The text of the FTA is not in dispute. What needs to happen is the strengthening of the enabling legislation. Strengthen the enabling legislation to ensure that the cultural content rules are part of the schedule. They should be scheduled into the legislation itself so there is a guarantee for the Australian people that we are going to have Australian faces on TV and Australian voices on radio and we are not going to have those rules weakened into the future. Labor also has sensible amendments to protect the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to ensure there is absolutely no delay in getting generic pharmaceutical products onto the Australian market.

If this government were fair dinkum about the national interest, if it were fair dinkum about good policy making, if it were fair dinkum about the trade agreement and the process and the legislation in the Senate, it would pass the Labor amendments this week in the interests of the Australian people.

talk.start.para: —Three days next time, I might warn the member for Grayndler!

—We are going to fight and insist for those interests all the way down the line. Every day in this parliament, we will be insisting on and fighting for our amendments. We want them adopted and, if the government wants its trade agreement, it will adopt Labor's amendments by the end of the week. (Time expired)

—In responding to this matter of public importance moved by the Leader of the Opposition, I want to clarify exactly the point at issue here in terms of ensuring the sustainability and the affordability of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme in Australia, and the ability of the audiovisual sector in Australia to deliver Australian stories on Australian free-to-air television and radio in Australian voices. From the day that we concluded these negotiations in Washington, we have contended that we have done that and that we have delivered in full the commitments that we made to the Australian people in terms of our objectives on those defensive issues that we went to prosecute in the negotiations in Washington.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition is alleging that, because there is an undertaking in the free trade agreement to notify, by certification, a patent holder of the advent of a generic drug on the market through the TGA process or to provide a certificate that one does not exist, that automatically is going to lead to a process of evergreening, as it is known in the United States. We argue quite clearly that that will not and cannot happen in Australia. The systems are totally different. We have given an undertaking in this agreement that, when a producer of a generic drug—that is, a drug that has been developed for use after the expiry of a patent drug—goes to the TGA for registration of their drug, one of the conditions is that they should either supply a certificate that indicates whether a patent exists on that drug and whether the patent holder has been notified or supply a certificate to the TGA that there is no patent in existence. That is the end of the story when that certificate is delivered.

It is alleged then that, through that notification process, patent holders are going to embark upon the sorts of litigious interventions that stop generic drugs getting onto the market—the way it sometimes happens under the American system. That cannot happen in Australia because we have a totally different system. We heard the Leader of the Opposition during question time and earlier on the MPI argue that this is about protecting the PBS. We have protected the PBS as a result of these negotiations and the undertakings in the agreement.

I will now go to the core issue of the challenge that could be raised to the registration of generic drugs. In the United States, if the originator—that is, the patent holder—files patent infringement litigation against the generic applicant, an automatic 30-month injunction is available, thereby preventing the generic application from being approved and the generic drug coming onto the market during that 30-month period.

In Australia, no automatic injunction is available outside of the court process. As was indicated during question time, it can only be instigated by a patent holder, not someone that has a patent pending. It should be noted that a patent applicant cannot take action against an alleged infringement of their invention until the patent has been granted, thus limiting the scope for patent applications to be used to frustrate legitimate exploitation of non-patented material.

It is also important to note the very clear difference between the Australian and American systems. In America, if a drug company has a patented drug for a particular use—for example, if the drug is for use by adults—they can automatically get an extension after the expiration of that patent for use by children. That does not exist in Australia. The ability to seek that 30-month injunction does not exist in Australia, so it is a totally different circumstance. The government's argument against this proposition is that the basis of the proposition—that, as a result of the FTA, we are opening the system up to more litigation and to patent holders slowing down or stopping the flow of generic drugs onto the marketplace—is false. The unworkability of this is, if you apply this sort of punitive measure to what are being loosely called spurious applications, will that then affect the entire patent law? Are you expecting to amend the entire patent law, which encourages the development of innovation and technology in this country? Are we going to destroy the ambition of innovators in this country? If they are going to have an adjudication on whether their argument for a patent is spurious and therefore they are going to be hit with a punitive action, are we going to destroy that innovation in this country? We argue we should not be doing that on a false premise. We argue that the premise by which this is being raised is false and unnecessary.

I will go back to the objectives that we set out to achieve in this negotiation. I was involved on behalf of government in negotiating this agreement, both on the offensive issues—the issues that we wanted to achieve in terms of improved market access and removing barriers to trade between our two countries—and of course on these all-important defensive issues, and they exist in every negotiation. That is what, in the end, creates a finely balanced negotiated outcome where you do not always get everything you want. We know that we did not get everything that we wanted, and we put our hands up and said, `We didn't achieve that.' We wanted to achieve more. But nor did the Americans achieve everything that they went out to achieve, and this is one area where they were really energetic, pushing hard to open up. We argued long and hard during the negotiations that our system in Australia was extremely unique. There are many countries in the world that want to replicate what we do in Australia. We saw that on the Four Corners program on Monday night. We know that, and that is why we want to always defend the structure, the sustainability and the pricing and listing mechanisms that we have in the PBS today, and we did. The PBS is not under threat as a result of the free trade agreement.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Hunter has no licence to come in here and interject.

—A crucial part of this negotiation in terms of some of the objectives that our counterparts were pursuing was the issue that would have affected the movement of generic drugs onto the market in a timely fashion. One of the American ambitions in the negotiations was to extend the data protection period on patented drugs from five years to eight years. That is what exists in the United States—an eight-year protection on the molecular structure of the patented drugs. In Australia today, it is five years. On 1 January 2005, when this agreement enters into force, it will still be five years. We resisted that move because we knew exactly the impact that would have on the generic drug industry in Australia: pushing back by three years their ability to get on the market. We resisted that, and that is not in this agreement.

speech.para: It is a very important point in terms of highlighting the government's position and the energy and focus that we put into protecting the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme as we know it in Australia. We are unlike many other countries in the world because the taxpayers of Australia invest hundreds of millions of dollars in research into and development of pharmaceuticals in this country. We argued for weeks in this negotiation that that made us different to anybody else in the world, and that we are not freeloading on American or European innovation. We pay our way in this country. But we were going to defend the right of this government and our nation to maintain one of the best structured health systems in the world—the core of that being the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme—and we have done that.

So we are quite prepared to stand and debate this issue of whether or not the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is being opened up to weakening as a result of this agreement. We say it is not being opened up to weakening. The points I have outlined here and the points that have been made during question time today show that we have defended that. We have defended vigorously the ability of the generic drug industry in Australia to get their product onto the market in a timely fashion—and not just to get it onto the Australian market but to springboard it into third-country markets overseas. This is a very important element, because we want to maintain a sustainable, viable and competitive generic drug industry in this country. It is a very valuable industry in this country.

The other issue, that was raised by the opposition yesterday and has been raised again today with this MPI, is with regard to the audiovisual sector and local content rules in the services sector of the FTA. It is another area of great importance to a nation of only 20 million people with a unique culture and a unique way of life that is not necessarily impacted upon as much as many other countries in the world by an influx through the media of culture from other parts of the world.

From the outset we had a clear indication from the industry involved, if I can term it that way—from the audiovisual sector, the actors, the creative people, the writers, the directors, the producers, the opposition and our own backbench—that we must at all costs retain the ability, to put it in its simplest terms, to deliver Australian stories, with Australian voices, on Australian free-to-air television and radio and at the same time maintain a structure in this country so that the people who work in those industries have the ability, between major projects, to get work in the advertising industry. That was a critical element that is often overlooked in what we achieved in this—that we achieved the same reservation on the 80 per cent local content rules on commercial advertisements on free-to-air television. As for maintaining the 55 per cent local content rules on free-to-air television, whether on an analog platform or moving to a digital platform, that has been done, achieved, reserved in this agreement. What about the reservation by value of Australian local content on pay TV—which was 10 per cent and we got a variation in there that we can move it up to 20 per cent, plus subquota sectors? It is done, agreed, in the agreement.

There was the sensitive issue of future media—some aspects and platforms that we do not even know exist yet but that we know will be developed as the technology develops. How can you codify or prescribe a reservation in that area? In the agreement there is a reservation that says that if an Australian government believes that Australian culture is unnecessarily being excluded from future media it reserves the right to intervene. We have the ability to intervene and put local content rules in the area of new electronic media beyond that which we know today. So there is no question that we have protected our ability to maintain acceptable levels of local content on free-to-air television and radio in the Australian system as part of the reservations that we have negotiated in this agreement.

I go back to my earlier point. When we embarked upon this negotiation we knew it was going to be tough, because prior to this there had only ever been two negotiated agreements between highly developed and competitive economies such as the United States and Australia. One was between Australia and New Zealand—the CER agreement that was negotiated over 20 years ago. The other was NAFTA, between the United States and Canada. We knew how tough they were to negotiate. This was going to be much more difficult, not just because we were going to be negotiating traditional areas of trade in commodities and manufactured goods—and even new areas like services and government procurement—but because we were going to get into the technology sector. We knew that it was going to be very difficult in the technology sector and that we had to defend the position in particular areas. We maintain that we absolutely have, in the interests of our nation. We knew that we were going to have to prosecute a position in areas that we wanted to gain extra access in—that is, the manufactured goods, services, government procurement and agricultural commodities sectors. At the end of that, our responsibility as a government, given this opportunity, was to make a decision whether overall, on balance, the deal was in the national interest.

One revelation that we have seen this week—notwithstanding the qualifications from the Leader of the Opposition—is that the Labor Party and the Leader of the Opposition have now acknowledged, and in their press release have listed, a whole page full of reasons why the Australia-United States free trade agreement is in the national interest. We welcome that. We welcome that support and commitment to the national interest, not just for Australians living today who want to do business with America but for future generations for decades to come, because of the economic benefit that will flow from this agreement in the future.

So we come down to a couple of very narrow, very important issues. We are not disputing that they are very important issues, but they are issues that we have dealt with in this negotiation. We have protected the national interest on these issues. We have protected Australia's ability to maintain local content rules on free-to-air television, as we said we would. We have protected the structure, the sustainability and the viability of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, as we said we would before I left Australia to negotiate this agreement. We say today—

talk.start.para: —What about sugar?
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Corio!
—We know what you've said on sugar.
—The member for Corio!
—that the premise on which this MPI is being raised is a false one, because the Australian patents system is totally different from that which exists in the United States. (Time expired)
—You've betrayed a whole industry.
—The member for Corio is warned!

—We have just heard a lot of dodgy detail about patent law, but we have not heard anything that would give us the clear truth. It is all designed to cloud the issue, and the issue is whether or not the government is prepared to stand up for the PBS. It is a simple issue. Let me explain it to you, Minister, because you clearly do not understand. It is a simple issue. Over the last few days we have watched the Prime Minister squirm and flip and flop because he does not know what to do in the face of Labor's proposal that we had better protect the PBS. Yesterday he said, the first time around, `We'll have a look at it,' then by the middle of question time he had ruled it out. By the end of the day he had had a cabinet meeting to rule it out. All of yesterday our proposal was `unnecessary'. Overnight it turned into `unworkable'. We have had three different versions today of why our proposal is unworkable, yet not one minister has come in here—not in question time and not in this MPI—to actually work through the issues. I am going to do that for you now, Minister, and I think you are going to learn something. You must get to breathe some rarefied air at those trade summits—some rarefied air, some clear water and the occasional glass of chardonnay at the end of a long day negotiating. But let me explain to you something about the real world.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Lalor will address her remarks through the chair.

—I am just explaining to the minister something about the real world, because I think he has been away from it for too long. Minister, why do you think that the drug companies and the American negotiators wanted a notification regime in the FTA? The patent holders wanted a regime where they would get a notice from someone who is going off to manufacture a generic. Why do you think they wanted that notice—because they have a big filing cabinet marked N for notifications and they are just going to pop it in there and wait for the next one? Is that why you think they wanted the notice? Do you think they have a lot of uncovered walls that they cannot afford to buy wallpaper for and they are going to put it up there? Is that why they wanted the notice?
—Get to the next point.

—I am coming to that. Let me just help the House right through all of the steps. They probably wanted the notice for a purpose. I do not think that they have lots of vacant filing cabinet space and I do not think they have lots of uncovered walls. They wanted the notice for a purpose, and that was to tell them that someone was going into the market with a generic.

speech.para: We are of course talking about drug companies whose profits are very valuable. I used an example in question time today. I picked one example—I could have picked a hundred others. In picking that example, I certainly was not ascribing a particular course of conduct to that drug manufacturer; I was just trying to give people an order of magnitude. Imagine I am the head of a company that manufactures a drug on the PBS that earned me $300 million last year, and I get a notice that someone is going to manufacture a generic. What do you think I am going to do? Am I going to say, `Oops, I lost $300 million—oh well, too bad'?

talk.start.para: —I am coming to the difference between the laws in Australia and the laws in America.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—If the member for Lalor and the minister want to have a conversation, they can go outside and have a conversation. Address your remarks through the chair!

—If I do not manage to explain all this to the minister in this time, I am happy to continue the conversation with him; but let me keep explaining. If I were manufacturing a $300 million a year patented drug and I got a notification that someone was going to put a generic on the market, do you know what I would do? I would call the lawyers. Call me crazy, but I would call a lawyer. Then I would probably call an accountant, too. I would say: `Guys, I don't care what it takes; I don't care what it costs. I want something that is going to hold this up. As long as you spend less than $300 million a year, it is worth it to me to do it.' I would get the best team of lawyers I could possibly buy and I would say, `Cook up anything to get me more time selling my patented drug in the market.'

speech.para: Do you know what they would do? They would cook up something. They would cook up some new patent applications; that is what they would cook up. Then they would cook up a legal proceeding based on the new patent application. They might well do that in the certain knowledge that they were going to lose, but they would cook up a legal strategy. In that legal strategy, they would cook up a few injunctions and then they would cook up a few delays. As the holder of the patent, as long as I am getting more time to sell my drug, it is necessarily worth it to me to use that strategy.

The minister is going to say—and I am sure Dr Southcott, whom he is advising now, is going to appreciate the assistance—`Oops, that can't happen in Australia. Deary me, that has never been known to happen in Australia.' But, Minister, let me get out a High Court case where it did happen. This was not one where the patent holder got notification, because that is not our current law. This is one where a generic was out in the market. That was Alphapharm's generic drug called Maxor. They launched that in Australia in May 1999. It was a generic that was based on the patented drug called Losec. They did not have to give notice to the patent holder; they put the generic into the market and they started selling. Then the patent holder of Losec decided it would embark on some legal action.

talk.start.para: —Wait for it! It decided to embark on some legal action in pursuit of a newly created patent about the design of the pellet, not about the pharmacologically active agent. No, they actually came up with a new patent regime as to whether it was a tablet or a pellet. They went to a trial judge and looked for an injunction. The trial judge said to them, `That does not look a very strong case to me.' They then managed to appeal and appeal and appeal, and they actually got a majority High Court ruling on their side.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Hunter is warned!

—This is in a regime where the generic manufacturer did not have to give the patent holder notice; the generic manufacturer actually got to go into the market first. So the simple proposition—the one that apparently the whole Howard government, from the Prime Minister down, is incapable of understanding—is that, if you are the holder of a valuable patent and you get notice that someone is going into the market in competition against you, you will probably try some novel and innovative legal strategies to protect yourself. It is a simple proposition. Anybody you stopped in the street outside would manage to understand it after a minute's explanation. No-one in the Howard government is capable of understanding that simple proposition—not one of them.

speech.para: What Labor is saying is: let us send a different price signal to the holder of the patent. Let us say to the holder of the patent: `If you actually embark on filing spurious, dodgy patent claims as part of a strategy cooked up with your lawyers to keep the generic out of the market and to keep you selling your patented drug and earning money, we are going to fine you a lot of money. We are going to fine you so much money that, when you do the maths on day one and you ask yourself whether it is worth ringing the lawyers, getting the crack accountants on it, filing the new patent, taking legal action and copping the penalty, the maths is going to come out that it is not worth you doing that.' That is what Labor's proposed amendment is.

I do not need the Minister for Trade, the Minister for Health and Ageing or the Prime Minister to believe that this is going to happen every second day; it is bad enough if it happens once. If this stops it once then it could have stopped a situation that would have cost Australian taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars. When drugs come off patent, that is what is involved: hundreds of millions of dollars. Two classes of drugs—two big classes—are coming off patent in the next four years: statins, which are about cholesterol, and serotonins, which are an antidepressive medication. The estimated savings from those two alone are $900 million. You do not really need to have it happen many times before a government—and taxpayers—can be hundreds of millions of dollars down, and that threatens the PBS.

It is the simplest series of propositions. If you actually cared about the PBS—if you cared about the merits of the issue instead of the cheapjack politics—then you would say to Labor, `Let's sit down and work out the text of the amendment and we will pass it.' That is what we are asking the Prime Minister to do. The Prime Minister is always full of advice for others. He has spent many weeks giving the Labor Party advice on the FTA. I would like to give him some back: Prime Minister, call this one for Australia. You advised Mark Latham to do that time after time. It is time the Prime Minister did it himself. If he calls this one for Australia then he will work with Labor to amend and better protect our PBS. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the member for Lalor, has a fairly unique record on the Australia-US Free Trade Agreement legislation: in the House she voted for it; in the shadow ministry she opposed it; in the Labor Party caucus meeting she was locked into the proposition that is before us now, which is passage of the free trade agreement with two amendments. The outcome of the negotiations was known to us in the early hours of 9 February and we now are in August: it has taken six months to find out where the Labor Party stands on this free trade agreement.

speech.para: I have to confess that I held the view they would look at either further delay or renegotiation. But I just knew that, when it came to the proposition of a yes or no vote, the Labor Party would never be able to hang together on the free trade agreement. When the three Independents and the Green member forced a division on the free trade agreement in the House of Representatives, we saw 14 Labor members cross the floor and vote for the free trade agreement with the government and 42 members of the Labor Party walk out the door. So there were three members for every one member who voted for it. We know that some Labor senators will never be able to vote for this agreement, and the amendments need to be dealt with separately. But the amendments do nothing to what was negotiated back in February.

The central proposition run by the Labor Party for six months was that Australia—through Mark Vaile and Stephen Deady—had not negotiated a good deal for Australia. Their central proposition presumably was that the Labor Party's standing in the United States is so high and their negotiator, Senator Conroy, is such a good negotiator that he would have got much better access and been much more successful in defending the offensive claims of the United States. That is laughable; that is absolutely laughable.

The parliament has had a Joint Standing Committee on Treaties since 1996, and this committee has looked at all treaties that have been signed by Australia in that period; we did not have a treaties committee prior to that date. So, as a matter of course, the free trade agreement with the United States was referred to the treaties committee. We had a threemonth inquiry. We received 215 submissions and we held 11 days of public hearings in seven cities around Australia.

There are sixteen members of the treaties committee; there are six members of the Labor Party on the treaties committee; there are three Labor senators on the treaties committee: Senators Marshall, Kirk and Stevens. There are as many Labor senators on the treaties committee as there are on the Senate select committee on the free trade agreement. But the problem that the Labor Party had with this committee was that it was government dominated—nine government members, one Democrat member and six Labor Party members—so we had to have a Senate select committee. The Senate select committee was set up by a vote of the Senate on 11 February. It was proposed initially that it would take three months to report; in the end it took six months. It missed its deadline twice. It did not really commence work until May. But as Sir Humphrey Appleby advised his minister, never establish a committee until you know the outcome. This was advice that the Labor Party took to heart: they only trusted a committee which was originally constituted by five non-government members and two government members to give them the answer they wanted. It descended into high farce over the weekend when we had Labor senators on the committee saying they were awaiting direction from the caucus and the caucus waiting for six months saying they were awaiting direction from the senators on the committee.

This week, we know, was judgment day; it was Labor coming to judgment day on the free trade agreement. According to the commentary, depending on whether you talk to a member of the left or a member of the right, there are two views as to what has been agreed. So the Labor Party, in continuing to paper over the divisions that exist within it on this issue, have come up with two amendments. One is an amendment that the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties—the committee which the Labor Party never trusted to give it a fair hearing—came up with. It is a very simple amendment: instead of the ABA being responsible for and able to change the local content rules—as has been the case since 1992—local content rules can only be changed by a deliberative decision of the parliament. That is a sensible recommendation. It does nothing to change the intent of the free trade agreement and it is certainly within the spirit of the text.

We made that recommendation because of the ratchet provision, but I have to inform members that it is only measures in annex 1 of the cultural material which are subject to a ratchet provision. That means it is only for free-to-air commercial television for both analog and digital broadcasting but on a single channel and it includes the 55 per cent quota and the 80 per cent quota for advertising. But the other annex 2 issues—multichanneling, subscription television, commercial radio broadcasting and interactive audio and video services—are not subject to a ratchet provision at all. The Labor amendment, I think, is a worthy amendment, but we had actually come up with it five weeks ago and so there was no need to wait another five weeks while we had a Senate select committee. This amendment does nothing but preserve the negotiating position of Mark Vaile and the Australian negotiators, which is to keep the 55 per cent for local content and the 80 per cent for advertising.

We also had evidence on the patent stuff. There were concerns raised by different groups, including the Australasian Society for HIV Medicine and the National Association of People Living with HIV-AIDS. Their main concern was that we would adopt the American practices. Australian patent law is remaining basically the same, and the view of the committee—and the Labor members of the committee—was:

quote.para: The Committee accepts however that the situation in Australia will be different due to our different legal and regulatory environment ...

speech.para: We understood the concerns, but we did not believe that, due to the different ways that the Patents Act operates, we would see the process of evergreening. We all know that evergreening occurs in the United States, but it does not mean that because we have signed the free trade agreement we are going to adopt evergreening. That just does not follow. There are all sorts of things in the American legal system, such as the right to bear arms, presidential term limits and so on, that we do not have in Australia. Signing the free trade agreement does not mean we are going to adopt them. Very simply, to apply for a patent in Australia you apply to IP Australia. The length of a patent is 20 plus five years. There are provisional patents in both the United States and Australia, but the difference is that in Australia provisional patents do not acquire legal rights; they do in the United States. We have not seen evergreening in Australia.

The big question for the Labor Party is: will they block the free trade agreement based on an amendment which is unnecessary and which was not the central issue that was raised over the last six months? In the speech from the shadow minister for health and in the questions from the Leader of the Opposition did we hear one thing about the review process for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme? Did we hear one thing about the review process for the PBAC? This is an admission by the Labor Party that pharmaceutical prices on the PBS will not rise. It is because the review process that we outlined in our discussion paper which was released by the minister for health on 25 July is fair—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak to the Leader of the Opposition's MPI regarding the government's failure to adequately protect the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and Australia's cultural content rules in its free trade agreement enabling legislation. There is no doubt that the enabling legislation is a dud. Why? It is because the FTA itself is a dud. But what we are seeing here today with this MPI is nothing more than a piece of Labor politicking. The Leader of the Opposition is trying to dig himself out of a hole—the hole that he dug himself into when he turned his back on Australian workers and our national interest by supporting the Prime Minister's free trade agreement with the United States.

speech.para: Rather than taking a principled stand against the free trade agreement, which, as I told the House on 24 June, delivers very little to Australia in real terms, the ALP is now tinkering around with amendments which expert advice tells us serve no purpose. For example, we are talking about patents and evergreening. What about the bigger issues—the central issues regarding this FTA? Did the opposition members miss the PM program last night? Professor Peter Drahos from the Australian National University was interviewed on it, and he had some things to say about Labor's amendments to the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Bill 2004 and about other changes. He said:

quote.para: While I think the proposals are well intentioned, ultimately they don't really achieve the objective of protecting the PBS. What really matters is the text in the actual agreement. That is what a free trade panel deciding our obligations under the act will look at.
That's what will ultimately govern a dispute resolution process, not the implementing legislation the Labor Party dream up.

They will look at the implementing legislation and they say, “does this implementing legislation fulfil the obligations that Australia agreed to when they signed the agreement?” and if there is a gap between what we've implemented and what we've agreed to in the text, then it is the text that has priority.
It's like entering into a contract. We've entered into a contract with the United States and that's the contract that will determine whether or not we've fulfilled our obligations.

The multinationals, that are really the architects of this free trade agreement, will look at our implementing legislation and they will ask themselves, “are the Australians complying? Are they doing what they have undertaken to do in the free trade agreement?”
And if they come to the conclusion that we haven't complied, then they will take us to court or the equivalent of a court, namely the dispute resolution process that is in the free trade agreement.

The whole point of this agreement is to obtain higher prices to deal with the domestic crises in the United States, to deal with the fact that PBS represents world's best practice for Australia producing cheaper medicines. That is the entire point of this.

speech.para: Labor's amendments and the government changes count for very little if that expert analysis is correct—and I believe it is. The reality is that any amendment to this agreement—whether it be on manufacturing jobs, pharmaceuticals, the environment or the proper transparencies and processes overlooking this legislation—coming into this place cannot be inserted into the free trade agreement, because it is signed outside the parliament. It is an agreement between Mr Howard and President Bush. It is extramural. It is outside the reach of this parliament.

Labor has two amendments here which are at the margins and are acceptable, it says, within the free trade agreement. It dare not move outside the free trade agreement, for it cannot. You accept it or reject it. Labor accepts this. The Greens reject it because we do not believe it is in the national interest. The FTA is a dud. Everyone accepts that there are negatives—for example, the loss of up to 50,000 jobs in the manufacturing industry—but there should be no negatives. There are so many problems with this so-called free trade agreement that the opposition should have rejected it outright, just as the government should have pulled the plug when it realised that Australians would be worse off as a result of this agreement.

There is nothing free about this agreement. It is a restricted, pointed, biased agreement which favours our giant but friendly neighbour across the ocean—the United States—against the interests of this nation. The Greens oppose the legislation because it is not in Australia's national interest—although it is in the interests of the United States and, in particular, the corporate sector in the United States, which stands to gain the most from it. The agreement binds not only many of the processes in our society but also this parliament. It does so in a way that is out of the reach of this parliament because, once the parliament gives assent to this agreement, changing it becomes conditional on the American interest being fostered. If you do not have that, it will not be changed in the future. Being able to alter the agreement will be out of the question unless the American interest is served. The only option would be to repudiate it further down the line. That of course is unconscionable when the option now is to repudiate it before it comes into force, with many fewer consequences for this nation—a nation which has an economy and population less than one-tenth the size of those of the United States.

It is very important to understand that the agreement is outside the reach of our democracy in both its formulation and its future impact on this country. This agreement is not subject to parliamentary scrutiny, it is not subject to parliamentary accountability and it is not subject to parliamentary alteration. It is another manifestation of the increasing wish by executive governments in this country—which has been refined and strengthened by the Howard government—to act as extra-parliamentary governing authorities that make decisions outside the ability of parliament to review and make alterations to in the future.

This agreement will help line the pockets of pharmaceutical corporations in the United States. It inevitably moves us a step towards the far inferior system of the United States, where the sick, the aged, the retired and the poor not only cannot afford many of the pharmaceuticals available but also, as we know, cannot access hospital care. That country is far worse served by the unrestrained market and the division between rich and poor than this country is.

As I said in this place on 24 June, the fact that our government is seeking to paint meagre concessions and horrendous potential damages as overall wins for Australia is at best naive and at worst anti-Australian. It is clear that the costs of this deal will dramatically outweigh the benefits and cause irreversible damage to our economy, to our major national institutions and to our enviable status as a disease-free producer. That is why this so-called free trade agreement should be rejected—not amended in the Senate as Labor proposes, but rejected outright for the outrageous sham that it is. This FTA threatens jobs, it threatens our industries, it threatens our health care system, it threatens our environment and it threatens our culture and our cultural heritage.

It is easy to understand why the Prime Minister pursued this agreement with his good mate George Bush, but it is not so easy to explain the dodgy decision by the opposition to cave in yet again. The public will undoubtedly judge both harshly whenever the next election is held. However, you can rest assured that the Greens will continue to stand up for ordinary Australians and defend Australia's national interests.
