talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hotham has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

—I had the opportunity prior to question time today to address and reply to some of the issues that were put forward with regard to the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 by the shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham. It is in fact quite laughable, as I stated at the outset of my contribution, that the party that comes into this chamber and claims to be a friend of small business is the Australian Labor Party. What is laughable about it is that the Australian Labor Party is the party that is proposing to introduce a 0.1 per cent federal payroll tax on businesses—a direct way in which the federal Labor Party will remove the incentive for businesses to hire new employees. There is a reason why under the Howard government we have seen record low levels of unemployment. If the Labor Party were elected you would see a situation arise whereby unemployment rates would start to go back up—as they always do under the Australian Labor Party.

speech.para: But the main thrust of today's debate is amendments to the Trade Practices Act. There is a whole array of them contained in this bill today. This bill largely comes about as a consequence of a review of the competition provisions of the Trade Practices Act that was chaired by Sir Daryl Dawson, commonly known as the Dawson review. The Dawson review was the most comprehensive review of the competition provisions in the act for more than a decade.

The reality is that both sides of the chamber recognise the inherent benefits that flow from a competitive marketplace. Both sides of the chamber recognise the inherent benefits that flow to the Australian people as a consequence of the dynamic and temporal efficiencies that arise out of a more competitive marketplace. I acknowledge that in the past the Australian Labor Party certainly has been one to engage in microeconomic reform, recognising that there are dividends that all Australians can enjoy as a consequence of, for example, deregulating the dollar, introducing the Trade Practices Act and so on and so forth.

But the difference today is that this bill before the House is a recognition by the Howard government—and in particular by the Treasurer, Peter Costello—that in fact significant benefits would flow from the implementation of a number of the recommendations that were put forward by Sir Daryl Dawson in the Dawson review. The overall theme of the Dawson review was that the competition provisions should protect the competitive process rather than particular competitors. The government strongly supports this view of the act and has accepted in fact—despite contrary claims by the member for Hotham—the vast majority of the Dawson review recommendations.

The bill before the House today will improve existing ACCC processes by providing for greater accountability, greater transparency and more timeliness in decision making, as well as reducing the regulatory burden on businesses that have in the past flowed not only from this act but also from other acts. Businesses both big and small, as well as consumers, will benefit from the new streamlined processes incorporated in the bill, which will be to the advantage of the whole economy.

I will touch upon some of the key processes and key reforms that are contained within the bill before the chamber today. A new voluntary formal merger clearance process will be put in place to operate in parallel with the informal clearance system. This will provide definite time limits for consideration which business can rely upon and will provide the certainty that a clearance is legally binding. The bill provides that merger authorisation applications will be considered directly by the tribunal instead of by the ACCC. This will ensure commercially realistic time frames for such applications and prevent strategic appeals by third parties. Likewise, with regard to non-merger authorisations, there will be strict time limits for consideration by the ACCC. Of particular advantage to small business, the ACCC will be able to waive the filing fee.

I will highlight some of the comments that were made by the shadow Treasurer with regard to these particular points. The shadow Treasurer raised concerns about the tribunal and the actual process contained in the bill before the House today. The reality is that there are benefits that flow. Principal among them, and contrary to the concerns that were raised by the shadow Treasurer, is the fact that there will now be an opportunity for tribunals to hear arguments with regard to public interest when it comes to merger considerations. That is not a negative. There are examples that exist where concentration ratios in a marketplace may in fact be breached but it could very conceivably be in the public interest for such a merger to go ahead. Why not allow the legal arguments surrounding those discussions to be put forward, considered and taken into account?

Similarly, with regard to the public interest, why not allow public interest to be a principal consideration when it comes to determining whether a merger should be allowed to go forward? The shadow Treasurer claimed that the tribunal scares the ALP, that the establishment of the tribunal raises concerns among ALP members and that this is all about providing an opportunity for the Howard government to give kudos and benefits only to the big business sector. It is simply not there in the legislation. Contrary to the scaremongering campaign of the Australian Labor Party, the legislation shows that the new process will allow for public interest to be a factor when it comes to consideration of merger activity.

For the opposition to claim, perhaps implicitly, that there are no circumstances in which a concentration ratio may be breached—for example, in a market through a merger—and that that could in some way not be in the public interest would be to deny the existence of the argument of national champions. Certainly many leading advocates in the debate about competition and the best use of market forces contend that there is a role for national champions and that consumers can actually win by having national champions. It would seem to me that that notion of national champions runs entirely inconsistently with arguments that we heard from the Australian Labor Party this morning.

This bill introduces the notion of collective bargaining and reduces the regulatory burden on small business through the introduction of a notification process that allows for collective bargaining by small businesses when dealing with large businesses. This provides an alternative to the authorisation process. Fundamentally, the Howard government does believe that there are benefits that flow from collective bargaining and realises that there can at times be situations where small businesses are at a distinct market disadvantage compared to a larger counterpart that small businesses are needing to negotiate and deal with in a marketplace. The introduction of the notification process for collective bargaining by small businesses is, I know, certainly most welcome. I know the Newsagents Federation, to give one example, would warmly welcome this kind of change.

Third line forcing is another reform that is being introduced in this bill. There is recognition—and the Dawson review highlighted this—that there are in fact procompetitive benefits that flow as a consequence of third line forcing arrangements. The test that will be used for third line forcing will be a substantial lessening of the competition test, instead of a per se prohibition with regard to third line forcing. This will make third line forcing consistent with other forms of exclusive dealings as contained in part 4 of the Trade Practices Act.

With regard to exclusionary provisions, price fixing and joint ventures, serious cartel type conduct involving exclusionary and price fixing measures will continue to be prohibited outright. Genuine joint ventures will provide a defence on competition grounds. There are also minor changes with regard to dual listed companies which will see them treated on the same basis as other companies under the Trade Practices Act. There will also be extra powers available to the ACCC when it comes to enforcement. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will have a new ability to seize evidence, but this will be balanced against the requirement to obtain a warrant from a magistrate.

Importantly, there are changes made with regard to penalties, and I would like to touch on this in more detail. The bill provides for a higher penalty for a contravention of the act. It allows for persons to be disqualified from directing or managing a corporation and prohibits the indemnification of officers, employees and agents against the imposition of a pecuniary penalty. There are also reforms contained within the bill which go to the constitutional validity and application of the act to local government.

Earlier today I heard the shadow Treasurer raising a number of issues about the timing of the Dawson review and the Senate report. The allegation was made by the member for Hotham that the Australian government had in some way acted in breach of, or not consulted widely with the states and territories in accordance with, the requirements of the intergovernmental conduct code agreement of 11 June. The Australian government did in fact seek and receive support from the states and territories for the draft bill as required. As I said, that occurred on 11 June this year. The Dawson bill was introduced into this House on 24 June and is now being debated today and is proposed to be debated by the Senate tomorrow.

It should be noted that no state or territory voted no to the bill. Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania all voted yes, and the remainder of the states and territories, through not responding, have their default votes counted as being affirmative. This is in accordance with the intergovernmental conduct code agreement, which says that during the voting stage the Australian government must receive three votes from the states and territories before the expiry of 35 days in order to introduce the bill. If no vote is received, it is considered a default vote. This occurred with regard to a number of states.

But that is entirely separate from the situation that exists in relation to the Senate report and the recommendations put forward by the Senate inquiry. The government tabled its response to the Senate report on 23 June and on that date gave notice to the states and territories. Once the government response has been tabled there is a three-month consultation period which commences with the states and territories as per the conduct code agreement, during which time the bill can be drafted. After this, there is a 35-day voting period on a draft bill before it commences. This concludes on 23 September. I highlight that because I do not believe that the shadow Treasurer actually understood the two separate processes that exist, the two separate reports, and the government response to the two separate reports, one with the Dawson review and one with the changes that were contained in the Senate report.

There are a number of benefits that flow from the changes before the House today. Small business is one of the biggest beneficiaries. All business—and not least of all small businesses, of course—benefit from a strong competition regulator. The report of the Dawson inquiry has reinforced the importance of a vigorous and independent regulatory agency, in the form of the ACCC, to oversee promotion of competition in the Australian economy. I know that on the Gold Coast, the small business capital of Australia, there is in fact a great deal of regard for the operation of the Trade Practices Act and that there are so many who stand to benefit from the temporal and dynamic efficiencies that exist in marketplaces as a consequence of the operation of the Trade Practices Act. I am pleased to know that there are so many others in this chamber who share the view that there are many benefits that flow to small business as a consequence of this act.

I touched upon the issue of collective bargaining, and I want to highlight some of its key features. As a consequence of this bill, the proposed system will include a period of only 14 days, or a longer period if it is prescribed by regulation, which should be allowed to elapse before a notification takes effect. It is proposed that the period be set by regulation at 28 days, as this will give the commission sufficient time to consider notification applications in the initial stages of the amendment. However, the time period will be monitored and reviewed after 12 months, with a preference for 14 days being introduced.

There are also benefits for business through the non-merger authorisation process. In addition to the time limits that will be imposed upon the ACCC in relation to non-merger authorisation to improve the speed of the authorisation process, the ACCC will be provided with the discretion to waive fees for non-merger authorisation which would otherwise be payable. The consequence of these changes is that they will improve the accessibility and effectiveness of the authorisation process by reducing the time and cost involved in obtaining an authorisation.

Likewise, consumers will benefit. Consumers can share in the benefits that are expected to flow from the government's amendments that are aimed at strengthening the civil penalty regime in relation to anticompetitive conduct. The maximum pecuniary penalties for corporations will be increased to the greater of $10 million or three times the unlawful gain or, where the gain cannot be readily ascertained, 10 per cent of the turnover of the corporation. This represents a very significant disincentive to engaging in non-competitive conduct in a marketplace. Likewise, the court, on application from the ACCC, will be able to ban directors and managers from participating in the management of a corporation, and corporations will also be prohibited from indemnifying officers, employees or agents against the imposition of a pecuniary penalty. These are probably the three principal ways in which consumers will benefit, knowing that when it comes to management and directors of companies as well there will be enhanced consumer protection contained in the Trade Practices Act as a consequence of this bill.

The Trade Practices Act has served the Australian people well. That was the overall finding of the Dawson review and it is the finding of a number of parliamentary committees. It has served the Australian people well but, like any piece of legislation, it does require updating from time to time to ensure it remains both relevant and the best utility available to serve a dynamic and competitive marketplace that exists across so many industries in Australia today.

I am very pleased to speak to this bill and to support it. I am disappointed that the Australian Labor Party does not support this bill as a whole. It would have been of assistance if the shadow Treasurer had perhaps at the outset understood the difference between the government's response to the Senate report and the government's response to the Dawson report. But, nonetheless, I am still disappointed that the Australian Labor Party does not recognise all the benefits that flow and support this in total rather than seeking to divide the bill into two parts. It is a good bill. It benefits small businesses. It certainly benefits consumers and it ensures that businesses going forward in Australia continue to operate in a competitive environment and, more importantly, in an environment that will continue to promote competitiveness.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 and support the amendment put forward by the member for Hotham. It is a pleasure to follow the member for Moncrieff. I was in his electorate only last Friday, in beautiful Surfers Paradise, speaking at a petroleum retailers conference and putting forward Labor's plan to protect small and independent players in that market, which is unfortunately something that the member for Moncrieff and those on his side of the House are not prepared to do. That subject has great relevance to the debate before us today.

speech.para: I am not surprised that the member for Moncrieff spent about 90 per cent of his time talking about the merger provisions in this bill and only about 10 per cent of his time talking about issues that go to small business protection. That should not be surprising. This bill really only has two initiatives within it. One is something for small business, in terms of the collective bargaining provisions, and the other is something for big business in terms of the merger provisions. He waxed lyrical about the so-called `new public interest test'. But he must be reading a different bill from the one I am looking at, because the public interest test has been in the bill since the Labor government introduced it back in 1974. But what has changed is that the bill removes the right for third party participation, including the right of the ACCC to intervene in these matters. It is not an enhancement of the merger provisions; I would describe it as a retrograde step in terms of those merger provisions.

This should be very much a bill about competition and small business protection. It is interesting to note that the Howard government was elected in 1996 largely on the back of a number of commitments it made to the small business community. In 1992 and 1993 John Hewson scared the hell out of the small business community. As was the case with Medicare, John Howard, the then reincarnated opposition leader, found it necessary to put the collective minds of the small business community at rest on both Medicare and small business red tape and paperwork. He, now infamously, promised the small business community at that time that he would not introduce a GST and that he would cut red tape and paperwork for the small business community by some 50 per cent. It is on the record, and it is history now, that the Prime Minister later broke his promise on the introduction of the GST, and it is now farcical to suggest that compliance with red tape and paperwork for the small business community has been reduced since the Howard government came to office. That is why the government cut the small business longitudinal study. That five-year study—an important study for small business academics in determining good public policy for a range of small business issues—introduced by the former Keating government was in its final year, but unfortunately it ended with the cutting of that funding.

Small business lost the fight against the introduction of the GST because a GST was what the big end of town wanted. Under this government, what corporate Australia wants it gets, regardless of any adverse impact that its wish list has on the small business community. It was the same story when in this place we were discussing retail tenancy issues; it was the same story when in this place we were discussing the Ralph review of business taxation. When the New South Wales government wanted to draw down the provisions of 51AC into its own Retail Leases Act, the Howard government did all it could to frustrate and hold up the New South Wales minister's plan. When the Howard government is faced with a conflict between the big end of town and small business interests, it will back the big business interests every time, and that is what this bill is largely about. That is why the Reid committee's recommendations were never fully adopted, that is why the Baird committee's recommendations were never fully adopted, and that is why the Treasurer is not prepared to embrace all the recommendations of the Dawson review or the recommendations of the Senate committee.

The Dawson review and the Senate committee started a war of words between the small and the big business communities. It is a war which the government inevitably had to take sides on and the government came down on the side of big business, which comes as no surprise to those of us on this side of the House. When the Howard government is seeking advice on small business policy, it goes straight to the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Retailers Association, the CPAs or the Tourism and Transport Forum. The membership of these organisations comprises the nation's biggest and wealthiest companies. Further, when it is looking for endorsement for its policy approaches, it is organisations such as these that the government turns to. When it wants endorsement for its antiworker legislation, it turns to the BCA; when it wants endorsement for its position on trade practices reform, it turns to the BCA and the Australian Retailers Association; and when it wants endorsement for its tourism related small business policies, it turns to the Tourism and Transport Forum, representing the Macquarie Bank, Leightons, Multiplex, ABN AMRO, Southcorp, IBM, Emirates and Singapore Airlines, to name just a few. Any dissent from an organisation generally representing the voice of small business is stamped out by threats of retribution.

One of the first lessons learned by students of economics is that competition is a key ingredient for the fair and efficient operation of any market. Without competition, sellers can abuse their market power, which in turn has the dual effects of misallocating resources and disadvantaging consumers. To preserve competition you must have a strong competition law and you must have a regulator with teeth. Strong competition and a strong regulator are critical to competition and the survival of a vibrant small business sector. In recent years the competition reform that was commenced by the former Labor government has stalled and the ACCC has grown concerningly timid.

This bill is symbolic of the government's lack of will when it comes to trade practices reform. The Senate committee made 17 recommendations. The Dawson committee made 43 recommendations. I was in the House when the Treasurer introduced this bill, and you can imagine how shocked I was as I sat and listened to him read his second reading speech. I had high expectations, as had many in the small business community. I was waiting for the phrase `predatory pricing', but the words are yet to pass the Treasurer's lips—nor, of course, did I hear the phrase `section 46', the most important phrase the small business community in this country is waiting to hear. It reminded me about the fact that I regularly hear the Minister for Small Business and Tourism in this place answering dorothy dixers from his backbench during question time. Earlier today I counted them in the Hansard, and this year there have been about 17 dorothy dixers from the backbench to the Minister for Small Business and Tourism about small business matters. I particularly searched for any reference to him making reference to the words `predatory pricing'. I was able to find only one, and that was only a passing reference when answering a question. The reference was his indication that the Treasurer would soon be making some announcements on predatory pricing, but, of course, we are yet to hear any such announcement.

Any trade practices practitioner in this country or indeed any person with an interest in trade practices law and in particular how it affects small business is aware that, post Boral, section 46 of the Trade Practices Act is desperately in need of reform. Indeed, pre Boral, section 46 of the Trade Practices Act was desperately in need of reform. That is why throughout the course of the Reid committee and the Baird committee we were taking lots of evidence and having lots of debate about the merits or otherwise of changing to an effects test or changing the onus of proof under section 46 as a means of making that provision stronger and giving greater protection to the small business sector.

Section 46 prohibits corporations with a substantial degree of market power from using that power in an attempt to damage a competitor, drive a competitor out of the market or stop a competitor entering the market or engaging in competitive conduct. The Boral case brought the efficacy of section 46 so much into doubt that the ACCC at that time gave up on four section 46 cases, believing that pursuing them post the Boral decision was not likely to result in any real outcome in its favour.

The High Court's judgment in Boral was handed down some 18 months ago. For 18 months small business has been without adequate protection from market power abuse and the ACCC has not had at its disposal an effective tool for dealing with abuse of market power. I thought, understandably, that when this bill was introduced on 24 June this year we were about to see that situation remedied and rectified, but we were all disappointed, and we remain disappointed.

This bill contains just one thing, as I said, for small business, and that is collective bargaining, although that is flawed—if I get time, I will return to that subject—and something for big business, in their eyes at least, in terms of improving the mergers provisions. It gives small business collective bargaining but it gives big business something on mergers. It contains nothing on section 46, as I have discussed extensively; nothing on predatory pricing in particular; nothing on creeping acquisitions; nothing to enhance the provisions of section 51AC; nothing on cease and desist orders; and no jail penalties for corporate players engaged in cartel type behaviour. These are all matters that Labor is committed to, but they all are matters that get no mention within the context of this bill.

The government, I suspect, will seek to reassure us that this is only tranche 1—that all these other matters that I have mentioned, all of those other matters that Dawson raised as concerns and all those other issues that the Senate committee raised as concerns will be found in tranche 2. To that we can only say, `We hope so.' But we are also entitled to ask the question: `When?' We are leading into an election—probably, I suspect, in mid-October. Some will have a different view, but it is certainly not going to happen before then. By the time we go through the course of an election campaign, even if the government is re-elected we are not likely to see tranche 2 this side of Christmas.

Of course, if Labor is elected we would hope more urgency would be shown and Labor could put its policy into place. There is a big chance at least that we will not see tranche 2—if there is to be a tranche 2—this side of Christmas. For 18 months already small business has been without adequate protection, and it looks like it is going to be at least another six months—and, taking into account Christmas, probably even longer—before we can hope to get anything out of the government. So one question is that of timing. The next question is: what are we going to get when we finally see tranche 2? Are we going to get that list of important issues I just mentioned? Specifically, what are we going to get on predatory pricing? Are we going to get the Senate committee majority recommendation or the minority recommendation put forward by government senators Brandis and Chapman?

Senator Brandis puts himself out as a bit of an expert on the Trade Practices Act, but the reality is that Senator Brandis's proposition on predatory pricing will take us back to square one. What Senator Brandis wants to do is require the ACCC to prove that recoupment is possible in the case of predatory pricing. Boral was about the ACCC, in the first instance, being able to show that a player had a substantial degree of market power, and the High Court proved that that is a difficult test to meet. Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I put to you that proving that a player is capable of recoupment will be just as difficult as was proving that a player in a market had a substantial degree of market power.

In the few minutes left to me I want to make a few points about the specific sections of the bill put forward to us today. One, on collective bargaining the initial contract concept is flawed. The government should simply permit notification for conduct covered by section 45. That would be in line with the current law and process on notifications. Two, it should be clear that the parties to any collective bargaining arrangement can have an agent and that the agent can act for more than one notifying group in the same industry or any other industry. Three, the act needs to say that when the ACCC is considering a notification it should take into account that collective bargaining is a public benefit because of the list of benefits outlined in the ACCC draft guideline on collective bargaining. This list should be spelt out in the legislation. Four, the legislation should be clear that the onus of whether or not a notice is rejected is on the ACCC. The ACCC should not be able to put information demands on parties making application which effectively reverse the onus of proof. Five, the $3 million transaction threshold should largely mirror what is in section 51AC and hence be raised to $10 million. There is a strong case for having no threshold at all. None exists, for example, for the authorisation process. Six, the ACCC should not be able to insist on small bargaining groups. Bargaining groups should be and can be national, state or territory based or even regional, depending on the market in which the target operates. The legislation should state that bargaining groups can be national et cetera.

I ask the minister, the Treasurer or whoever is doing the summing up to answer those concerns that I have expressed on the collective bargaining provisions within this bill. I think the omission of those suggestions that I have put forward are deliberate omissions and are designed to undermine the effectiveness of collective bargaining for small business. Lastly, on detail, whilst I think I know why the third line forcing provisions are in there, they are unnecessary. It is another undermining of the Trade Practices Act. It is another example of the undermining of the effectiveness of the Trade Practices Act in protecting both small business and, of course, the Australian consumer. So I ask the minister when he sums up to answer those questions I have raised on collective bargaining.

In summary, I just say that this is very disappointing. Eighteen months post Boral, after two extensive inquiries and with plenty of examples of the issues facing the small business community and, indeed, consumers, here we are with a bill which has something for big business and a little something for small business but still nothing on all of the key concerns raised in both of those inquiries all that time ago. Here we are, leading into an election and into Christmas and it looks like, no matter who is in government, because of the timing of these things and the time taken by the election et cetera, small business is facing the possibility that, if there are to be further reforms to the Trade Practices Act in their favour, it is possibly going to be 2005 before they see them. That is unacceptable. None of us who have watched this government in action over the course of the last 8½ years should be surprised. When it comes down to the rights and interests of the big end of town as opposed to small business interests, this government will fall to the side of the big end of town every time. I think this bill demonstrates that again here today.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham, and the remarks made by my colleague the member for Hunter on the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. They both spoke so comprehensively that I should be able to make a contribution that supports their position without taking the full quota of time, thus facilitating the business of the parliament. Yesterday we were in the parliament debating a very disappointing set of propositions from the government about assisting small business to cope with the red-tape crisis of the GST and the business activity statement. It was too little too late. It was disappointing and the very least they could do to give themselves a fig leaf to cover the embarrassment of failing to act. Yesterday what we saw was a very small fig leaf and a very large embarrassment.

speech.para: We have the same situation today. These changes are trumpeted as ostensibly being part of the government's reform agenda to assist small business. But the government have been slow to act. They have acted without commitment. They have left the small business community understandably disappointed. It is a minimalist approach. The minimalist movement in art had a lot to recommend it, but, as a way of reforming the Trade Practices Act and acting in defence of small business, it is a terribly disappointing approach. You wonder why, because, in the normal course, the government have seen the small business community as their core constituency. They have trumpeted their concern for it. They have campaigned to it and sold their message to it. Yet, when the small business community comes to them for support, the government are missing in action.

Why is that? It is because, for the first time, it has become clear that the 21st century challenge for government in assisting small business is in assisting small business to cope with unfair competition from big business. Suddenly the government have gone to water. The only voice they have listened to with regard to this matter is the Business Council of Australia, as advocates of the big business interest, and it has driven the government back. First, they had an intention of doing absolutely nothing, then they set up the Dawson review with the intention of doing as little as possible and then, when the Senate committee was imposed upon them, they sought to constrain significantly its recommendations. Now they have sought to recommend none of it in this legislation when some of it was possible. They know they have bipartisan support for some of those reforms.

Some of the reforms need consultation with the states. We understand that. They cannot legislate to do those things without that consultation. But they have the support of the states, and they know that, if they wished to, they could expedite that. The act sets a time that has to be set aside for consultation but, if they wanted to change it more quickly and went to consult with the states proactively, they would get support because the states have been calling for those reforms. The only people who will not act are the Howard government. They will not act because it does not reflect the interests of the people they actually see as their primary constituency—that is, big business in Australia. They will not act and small business is understandably disappointed at the government being so slow and so weak and having no serious reform agenda.

Seriously, for the economy as a whole, they are weak on competition policy. Australia needs a new round of productivity boost that comes from enhanced competition. We have had rounds of competition in the past engendered by previous Labor governments in the reduction of tariffs, the opening up of the economy, the floating of the dollar and the liberalisation of the banking system. In the National Competition Policy we blew the winds of competition through the fusty corridors of the Australian economy, which had been ossifying for generations. Now we need another round, and the government are found wanting again. When the current Prime Minister was Treasurer, he failed to implement the necessary competition reforms. As Prime Minister he has done nothing.

Mark Latham, the Leader of the Opposition, has outlined a seven-point plan to deal with the abuse of market power and to amend the Trade Practices Act to allow small businesses to be effectively competitive with their bigger competitors, to have a fair go, to drive reform, innovation and competition and therefore economic success. But this is a government that is absolutely bereft of new ideas. When was the last time this government came forward with an original major idea or reform? I ask this question at forums all around the country: what was the last new idea that the government came forward with? Most people say the GST. Whether that was a major reform or not, and I suspect that history will say it was not, it was six years ago that we went to an election about that idea. It was actually first articulated more than 10 years ago, but it was articulated by the government seven years ago. There has not been a major economic reform in seven years, and there will not be any until there is a change of government.

As the member for Hotham and the member for Hunter have outlined, we do support the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004, because it includes measures to make collective bargaining easier and cheaper for small business, and that should happen. It is overdue. The Dawson report came in so long ago that it is amazing that that has not happened so far. Although all too little and too late, there are measures in the bill which, despite some inadequacies, queried and properly raised by the member for Hunter, will nevertheless provide the only collective bargaining the government is going to allow for small business. So we will support that part of the legislation.

But we do want to see more done. We want to drive the government to meet the cries for help from the small business community. It can do that by supporting the ACCC and by making changes to the Trade Practices Act so it can become an effective, functioning force for competition reform and for enhancing the role of small business. Professor Fels was an outspoken advocate of the need to reform the Trade Practices Act, and the government did nothing. Even the more cautious Mr Samuel, who was Mr Costello's chosen Chairman of the ACCC—and for whose appointment Mr Costello battled so hard—says that the Trade Practices Act is not strong enough to give small business a fair go. But the Treasurer is not listening.

This bill is running way behind the views of the small business constituency, and I find that even more the case—and I see the member for Kennedy in the chamber—in regional Australia. In the small business communities in country towns and regional cities—Nowra, for instance, which I went to not long ago—around Australia and in the smaller capital cities such as Darwin, where I was discussing this recently, we find even more awareness that small business is finding it harder and harder to compete with the growing dominance of a small number of large companies. We have a trend to duopoly in so many areas, and it is making it harder and harder, particularly in smaller towns and the smaller regional cities. It is hard enough in Sydney and Melbourne, but the smaller the city the harder the task is for the small business community. The government is made up of the Liberal Party, which purports to represent small business, and The Nationals, which purports to represent regional interests. Yet regional small business is suffering and the government will not act. It will not act, because those who pull the strings will not let it.

Those aspects of a very strong Senate report that would place small business on a fairer footing have been left out of this bill. My colleagues have outlined this, and I have outlined this in speeches before. I simply reiterate now that we can give a commitment to Australian small business that, if the government changes after the election, the law as it relates to the interests of small business in competition with their larger competitors, suppliers and customers will change so that small business will get the reforms recommended by the majority Senate Economics References Committee report into the role of the Trade Practices Act in protecting small business. We will make those changes. We need another package of reform. This government is incapable of delivering it; we will do so after the next election. It is an inevitable change. It must happen. It needs to happen. The economy needs it, small business needs it, regional Australia needs it, and only a Labor government will deliver it.

My colleagues have spoken about some concerns about the merger provisions. I speak in this debate as the shadow minister for small business. The merger provisions are the area of my colleague the shadow Treasurer, but I have heard his advocacy and share his view that we have serious concerns about that. We do not want to be defenders of the status quo just for the sake of it, so let us have a careful look at this part of the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill. Send it off to the Senate committee but do not hold up the collective bargaining provisions for it. I say to the government: I know we are getting close to the election and there are political stunts about all sorts of legislation, but do not hold up the collective bargaining provisions, do not hold them hostage to concerns about the merger provisions. They should not be in the same legislation—it would be far better if they were not—but, given that they are, let us send off for investigation those parts of the bill that relate to mergers, without delaying the collective bargaining provisions. We will know whose interests the government are serving if they fail to do that.

We in the opposition—the alternative government as we approach this election—have made commitments to more substantial reform. We will deliver that reform, which will drive competition, give small business a chance, make the economy more efficient and therefore generate the wealth we need. Those of us in the Australian Labor Party and in parties of its ilk—its counterparts around the world—know that our commitment to redistribution of wealth will only work if we generate the wealth in the first place. So we want an effective, competitive economy, and we need small business to have a fair chance of succeeding, in order to deliver it.

We participated in the Senate Economics References Committee inquiry into the effectiveness of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in protecting small business. We support all 17 recommendations of that committee. That is the reform that Australia needs. We have been highlighting the problem for ages. We have been campaigning on it for ages, in support of Professor Fels first and in support of Mr Samuel now—and in support of the claims by small business groups all around Australia, who are not traditional supporters of the Labor Party but are looking to the Labor Party for support in delivering reform, because they know that the Howard government will not do so.

We will support these measures as they relate to collective bargaining. If the government will cooperate in sending off the merger provisions—and others referred to by the shadow Treasurer—for committee investigation, we will focus on and support the quick passage of these collective bargaining propositions. I suspect, in the terms outlined by the member for Hunter, that we would like to see stronger ones, but these are all that small business is going to get, so we will support them. We urge the government to allow the procedural matters outlined by the member for Hotham to occur in the Senate so that those parts of the bill that relate to collective bargaining can pass. We give a commitment that, as the Howard government is unable to deliver the reforms that small business need in the Trade Practices Act, an incoming Latham Labor government will deliver those reforms.

talk.start.para: —I am bitterly disappointed in what has come forward from the government in the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. I would have thought that, on the eve of an election and with the threat from the ALP, they would have gone further. I pay tribute to and thank the opposition for the proposals that they have put forward. They do not go anywhere near far enough, but they go a hell of a lot further than the government's proposals. I would have thought that, with the rhetoric from the government and the championing of small business and with The Nationals senator from Queensland running around making a lot of noise, they must feel ashamed, but they do not. They have no sense of shame whatsoever.

speech.para: Fair market or market failure? is an extraordinary document. In this document, ACNeilsen, the gospel, says that Woolworths and Coles moved from a 51 per cent to a 75.4 per cent share of the food market in Australia. The nearest comparable country on earth permits I think about 12 per cent for the big two. But these blokes are saying that there is no problem with a movement from 51 per cent in 1991 to 75.4 per cent by the time this document came out. I have raised many times in this place the issue of deregulation and its effect. The first industry to hit the wall after deregulation was the egg industry, but before I talk about that it should be remembered in this place—and I do not want to let the ALP off here—that the architect of all this rubbish was Mr Keating. But the opposition have magnificently continued on with his work. There is no doubt about that.

We are supposed to be deregulating to help consumers. You understand that, Mr Deputy Speaker: in the area of eggs, we deregulated the egg industry, which guaranteed a price to the egg farmers and in almost all states guaranteed a price to the consumers as well. So we had a fixed system. You have to judge proposals by their outcomes. You cannot just say that competition is wonderful; you have to judge it by its outcomes. There was a most magnificent cartoon from that period that had Mr Keating reading a book on the Japanese economic miracle and saying, `It won't work. It works in practice, but it will never work in theory.' Of course, this is what we have here.

Let me get back to the eggs. In Australia we started with a Brisbane price of $1.93 and an Australian price of $1.85 a kilogram. When we brought this wonderful free market system in, did egg prices go down? They went down for the farmers. They went down 65c a dozen for the farmers. The farmers, who in 1992 were on $2.10 a dozen, lost 65c a dozen. But did the price go down for the consumers? No, it did not. Consumers should have got 65c off a dozen. The price to the consumers went up $1.08 a dozen. So the price paid to the farmers went down by 65c a dozen and the price paid by the consumers went up by over $1.

Was this a good outcome? I tell you what: it was a damn good outcome for the big retail chains. If you multiply the rise in price of eggs and the drop in their cost by the number of eggs sold, the amount you are left with translates into an extra profit of $415 million per year for the people in these retail chains. Was it a good outcome for the farmers? It was disastrous for the farmers. I think we had over 20 or 30 egg farmers in the Kennedy electorate; I think we are now down to about two. There used to be about 3,000 egg farmers in Australia. The last time they tried to get a figure, there were under 300. Deregulation was disastrous for the farmers and it was disastrous for the consumers, but the big retail chains made an extra $415 million a year in profit. The people who participated in this document knew that. They knew that two companies in the main had taken an extra $415 million a year out of the poor struggling purse of Mrs Housewife and over the broken backs of Australian farmers.

The industry that I represent—the sugar industry—was No. 2. We are deregulated now, but we were not deregulated then. But they took the tariff away from us. You must understand the importance of this tariff. We were getting a tariff of $120 a tonne. All we are getting now is $240 a tonne for our entire production. The tariff was worth $120 a tonne to us. During the period when this tariff was taken off, the world price for sugar fell. Brazil went to ethanol, which enabled her to sell the sugar she was putting on the world market at a much lower figure, so the world price fell during this period as well.

Once again, we had a pre-deregulation price for the farmers of $429 a tonne. We have since had an average price for the period 2000-02 of $287 a tonne. So we have gone from $430 a tonne down to $290 a tonne. The price has fallen for the big retail chains. Did the price go down for the consumers? The price that the retail chains are paying to the farmers has nearly halved, but did the price go down for the consumers? It should have just about halved. Surprise, surprise: it rose from $2.01 for a two-kilo pack to $2.32 a kilo for a two-kilo pack. Once again, the benefit accrued to the retail chains. How much was that benefit? That benefit was $378 million a year of extra profit, taken out of the purse of poor, struggling Mrs Housewife—poor, struggling little mothers with kids—and taken over the broken backs of the farmers. We pay Channel Nine a great tribute, because they did a wonderful story on the number of suicides that are occurring. We are averaging one a month in sugar areas. I hope the people in this place feel happy with their achievements. We saw $378 million in extra profit and, once again, the bulk of it would have gone to the two retail chains.

Now we come to milk. A past Dean of the Faculty of Economics at Queensland University—a very distinguished academic figure in Australia, not just Queensland—said there are three great shames in the history of this country: the way that we treated the men that came home from Vietnam; the way that we treated the original Australians, the Aboriginal people, if you like; and, the way that we treat the dairy farmers of this country. I did not think that it was an exaggeration to put dairy farmers in the same category as those others. They are the hardest working people. After deregulation, I went and visited 12 dairy farms. I suppose it was to punish myself. I went and said g'day to them and told them that I was sorry for what had happened and that it was my fault that I had failed to win for them. Those 12 farms are run only by husband and wife teams. There are no employees whatsoever. They get up around 5 o'clock in the morning and they go to bed at 7 o'clock at night. I know, because I have visited a lot of them. They finish their last milking at 7 o'clock and then they have to clean up. They have a bit of a spell during the day. They have no employees. The husband and wife on each farm both do this every day of their lives, every year of their lives. These people are the hardest working people. I did not believe anyone still worked that hard.

After the disaster of the deregulation of the wool industry, which I am not going to talk about today, after the disaster of the deregulation of the egg industry and after the disaster of the removal of the tariffs on the sugar industry, one would have thought that the government would have said, `This is a hopeless failure. Every time we've tried it, it has been a disaster.' But, no, they are driven by ideology. The communists are not dead in this country. The government believe in the ideology and no power on earth and no amount of persuasion or reality is going to change them.

I am extrapolating these figures from Queensland and New South Wales, because it is very hard to pick a time period in Victoria, as there was a rolling sort of deregulation in Victoria. I do not think anyone familiar with the industry would question that it is fair to apply these figures to the Australian situation. Did it help the consumers? No. The price in Sydney was $1.15 a litre. It went up to $1.54 a litre. The price in Brisbane was $1.16 a litre. It went up to $1.59 a litre. The average price of milk—and I am pleased to see a representative of the dairy industry in here now—for the consumer went up 41c. What happened to the farmers? Did they enjoy the benefit from this 41c rise in the price paid by the consumers? Surprise, surprise: their prices went down, from an average of 53c to an average of 34c. That is a 19c fall. If you add 19c less to the farmers to the 41c more to the consumers and extrapolate from that figure, which is a fair thing to do across Australia, multiplying it by the number of litres—1,884 mega-litres—you come up with an astounding figure of $1,130,000,000 dollars of extra profit every year.

Then this pathetic fair trading legislation is brought into the House today. It is absolutely pathetic and a continuation of what we have copped. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you allow for the 11c a litre from the government—and we thank the government for that 11c a litre—that takes it down to only $923 million of profit, which in the main is divided up between two companies.

Let us not beat around the bush. You will recall me mentioning that 75.4 per cent of the marketplace was shared by three companies. Now, of course, there are only two companies and so the 75.4 per cent is effectively divided up by the two of them. Strangely and very interestingly, ACNeilsen is not doing these figures anymore, so we have to refer to Woolworths' and Coles' annual reports for growth figures. But, if you add what they claim the growth of their sales to be to what ACNeilsen reported, they are now on 81.6 per cent of the retail market.

We have the government saying that there is no problem here and that they are going to stop them from getting any bigger. That should not make those two retailers lose any sleep at night. They have 82 per cent of the Australian market, and anyway the government are only stopping mergers. Coles and Woolworths can still go and buy as many individual supermarkets as they want. I know that one of the independent groups in Australia is taking its own action, because it does not believe that in its lifetime this or any other government is going to do anything to help. It believes that the major parties of Australia are owned by the big corporations.

I have to be fair to the ALP and say that the offer that they are putting on the table is much, much better than the offer that has been put on the table by those on the other side of the House. One has to remain somewhat sceptical, because they were in government for 12 or 13 years and they were very much involved in creating the problem. A lot of the damage in the egg industry and in the sugar industry was done by them. So in three items there were extra profits: milk, $923 million a year; eggs, $415 million a year; and sugar, $378 million a year. We are talking about extra profits per year of nearly $2,000 million coming out of the pockets of poor Mrs Housewife and from the broken backs of the farmers.

I went down to attend one of these hearings. I was confident that our representative, The Nationals' senator on this, was going to do the job for us. One of the reasons for my very great anger and rage with this document and this committee was that he sold us out lock, stock and barrel. There is no doubt about that. The day I went down, one of the members of the committee stood up and said, `We have got three ways to travel here.' I had said on many occasions—not to him, to somebody else—that there are three ways to travel here. I said that you could go to the antitrust legislation, the famous legislation of the truly outstanding man of American history, a remarkable and wonderful man, Theodore Roosevelt. Under his trust-busting legislation, he made a stand against the eastern Standard Oil Company in New Jersey—Rockefeller's company—busting it up into 13 or 20 different companies, through great courage and tenacity.

You can go to that antimonopoly legislation, similar to what America has, but that would still leave it in the hands of the courts, to some degree, and I would have my scepticism about the determination or the ability of a government to go out against organisations so big. Or you could go down the pathway of strengthening the existing laws, which is hardly happening here at all. Alternatively, you could have gone to what NARGA asked for, which is capping and divestment, which obviously is the only way that you are going to deal with this problem. I must say it will take a lot of courage now, because these people have such a stranglehold on the Australian economy.

In my home town of Charters Towers we could walk down the street—three or four of us—and raise enough money for a paid player for the local rugby league team. If I walked down the street and tried to raise money for the local rugby league team, I would be flat out paying for a player for one weekend. That is because these big stores come in and they do not just want to close the other supermarkets in town; they want to close the after-hours supermarkets, which leaves us nowhere to go. We had the aged persons president in Townsville come to us and say, `We need the corner store. We can't afford a taxi to go uptown.' Outside of Brisbane there is no commuter transportation system. Throughout Australia there is no transportation system outside of the metropolitan areas. Even inside the metropolitan areas people say they need the corner store. But if you allow unrestricted trading hours, then of course there will be no corner stores.

When the trading hours were extended in Queensland, 100 or 200 corner stores closed down. The main after-hours store in Charters Towers told me that they lost 30 per cent of their business when extended trading hours came in in Queensland. The big stores want to wipe out not only all the competition but also all the bakeries, all the butcher shops and all the florists. There is a bakery, a butcher shop and a florist in these big stores. Now they want to close down all the service stations. They want it all. There is no limit to their hunger for profit.

I heard Tim Fischer in a speech last night say that this is a land of opportunity. I would like to know where the hell the opportunity is! I know families in this country that have never ever worked for anyone else. They have been owner-operator families for six and seven generations. All their kids can hope for is a job working for some big corporation which, as time goes on, will increasingly be an overseas-owned corporation.

If there is one thing that competition policy has not delivered in this country, it is competition. This country has gone from having a situation where two corporations have held 51 per cent of the food market to a situation where two corporations, according to their own figures, hold 81.6 per cent of the market. There is not another country in the world that would stand for this sort of situation. For the farmers, what is the use of farming? The biggest farmer in Australia said to me, `We are getting out of it; we are going into cattle and we will sell on the export market, because you cannot survive in this country. We have only two people to sell to.' If you have 5,000 or 10,000 or 15,000 sellers of a product and you have two buyers, when I went to university they told me that was called an oligopoly. I might even say a monopoly of two, as the previous speaker said. We appreciate that in the government there are probably some people that have fought hard for the minor changes that are in the bill. But stopping mergers will not stop the takeovers in Charters Towers and Cloncurry and the thousands of other takeovers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the government it is my pleasure to sum up the debate on the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. I have listened with interest to the characteristically passionate contribution by the member for Kennedy, for whom I have a high regard. But on this issue I confess we have a divergent opinion. I note that under the ongoing competition reforms which this economy has been subject to under the previous government and under the current one in particular, we see Australia being described as the miracle economy by the OECD. We see unemployment at record low levels. In my own electorate it has fallen from 12 per cent to four per cent. We see rapid rates of economic growth. We see real wages for low-income earners rising significantly and consistently. We see tremendous benefits to Australian consumers. This bill provides a healthy balance between the desirability of new market entrants and the capacity of efficient Australian corporations to grow.

speech.para: The government would like to thank those honourable members who participated in the debate on the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. This bill implements the government's response to the independent review of the competition provisions of the Trade Practices Act in 2003, chaired by Sir Daryl Dawson. The Dawson review was the most comprehensive review of the competition provisions of the act for a decade. After extensive consultation and careful consideration, the Dawson review concluded that the competition provisions of the act have served Australians well. It made a total 43 recommendations aimed at improving the operation of the competition and authorisation provisions as well as the administration of the act. The overall theme of the Dawson review was that the competition provisions should protect the competitive process rather than particular competitors. The government strongly supports this view of the act and has accepted the vast majority of the Dawson review recommendations.

The bill will improve existing ACCC processes by providing for greater accountability, transparency and timeliness in decision making and by reducing the regulatory burden on business. Following the government's response, the government undertook a three-month consultation period with the states and territories and a 35-day voting period on the text of the bill required by the Conduct Code Agreement. All eight jurisdictions have approved the bill and the government is eager to see early access to the benefits that are contained in the bill for business, both big and small, and for consumers.

The new processes and requirements are: a new voluntary formal merger clearance process to operate in parallel with the informal clearance system, definitive time limits for consideration by the ACCC that business can rely on and the certainty that a clearance is legally binding. Merger authorisation applications will be considered directly by the tribunal instead of the ACCC to ensure commercially realistic time frames for applications and to prevent strategic appeals by third parties. Non-merger authorisations will have strict time limits for consideration by the ACCC and, of particular advantage to small business, the ACCC will be able to waive the filing fee.

The bill will reduce the regulatory burden on small business by introducing a notification process for collective bargaining by small business dealing with large business as an alternative to the authorisation process. The third-line forcing can be beneficial and procompetitive and will be subjected to a substantial lessening of the competition test, instead of being prohibited per se, consistent with other forms of exclusive dealing. Serious cartel type conduct such as exclusionary and price-fixing provisions will continue to be prohibited outright. Genuine joint ventures will provide a defence on competition grounds.

Dual-listed companies will be treated on the same basis as other companies under the Trade Practices Act. The ACCC will have a new ability to seize evidence, but this will be balanced by the requirement to obtain a warrant from a magistrate. The bill provides higher penalties for a contravention of the act, allows persons to be disqualified from directing or managing a corporation and prohibits the indemnification of officers, employees and agents against the imposition of a pecuniary penalty. This will ultimately be of great benefit to consumers, providing a strong incentive for companies and those responsible for managing company business to comply with the act. Other measures help ensure the constitutional validity of the act's national application and apply the competition provisions to local government, insofar as it carries on a business, consistently with the act's application to other levels of government.

The opposition is critical of including merger and collective bargaining proposals together in a single bill. The Dawson review recommended the proposals as part of the one package. Both sets of proposals streamline administrative processes, providing transparency, timeliness and accountability. The government is about finding the best and fairest environment for all business to operate in, not favouring one type of business over the other to the detriment of all. If the opposition is serious about bringing the benefits of Dawson to business, both big and small, it will not try to break up the bill and delay it further by sending various parts off to a committee.

The government has responded to the report of the Senate Economics References Committee on the effectiveness of the Trade Practices Act in protecting small business by accepting some changes to clarify the misuse of the market power provision, section 46, and the prohibition of unconscionable conduct in business transactions. I note the Minister for Small Business and Tourism has arrived at the table and I commend him for his valuable contribution to those reforms which are to the benefit of small business.

The opposition is querying why the government has not included the changes that it proposes to section 46 in the Dawson bill and why, in fact, the government has only included one recommendation from the Senate inquiry—that is, collective bargaining—in the bill. The government is consulting with the states and territories on its proposed amendments to section 46 as required by the Conduct Code Agreement. The states and territories have a maximum time limit of three months to respond. As at the time of this speech, no state or territory has responded. Following the consultations, the government will seek the vote of the states and territories on a draft bill. Amendments to section 46 cannot be progressed until the states and territories respond as per the Conduct Code Agreement.

I also note that there have been calls by the opposition and by some in the press for a whole range of new provisions in the Dawson bill to include mechanisms such as a cease and desist power for the ACCC and a prohibition on creeping acquisitions. Dawson, reviews prior to Dawson and the minority government senators in the Senate report specifically rejected such new powers as not only unjustified but quite possibly damaging to the competitive process. Business, particularly small business, is eagerly awaiting the benefits that this bill will confer. I am hopeful the government will receive the support that is needed to streamline and improve the administration and enforcement of the act. I commend the bill to the House.

To this the honourable member for Hotham has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.
