debateinfo.title: SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE (LEARNING TOGETHER-ACHIEVEMENT THROUGH CHOICE AND OPPORTUNITY) BILL 2004

cognateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 August, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Labor do support enhanced reporting arrangements for all schools to provide better information to parents and teachers so they can use this information. But many of the accountability measures that are included in the Schools Assistance (Learning Together—Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 are already under way. A number of them were started by Labor state ministers and they, of course, have Labor's support. Not surprisingly, we also support schools flying the flag, but it seems to be the case that this government is actually more interested in the condition of the flagpole than the resources that are available to children in classrooms. Of course this Minister for Education, Science and Training is not the slightest bit interested in talking about resources. He wants to talk about anything but the resources that are available to our schools. He will do anything to avoid talking about it, including, as regularly as possible, blaming the states for any problem with Australian schools. He does this at any opportunity.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition, in his budget reply speech, announced that a federal Labor government would pay the TAFE fees for secondary school students. I think this is a terrific policy initiative because it will encourage more young people to get vocational qualifications, whether it is in information technology, construction or whatever it might be. These students can get that vocational education at a TAFE while they are still at school. If Labor are elected, this iniative will be at no cost to either the parents of those students or their school. But, in response to this terrific initiative announced by the Leader of the Opposition, the education minister immediately issued a statement saying that federal Labor could not make this commitment and that collecting TAFE fees was a state responsibility. Clearly the minister had not considered the possibility that federal, state and territory governments can actually work collaboratively to make sure that we get things done. That is precisely what a federal Labor government will do if elected.

The recent agreement between Mark Latham, the Leader of the Opposition, and all premiers and chief ministers will put an end to the kind of futile buck-passing that is typified by the attitude of the current Minister for Education, Science and Training. Abolishing TAFE fees for secondary students is just one area where the states, territories and a federal Labor government can work together for great results. Schools are another.

There is an urgent need for federal and state governments to work together to bring all schools up to a decent national standard. Our schools cannot wait for another three years for a fair funding system. From Labor's point of view, it is well past the time to end the Howard government's unfair schools funding system. We want to see the introduction of a new, needs based funding arrangement. That requires the Commonwealth and state governments to work together. That is exactly what all federal, state and territory Labor leaders have agreed to do. This landmark agreement is Australia's only chance to fix up the school funding mess that is giving the largest increases to the wealthiest schools in this country. Together, federal and state Labor will restore fairness to school funding.

The Howard government takes every opportunity to claim that the 70 per cent of Australian children in public schools are a state, not a federal, responsibility. Labor strongly disagrees with this view held by the current government. The education of all children must be the responsibility of all Australian governments. The Labor leaders' agreement commits federal, state and territory leaders to making public education a national priority and finally ending the buck-passing. If there is problem in a local school, parents want that problem fixed. What they do not want is meaningless blame-shifting between different levels of government. The agreement that was recently signed by all the Labor leaders will provide increased public funding for our public schools. It will also provide public funding for the non-government school system on the basis of need. That need will be assessed against a very clear national standard. Labor support families who choose non-government schools, and all non-government schools will continue to receive funding support from a future Labor government.

If Labor are elected, Australia will have a national schools resource standard for the first time, and both federal and state funding will be linked to it. This standard will fulfil two purposes. First, it will be a measure of the recurrent funding required for a 21st-century standard of education for all schools in the future. It will establish the level of resources that schools will need to provide quality teaching, literacy and numeracy support and up-to-date technology and to make sure that we have increased retention in our schools. Second, the standard will become the benchmark for assessing which schools need an increase in funding so that they can deliver a 21st-century standard of education. There will be increased funding for government schools to bring them up to the national standard. The combined funding available to non-government schools from federal, state and private sources, including fees, will also be assessed against the national standard. Non-government schools that do not have the resources to meet the national standard will have their funding increased.

The current lack of coherent funding principles for non-government schools in Australia has allowed eight different state and territory funding systems to develop alongside, and at times in conflict with, federal funding. There has been no attempt by this government to get a comprehensive approach to the funding of schools at the federal, state and territory levels. By contrast, state and territory governments have agreed to work with a Latham Labor government to make sure that much-needed increases in funding go to those schools that are operating below the standard of resources that they need to operate on. This is by far the fairest way to decide which schools will receive extra funding and which schools will have their funding cut. Funding will be tied to a set of accountability and reporting standards for all schools, which will also deliver a common starting age, a nationally consistent curriculum and national literacy, numeracy and technology standards.

There are so many opportunities for our neighbourhood government and non-government schools to work together, to share resources such as library facilities or sporting facilities, as some of them already do. Our funding systems should be geared towards creating complementary relationships between government and non-government schools. We do not want to promote the duplication of resources or the resentment that exists at the moment between the different sectors. That resentment has built up over the years of the Howard government—when they have given huge increases to the wealthiest schools in the country. Labor's national schools resource standard represents, for once, a coherent, rational and fair way for all schools to be funded. If we want to give all children—every single child in Australia—a great education then the Howard government's unfair policy has to come to an end. The policy that Labor in government will implement, a fairer funding system, will come about from the beginning of 2006.

Tonight we are also debating the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 2004, which deals with literacy initiatives that were announced by the Minister for Education, Science and Training in the week following the budget. That announcement was another case of the Howard government playing catch-up politics. The Leader of the Opposition has put children's literacy firmly on the national agenda. He did that earlier this year when he announced Labor's program called Read Aloud Australia—an $80 million program to encourage parents to read to their children from birth. The literacy initiative that we are debating tonight in this bill is a very late attempt by the Howard government to catch up with the Leader of the Opposition's incredible efforts to put this issue on the national map.

Labor welcome the fact that the Howard government is trying to catch up on the critical issue of children's reading. There is no doubt that reading and writing, especially for young children, will be a Labor priority. We particularly support very early childhood development programs, as well as remedial support for children experiencing difficulties in meeting the minimum standard of literacy once they are at school. Of course, we welcome any additional funding support for children's reading.

But it is interesting that the minister describes this literacy announcement as a Howard government idea. As it turns out, in fact, it is not. Here is how one US journal described a policy announced by the US President Mr Bush back in 1999. It was an education plan that required states to `test their disadvantaged students on academic basics every year'. The journal said:

quote.para: ... federal money would then go to parents, who could use it as a voucher to pay for ... tutoring ... worth about $1,500.

speech.para: I would like the minister, in his response at the end of this debate, to confirm whether or not he ripped off Mr Bush's education policy and is now passing it off as his own. Not only is he trying to impose a US higher education system on Australians, it now seems we are getting a US style literacy plan. But this is of course nowhere near enough to tackle literacy. There is no question on the part of those who educate our children that trying to intervene after year 3 is far too late. If the Howard government were serious about tackling literacy problems, it should adopt Labor's read aloud policy to make sure that more children are read to from infancy. We also want to see increased support provided to those schools where high numbers of children experience reading difficulties. Of course, that is unfortunately not contained in the legislation before us today.

In conclusion, we will be supporting these bills—we will be passing them—because we want to give schools funding certainty for 2005. But I make it very clear here tonight that, should we win government, schools will be funded from 2006 on a needs basis, because Labor believe that a quality education must be provided to all students, regardless of the schools their parents choose and regardless of their parents' income. We want to make sure that schools are funded fairly. We will not support these massive increases in grants from the federal government going to the wealthier schools in the country. We want our public schools as well as our needy non-government schools to get increased resources. That will be reflected in the policy that Labor takes to the upcoming election. I move the amendment circulated in my name:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) condemns the Government for:
(a) refusing to accept its responsibilities for funding government schools as a national priority;
(b) providing only $4 million in new money for government schools out of its $31.3 billion package for schools;
(c) failing to include needs-based criteria in its funding and accountability provisions for non-government schools;
(d) refusing to take into account the total level of funding for non-government schools from all sources - Commonwealth, State and private - in assessing funding needs;
(e) entrenching its divisive and unfair funding arrangements for schools, where the largest increases in funding have been provided to some of the best resourced independent schools in Australia;
(f) failing to meet the urgent needs of students in government and non-government schools who have special needs, including:
(i) schools with concentrations of students from families living in poverty, unemployment and with low levels of school achievement and students with disabilities;
(ii) Indigenous students; and

(2) calls on the Government to introduce funding arrangements that reflect the relative needs of schools and students, so that all students have access to the resources they need to achieve the educational outcomes set out in the National Goals of Schooling for the 21st century”.

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie) —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Proposed fitout of new leased premises for Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources in Civic, ACT.

speech.para: The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources proposes to fit out new leased premises in Civic in the Australian Capital Territory. The need for the new facility has been driven by the approaching expiry in 2006 of the current Allara Street leases adjacent to the site of the proposed new building in Binara Street. The proposed building will provide approximately 21,750 square metres of lettable office space, consisting of a small basement containing about 600 square metres of storage space, computer equipment, showers, change rooms, building services and storage for 60 bicycles; a ground floor incorporating the main entrance lobby off Binara Street, a conference centre, reception/security facilities, a child-care centre, a cafe, one other small retail outlet, a loading dock and a mail centre; three levels of above-ground parking with space for 261 cars and 25 motorcycles; six levels of office accommodation of about 2,500 square metres each; and three smaller top-level office floors of about 2,000 square metres each. An additional optional floor may be constructed to cater for an expanded organisation, if required.

The department currently has about 1,240 staff. The proposal has provision for approximately 1,400 workstations and offices, which allows for expansion and flexibility in the workplace. Staff facilities will include an amenities room, parenting rooms, a carers' room and a prayer room. Fit-out works to be undertaken include integration of services into the base building works, including electrical, airconditioning, ventilation, lighting control, data, communications, security, fire and hydraulic services; office accommodation, including partitioning to form individual offices, meeting rooms, reception areas, training rooms and staff facilities; workstations, including desks and provision for personal storage; and loose furniture.

The developer is expected to construct the building from late this year or early next year. Subject to parliamentary approval, the proposed fit-out will be undertaken concurrently with the base building construction, and both are due for completion in late September 2006. The estimated cost of the proposed fit-out is $19.4 million. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2004

talk.start.para: —These two pieces of legislation, the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 and States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 contain a number of measures, but essentially they do two things. Firstly, they allocate Australian government funding for schools for the next four years. Secondly, they introduce a number of accountability requirements aimed at improving the performance of schools and better ensuring that they meet the needs of students and their parents. I want to turn my attention to each of these in turn.

speech.para: Firstly, in regard to funding, the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 allocates $31.3 billion over the 2005-08 quadrennium. That is an $8 billion increase from the current quadrennium. Next year alone, schools in Australia will receive a record $7.6 billion in direct funding from the Commonwealth. This figure is up 111 per cent since 1996—that is, since the Howard government has been in office direct Commonwealth funding for Australian schools has risen by 111 per cent. This is clear, unequivocal evidence of the Australian government's commitment to Australian schools. Let me elaborate briefly on a number of the features of this funding. Firstly, the largest increase is in general recurrent funding to cover ongoing costs, principally the costs of salaries of teachers and school staff. There is a figure of $27.4 billion in general recurrent grants for public and non-government schools. That includes full indexation to AGSRC—the average government school recurrent cost—at the current level of about six per cent per annum.

The bill includes $1.5 billion in capital grants to improve school facilities and help build new facilities. It includes $2 billion for literacy, numeracy and special learning needs—that is an increase of $393 million, or 25 per cent, over the current quadrennium. This funding will target the most disadvantaged students and reduce the chances of them getting behind in literacy and numeracy in those early years. If that happens, it compounds in later years and puts young people at an increasing level of disadvantage.

Contrary to what the former speaker, the member for Jagajaga and shadow minister for education, said, this level of funding is a record level of funding ever by any Australian government for literacy and numeracy in Australian schools. It is clear evidence of our commitment to addressing need—particularly the needs of disadvantaged students with respect to literacy and numeracy in those essential early years of schooling. In addition to that there is $113 million for geographically isolated children to meet their special education needs and $231 million for newly arrived students from non-English speaking backgrounds to help address the unique needs they have with respect to education.

The simple point is this: this funding package contains a record level of funding and is a massive increase. It shows very clearly—unequivocally—this government's commitment to the education needs of all children in this country, whether they be in public schools, Catholic schools or independent schools. Importantly, it supports parents in the choices they make for the education of their children. If parents want to choose to send their children to public schools, they should be supported, and they are. If they choose to send their children to Catholic schools, they should be supported, and they are. If they choose to send their children to independent schools, they should be supported, and they are.

This is in spite of every dishonest and divisive campaign being run by the Australian Education Union and the New South Wales Teachers Federation, which totally misrepresents the situation and plays the public system off against the private system. It creates negativity, division, harm and disunity within our schooling system. Sadly, this division and disunity are echoed and intensified by the comments of so many opposite. Sadly, the Australian Labor Party is happy to be part of this campaign of misrepresentation and dishonesty.

I want to make four points about this campaign and its dishonesty. The first point is that non-government schools do not get an unfairly high share of public funding. The nonsense that we heard from the member for Jagajaga before tries to pretend that somehow this government is favouring non-government schools, particularly elite non-government schools. The facts are simple: public schools in Australia received last year $19.9 billion of combined state and federal public funding; non-government schools, on the other hand, received $6.2 billion of public sector funding. So the 68 per cent of students who go to public schools received 76 per cent of public sector funding. The 32 per cent of students who attend non-government schools received 24 per cent of public sector funding.

The focus of the Education Union and New South Wales Teachers Federation and Labor Party campaign has been on just one component of funding. That has been the specifically targeted federal grants. They have totally deceptively and deliberately ignored the larger component of indirect funding that comes via general revenue grants, GST revenue et cetera to the states. Last year, the state governments received some $45 billion in total in revenue from the Commonwealth. Indirectly, that helps to fund state funding on public schools. The point is this: any meaningful, honest, accurate representation of funding needs to look at combined state and federal funding. In combined total figures, public schools receive $19.9 billion and non-government schools receive $6.2 billion. This is fundamentally fair.

For those non-government schools, the funding depends on the level of need. We are hearing much rhetoric from the other side about introducing a needs based formula. The funding formula is already based on need. The wealthier, less needy non-government schools receive 13.7 per cent—less than 14 per cent—of the average government school recurrent cost. It is a very small amount. The needier schools—those poorer Catholic schools and schools in greater need—can receive up to 70 per cent of the average government school recurrent cost. So the level of public funding, first of all, is always less than 100 per cent of the level of public school funding. Secondly, the proportion that is received depends on the level of need. This is fundamentally fair.

The second point that I want to make is that it is not a case of wealthy versus poor or of the government supporting wealthy private schools and not supporting supposedly poor, struggling public schools, and yet this is what we would be made to believe if we listened to the comments from the member for Jagajaga. The fact is that 80 per cent of the funding for non-government schools is for Catholic and low-fee Christian schools. It does not all go to so-called wealthy or elite schools; not even the majority of it goes to so-called wealthy or elite schools. Eighty per cent of it goes to the poorer Catholic or independent, low-fee Christian schools. The other point on this is that 20 per cent of families who send their children to non-government schools are earning family incomes of less than $21,000 a year. They are not all wealthy and they are not all elite. Many of them are struggling and yet, for whatever reasons, they still choose to send their children to non-government schools. This government respects and supports that choice.

The Blue Mountains Grammar School, a non-government school, is in my electorate. We hear people in the Australian Education Union and the Teachers Federation arguing that this is an elite private school and that the families are all wealthy and can afford to pay high fees. I know that there are two-income families at that school that have deliberately taken on a second job—it is usually the mother—in order to pay the fees, because they want to send their children to that school. In a conversation I had with the school principal recently, he said that many of the families are low and moderate income families, struggling to make the sacrifices to send their children to that school. He said that in some cases even the children are working in part-time jobs as well and contributing to the fees of that school. They are not elite, they are not wealthy; they are ordinary families making a choice in the best interests of their children, as they see it, and meeting the needs of their children. This government support that choice, and so we should.

The third point I want to make is that, contrary to the claims of the teachers unions, non-government schools actually save taxpayers and the education system substantial amounts of money. We have roughly 1.1 million students in non-government schools around this country. The level of funding those schools receive from the government is around $3,500 to $4,000 per student per year less than if they were public schools. That is, the non-government schools are subsidising the education of the children to the tune of around $4 billion a year. It is not simply that taxpayers are subsidising the education of the children, although that is happening; more to the point, they are subsidising the state governments of the day in educating their children. If all those children were to go back to the public systems, the public education systems around this country would have to find roughly $4 billion a year extra just to maintain the current level of per capita funding, just to maintain the same student to teacher ratios and just to maintain the same level of equipment in the schools. So it is not that money is being taken from public schools to give to non-government schools. The fact is simply that non-government schools are saving taxpayers and state and territory education systems money and making it possible for their education dollars to go further. If this were to be reversed, they would all be screaming because the funding per student in public schools, which is provided by state and territory governments, would be falling.

The fourth point I want to make about this debate from the teachers unions, and supported by the Labor Party, is that this debate has been letting the state and territory governments off the hook. Allowing the debate to focus on issues of federal funding between public and private schools has allowed the state governments to get away with the fact that they are underfunding state public schools. The fact is that public schools are constitutionally the responsibility of state governments. The member for Jagajaga was saying that it is everyone's responsibility to fund schools. It is. We help fund public schools with the massive general revenue grants—those massive buckets of money—that pass every year from the Commonwealth to the states, out of which they fund their public education system. So we are assisting; we are not ignoring our responsibilities. But with the Labor Party and the education unions trying to pretend that we are, and trying to create a dishonest view of what is going on, they are allowing the state governments to escape their responsibility.

In recent years we have seen direct federal grants—put aside the indirect grants for a moment—from the Australian government to state public schools growing faster than the grants of the state governments to their own schools, and they have been able to get away with that. Why? Because the teachers unions, supported by the Labor Party, have put the focus on the wrong issues. In the last year, for instance, Commonwealth direct grants to public schools rose by six per cent. State government grants to their schools rose, on average, by 2.1 per cent—that is around one-third of federal government grants, and not even keeping up with inflation. Over the past 8½ years under the Howard government direct federal grants to public schools have risen by 68 per cent. So this whole debate, this whole nonsense, that we are getting from the other side and the teachers unions is not only distorting the issue but allowing the state governments to escape their prime responsibility for funding public schools.

This bill illustrates and, indeed, confirms the Howard government's commitment to funding Australian schools and supporting parents in the choices they make regarding their children's education, be it in public, Catholic or non-government schools. Sadly, the Labor Party's view is different. They have indicated very clearly that they intend to cut the funding from some schools that they deem to be overresourced. This government says, `We're not going to cut funding from any school. We're committed to at least maintaining and, where we can, which is in most cases, we are increasing funding for our schools.' Yet the Labor Party's view is: `We think some schools get too much money. We think some schools are overresourced. We intend to cut funding from some of those supposedly overresourced schools.'

In a press release in March this year, when asked about how many schools, the member for Jagajaga and opposition spokesman for education said, `Well, if you look at Melbourne and Sydney, for instance, there is more than just a handful; there are many.' So there is not just a handful; there are many schools in the non-government sector from which Labor is planning to cut funding. In other words, Labor will penalise those parents who work hard, those families where two parents choose to work in order to pay school fees and those parents who take on an extra job or do overtime in order to pay the fees for their children to attend the schools of their choice; Labor will penalise them by reducing government funding. It is appalling that the Labor Party could even propose this. And what do we hear from the shadow spokesman? `Not just a handful; there are many schools.' It prompts the question: just how may schools are in fact on Labor's hit list? Just how many schools in the non-government sector will Labor cut funding from in order to appease the teachers unions? How many hardworking parents will they unfairly penalise? The union campaign supported by the Labor Party on this issue is divisive, it is dishonest and it is disgraceful. By contrast, this government is committed to supporting all parents in the choice of education for their children.

The second bill includes seven conditions of funding—seven accountability measures. Time prevents me going into these in detail, but the aim of these conditions is to make sure that the government funding that is given to help schools, be they public or non-government schools, will help to raise standards in these schools, help to instil the values that are important in these schools and help to ensure that children's needs and parental expectations are being met in these schools. I will quickly outline the seven conditions.

The first condition is that there has to be a move towards greater national consistency. We have the ridiculous situation in this country where we have six separate state education departments and two different territory education departments with different standards, different starting ages for school, different reporting arrangements et cetera. The government's intention is that we need to move towards a more coherent and consistent national standard. When there are 80,000 students each year moving interstate there is obviously a clear need for greater consistency.

The second condition is that there is clearer and better reporting to parents—not confused and vague reporting but clear reporting to parents—so they know how their child is performing at school in the basic subjects, against national standards and compared to other students. This way parents will know whether extra support or help is needed and they can talk with their children about those needs. The third condition is transparency of school performance so that parents know which schools are doing well and which are not doing well in a whole range of national benchmarks, including literacy and numeracy, year 12 results, school leaver destinations, teacher qualifications, teacher professional development, staff and student retention and absentee rates—all of these things. This way parents will know the quality of their school versus other schools.

The fourth condition is greater autonomy to school principals. This government believes that school principals have a much clearer idea of what is going on in a school, of the needs of the children and of the performance of their staff than do centralised state bureaucracies. The fifth condition is the implementation of a National Safe Schools Framework in which there are clear principles to which all schools will commit, ensuring the protection of children. The sixth condition is a commitment to physical activity. We have heard a lot lately about obesity and related problems. This is a requirement for at least two hours of physical education for students each week.

The final condition is making core values a part of schooling so that every school in this country, public or private, commits to focusing on those values we all consider essential to a cohesive, strong and united country. The government believe that these seven conditions will help focus the attention of schools on raising standards, on meeting the expectations of parents and on meeting the needs of the children they educate. The Howard government are committed to quality education and to supporting the choice of parents. We have shown that with record levels of funding. We have shown that with large increases in funding over previous years and we continue to commit to this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak to the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 and the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 2004,I must say at the outset that once again the Howard government has come out with another nasty piece of legislation which seeks to further undermine the nation's public education system, a fact not addressed by the previous government speaker who spoke often about choice and did not hold back in bagging the teachers unions. Unfortunately there was no mention by the previous speaker of what we are seeing out there in our communities, which is the running down of the public system. So many on the other side of this House are in denial about the crisis currently facing the public education system in this country. Many members in this House are quite aware of that crisis—they are made aware of it any time they visit their local public school.

speech.para: Who can forget the Prime Minister's ill-founded swipe at the values—or apparent lack thereof—of the public education system earlier this year? Teachers and parents committed to the public system were stunned and outraged by the Prime Minister's audacity on that occasion. This bill must be clearly seen for what it is: another blatant attack on the public education system in this country. We heard the previous speaker talk about the increasing amounts of money being put into the education system by this government, but the whole problem is that a lot of it is going into the private system while the public education system is missing out increasingly as time goes on.

We have seen that the Prime Minister's agenda is also being imposed on the public education system. For example, in order to qualify for the government's 2004 budget funding package, schools have been told that they must embrace apparent values based conditions, including each school flying the Australian flag. The Prime Minister told Australian schools that they would not receive federal funding unless they had `a functioning flagpole and flew the Australian flag'. Surely most parents and teachers are much more concerned with resources and infrastructure, especially at the present time, than whether their school flies a flag. I would suggest that most schools already have the flag flying anyway.

I know that in my own electorate of Cunningham there are numerous schools facing leaking buildings, doors falling off school classrooms and students forced to go to class in cold, damp and wet conditions. We could just go on and on. The infrastructure in the public education system is being run down as we speak. The federal government have a role to play in addressing this real concern out there at the moment. The Prime Minister is usually misguided on the subject of values at school. He seems to want to try once again to force his outmoded social perspective upon the next generation. He said with the budget that he will not give schools any money unless they agree to this. This is typical coalition social engineering in full flight.

The federal government have been attempting to undermine the perceived quality of our public education system for some time now and this bill is further evidence of that. It is about their attempts to make the public education system a residue system in this country. Rather than representing honestly what public education stands for and what it delivers to students—that is, quality, diversity, tolerance and access—this government are trying to make out that public education is the poor sibling of private education and that they are simply doing their bit to give the public system a hand up. The schools assistance bill is about this government's inability to recognise our public education system as one of the nation's greatest assets, just like their failure to recognise our public health care system as a national asset and a world leader. They want to downgrade public providers to speed up the transition over to private education because this government are obsessed with privatisation and the principles of user pays. The government fundamentally believe that those who can afford to pay deserve higher standards and that those who cannot must work harder until they can break through to the supposedly superior private system.

What this government must realise is that Australians recognise that our nation's greatest social asset—our commitment to egalitarianism—will be fatally undermined by the government's twisted and misguided ideological agenda. There is no doubt that the government are determined to create a nation of haves and have-nots. Undermining the public education system is just one element of their unwavering support for and faith in the free market. They seem to believe that it is not the government's role to provide essential education and health services but, rather, it is the role of the market to do so. We heard the previous speaker talk about the $4 billion that is coming out of the pockets of ordinary Australians in supporting the education system at the moment. Under this government that cost is increasing every day.

This government are encouraging in any way they can the flight of Australians from the public system to the private system. This is something that we all need to be really concerned about. This bill represents a further effort by the government to achieve this goal. As the Prime Minister explained when he announced the changes contained within this bill, parents want to see better standards in primary and secondary schools. So, according to the Prime Minister, it seems that obviously the public system needs help to get it up to private system standards. I think that is rubbish. This is despite the fact that most states have indicated that they already have in place most of the programs that the Prime Minister has highlighted, including, for example, compulsory two-hour-per-week exercise programs. By the end of last month, for example, only 123 schools had applied for the $1,500 to buy a flagpole, so it seems that most already have a flagpole standing with the flag fluttering. Teachers unions across the country have highlighted how the Howard government's proposals have more to do with politics than educational outcomes.

The Greens oppose this bill because most of the conditions which have been tied to funding are either inappropriate or unnecessary. On top of this, the Greens are fundamentally opposed to the inequitable socioeconomic status or SES funding model which, under this bill, the government plan to further extend. A major change implemented by this bill is that all nongovernment schools will now be covered by the SES system which was introduced in 2001. The SES funding model allocates money to a school based on the socioeconomic status of its students, regardless of tuition fees. This means that this government rely on a funding formula which allows them to financially bolster those schools which they perceive to be the best schools—the nation's wealthiest private schools. This government appear to be under the false impression that the most gifted and talented students attend the nation's wealthiest schools. Rather than bolstering our wonderful public system and ensuring that students across the nation continue to have equality of opportunity, this government now blatantly favour the nation's wealthiest schools. That cannot be denied. As a report tabled by Associate Professor Louise Watson at the Senate inquiry into this issue says:

quote.para: [Private] schools receive $368 million per year in government grants, which assist in raising their total average resources per student to more than 62% above average state school resources.

speech.para: The Greens consider this funding model completely unacceptable.

The consideration of this bill takes place against the backdrop of continuing debate about Commonwealth funding for schools. It is also occurring at the same time as the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee is conducting an inquiry into Commonwealth funding for schools. This committee is set to report on 11 August. Once again, we have a government showing disrespect to the parliamentary process by handing down relevant legislation into the House before a relevant committee hands down its own report. The committee is examining the principles of Commonwealth funding for schools with particular reference to efficiency, effectiveness and accountability. The Minister for Education, Science and Training, in his budget media release, announced that the government will provide $31.3 billion in funding for Australian schools from 2005 to 2008, representing an $8 billion increase over the current quadrennium of Commonwealth funding for schools in 2001 to 2004. That is $31.3 billion over that 2005-08 period. The bill gives effect to the budget provisions.

Over two-thirds of the $31.3 billion will be allocated to non-government schools, continuing a trend which has seen the non-government schools' share of Commonwealth specific purpose funding for schools grow from 55.6 per cent in 1995-96 to an estimated 68.9 per cent by 2007-08. That is an additional 13.3 per cent diverted away from the public sector. This allocation takes place in the context that the Australian government considers its school funding role as a supplementary one and that, under the Australian Constitution, government schools are the responsibility of state and territory governments. We have heard the previous speaker refer to that belief. Most of the $8 billion funding increase will be due to indexation and supplementation. From the various ministerial announcements regarding the funding arrangements for the next quadrennium, approximately $404.6 million, or five per cent of this increase, can be readily identified as new money. A major proportion of this money, amounting to $362 million, will finance the Catholic systemic schools' move into the socioeconomic status—SES—system of Commonwealth general recurrent funding for non-government schools.

There has been some confusion over the detail of the ALP school funding policy and its potential impacts. There can be no confusion over where the Greens stand on schools funding. As Senator Nettle, the Greens spokesperson on education, pointed out earlier this year, when a government choose whether to give money to the public school system or to further subsidise the private school system, the government are making a clear decision about the kind of society they want to be supporting. They are choosing between an inclusive, cohesive and high-performing society and a divided, elitist, and inefficient society. This is a choice the Greens are unafraid to make. We say loud and clear that public education must be the priority of all governments. We say that a free, universal, high-quality public education system is the best policy option for Australia. Such a system must enable lifelong learning and include preschool, primary, secondary, TAFE and university study.

The Greens recognise that there is a long history of private schooling in this country and that it fulfils a discrete role in the education spectrum. But the dominance of the public school system is a public good, and we believe that it should be recognised and defended as such. Only through a strong public school system that educates the overwhelming majority of our children can we guarantee an inclusive and cohesive education that knits our society together. An education system that allows wealth, religion, and snobbery to segregate kids at school is sowing the seeds for a divided and therefore poorer society. Sadly, this is the direction Australia is moving in as enrolments in public schools drop across the nation. Whilst this continues, governments and political parties cannot afford to stay silent about the shift in enrolments from public schools to private schools.

Support for public education is central to the political philosophy of the Greens. The benefits of education can only be distributed fairly if all children and all Australians have the right to access education free of charge. The Greens recognise that the process of learning is a continuum from birth to the end of our lives, so our commitment to social justice means that we support a free education system from early childhood through to university. No child should be denied the opportunity to learn and socialise with their peers because of financial barriers, in the same way that no student should be barred from going to university or TAFE because they cannot afford the fees.

The continuing trend of less federal money for public schools must therefore be reversed. Key to this reversal is the abolition of the outrageously inequitable SES funding system and the funding maintained status of wealthy independent schools and now of Catholic schools. The Greens have always been opposed to the SES system. We voted against it when it was first introduced and we will vote against it again in this debate. We have recognised from the outset that it would never deliver the advertised needs based funding but would entrench the advantage of the wealthiest private schools, and we are seeing that happen. By measuring needs via census districts rather than actual income or assets of parents, SES can never be an accurate model for measuring need, especially since it does not consider the millions of dollars that parents of private school children put into their children's schools. The government's continuing defence of such a model as equitable would be laughable if it did not have such a serious impact on the quality of education that future generations are receiving. The Greens are fundamentally opposed to the ideological thrust of the coalition's education policies and their implementation. They offend against our belief in social justice and they offend against our demand for responsible public policy.

You might ask: what is the Greens' vision of how to fund schools? This may be a controversial issue elsewhere, but there is unanimous support within the Greens and within the general community that I deal with for the need to prioritise the funding of public schools ahead of private schools. There is a limited bucket of money available from the public sector, and we feel that the public school sector should receive priority in that allocation. We reject the central argument put forward by advocates of private schooling that each taxpayer is entitled to a share of their education dollar. This is at the heart of the so-called choice argument constantly put by the government. This argument is peddled by the government despite the fact that this is not the way taxation works. Our taxes are not hypothecated—no-one can claim a personal share from their defence dollar or their welfare dollar, much as they may wish to. We all pay taxes, and services are provided for the whole of the community. The responsibility of government is to provide the best public education system they possibly can for the whole of the community.

The Greens' vision for how this should occur is to abolish the Commonwealth government's inequitable schemes for funding private schools, including the socioeconomic status—SES—and funding maintained formulas; to immediately end public funding for the wealthiest private schools, the former category 1 schools; to phase out public funding of category 2 private schools; and to significantly reduce the funding of category 3 private schools as well. Our vision is to redirect this money into a national priority public schools funding program, previously the Disadvantaged Schools Program, to assist in improving educational outcomes in public schools that need additional support. There is no doubt that there are a lot of public schools out there at the moment that need that additional support. The Greens are calling for the funding to private schools to be frozen at 2003-04 levels pending the outcome of a full inquiry into the funding of non-government schools. The Greens are committed to these measures because they represent a significant first step in turning around the enrolment trend away from public schools and towards ensuring that our public education system is up with the world's best.

The Greens' policies would ensure that approximately $6 billion would be redirected from the private to the public system over the next quadrennium, and that is approximately $610 per student. This would go a long way to addressing chronic teacher shortages, problem class sizes and increases in teacher salaries. But it is not the end of our commitment. The Greens support a further increase in direct federal funding to public schools which would bring our spending on public education closer to the OECD's highest, as a proportion of GDP and per capita levels.

The Greens believe that accountability for public money is a basic prerequisite of good government. To that end, private schools receiving public funding must fulfil the same accountability requirements as public schools. The Greens support the introduction of standards for full financial disclosure, transparency and accountability; the achieve-ment of core educational standards that must be met by all non-government schools receiving public funding; and the introduction of accountability frameworks to apply to government funding to non-government schools to create the same minimum level of public accountability and transparency that applies to public schools.

We believe that funding, accountability and equity are the three corners of a responsible and equitable schools policy. What is needed is an overhaul of schools funding which delivers more to public schools and scraps the unfair SES funding model for the private sector. What is also needed is a commitment to accountability for all public funds going to schools and an end to discrimination in any schools for any reason.

These initiatives can be funded by redirecting the government's existing schools expenditure on a more equitable basis. Australians have consistently told the government in recent times that, when it comes to budget time, people want public money invested in services like health and education, not frittered away on vote buying tax cuts. The Greens believe that in times of prosperity it is the responsibility of government to invest in public works and services that will stand us in good stead in leaner times. This means investment in education and health, not tax cuts.

Our policy is designed to ensure that its implementation would reap dividends for all Australians for generations to come and to turn around enrolments, as parents see government backing for our public schools and watch public schools thriving on that support. Given the great work currently done by teachers in the public school system, an injection of funds would allow such work to be magnified so as to turn out more quality students ready to make a great contribution to the community. In this way we will all see the benefits of investing in and supporting our public schools. A great public education system, educating the overwhelming majority of the population to the highest quality, can only be of massive lasting benefit culturally, socially, academically and economically to the nation, and that is what the Greens are working for.

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure for me to rise tonight in the House and to speak on this very important legislation—the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 and the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 2004—which deals with the education of young people across this nation. The 18th century philosopher Rousseau once wrote:

quote.para: We are born weak, we need strength; helpless, we need aid; foolish, we need reason. All that we lack at birth, all that we need when we come to man's estate, is the gift of education.

speech.para: While society has of course developed significantly since then, these words still reflect the underlying importance of education. Education equips our young people with the skills to reach their potential and to shape our future. Education is our greatest investment for future success and prosperity.

From the outset I want to say how much I respect and admire the work of educators across this great nation. They are the great unsung heroes, and their work in teaching our nation's youth is a huge and critical responsibility—one that I know they take very seriously and undertake with great passion. The Howard government fully understand this—an understanding reflected in our strong track record in the area of education. Under this government, all schools have received greater support because we value their contribution to society. In every budget, and in grants to every state and territory for every year since 1996, school funding has increased.

This legislation builds on that foundation by continuing the two-pronged approach to education that has delivered real results to children in Australia. The first fundamental tenet that has underpinned our approach to education has been the provision of additional resources for Australian schools. In the next four years, the government will deliver over $31 billion to Australian schools. This is the largest ever funding commitment, and it is an increase of $8 billion on the previous four years. By increasing financial assistance to both government and non-government schools, particularly those serving the neediest communities, the government are playing their part in helping students get more from their education.

Over the next four years, state and territory governments will receive almost $10 billion in supplementary funding for their schools. This represents an increase of almost $2 billion over the previous period in this area—a product of the government's policy, which delivers increases of six per cent per annum. From next year, Catholic systemic schools will be fully integrated into the socioeconomic status funding model. This means that every non-government school in Australia, regardless of affiliation or denomination, will receive funding on the basis of the socioeconomic status of the communities they serve. As a result, Catholic systemic schools will share in over $12 billion over the next four years. Independent schools will continue to be funded according to the socioeconomic status model and will receive over $7 billion during the coming four years.

These funding arrangements demonstrate two key points of differentiation between the coalition government and Labor. The first is that under this government every student and every student's family in Australia will be financially supported, regardless of the school they attend. The second is that under this government no Australian school will have its funding cut.

The crux of the issue here is choice and the right of Australian parents to have that choice. This government supports the right of parents in my electorate and across the nation to choose the school that best meets their child's needs. Labor, in contrast, for some strange reason want to punish those parents that choose to send their children to a non-government school. They want to punish them by taking away valuable resources from children for their education.

In addition to this general funding, the Howard government is also investing more in specific programs designed to help those students that need a little extra help. The $2 billion Literacy, Numeracy and Special Learning Needs program has received an increase in funding of 25 per cent. This includes additional support for students in both government and non-government schools that need extra assistance. The new tuition credit initiative will provide help for those children that have not attained the minimum reading skills as measured by the year 3 national reading benchmark. Up to $700 worth of tuition will be available for students on a one-to-one basis out of school hours by appropriately qualified, screened and vetted tutors. Parents will be able to redeem their tuition credit to choose the most appropriate type of assistance for their children.

This initiative is an important and practical step in the government's work of ensuring that all students have the necessary fundamental skills in literacy and numeracy. However, as I mentioned earlier, these additional resources are only part of the equation. The second fundamental tenet of the coalition's approach to education is to make the country's investment in education work more smartly. We understand that we have a responsibility to ensure that our children get the most from the public investment in education. That means providing the right framework to achieve excellence and to promote performance outcomes. The success of introducing national literacy and numeracy benchmarks demonstrates the value of this kind of approach, and we are building on past achievements with these new measures. These measures will work to ensure our increased funding does deliver improved educational outcomes for our children.

The first initiative in this area is greater national consistency, which is something that I have spoken about before in this House. At present, for some antiquated and outdated reason, the education systems of each state and territory in this country differ markedly from each other in a range of ways. These are differences that cause enormous difficulties for over 80,000 students and their families who move interstate each year. This will finally begin to change under this reforming legislation. State and territory governments, along with school authorities, will have to agree to implement by 2010 a common school starting age and common testing standards. This will not only help address one of the challenges faced by those students who move interstate but will also ensure that all Australian students meet key educational benchmarks.

The second initiative is in the area of better reporting to parents. Too often, parents are not provided with a real understanding of their child's progress. Under the new funding conditions, school reports will be required to be written in plain language and include assessment of their achievement against national standards. Parents will also be provided with greater reporting about school performance. All schools will be required to publish school performance information. This will enable parents to assess schools comparatively and, where appropriate and where needed, better hold their school accountable. This information will include national literacy and numeracy benchmark achievement rates, year 12 results, school leaver destinations, staff and student retention rates and staff and student absenteeism rates.

The third initiative is greater autonomy for local schools. As I travel around to schools in my electorate, one thing that strikes me is their diversity—a diversity that needs to be acknowledged. Principals, teachers and the local school community are best placed to know how to best address the challenges their school faces. We need to give them the autonomy, support and encouragement to do just that. Of course, along with greater autonomy comes greater accountability. Parents cannot expect schools to be accountable for meeting targets when their hands are tied. This legislation provides local schools and principals with that much-needed flexibility to better achieve this.

The fourth initiative is creating safer schools for our schoolchildren. It is vital, if we are to ensure our children get the most from their education, that they feel safe and protected at school. All parents and teachers would agree that bullying is never acceptable, but not every school has a clear protocol in place for dealing with incidences of bullying when they occur. All schools will now be required to implement the national safe schools framework. This framework sets out the guiding principles for schools to follow in providing a safe learning environment.

The fifth initiative is ensuring a common commitment to physical activity. We have heard a lot lately about the increasing incidence of childhood obesity and the decreasing level of physical activity among our young people. These trends create a significant challenge for our society, particularly in the area of health and its impact. Under the new funding conditions, all students in the compulsory years of schooling will have to undertake a minimum of two hours of physical education as part of the curriculum. Again, this is a practical initiative aimed at getting real results for our children.

Finally, the sixth initiative is to emphasise the role of values, elevating that role to a core position as an even more important part of Australia's education system. The government will be seeking the states' and territories' endorsement of the national framework for values education in Australian schools. In addition, every school will be required to have a functioning flagpole and to fly the Australian flag. This is an initiative that many schools in my electorate and across Australia are already openly embracing.

These bills represent a comprehensive plan for reform of Australian school education over the next four years. It is a plan that not only invests additional resources in our local schools but also ensures our children get the maximum return. We hear a lot in this place about the importance of making positive change. Unfortunately, we also hear a lot of negative whingeing and whining from Labor when it comes to change of any kind. My view is that the initiatives in this legislation are another very positive step forward in supporting children, in supporting parents, in supporting educators to do even more great work in their daily lives. Nelson Mandela summed it up well when he said, `Education is the most powerful weapon you can use to change the world.' We in this place are charged with the responsibility of designing and establishing policies and initiatives that support positive change. We should get on with discharging this responsibility as a matter of urgency, for the benefit of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —It really surprises me to hear the member who preceded me quoting Nelson Mandela, because I think his interpretation of education and quality education is that it is for everybody, not just an elite few. Whilst I will not be voting against the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 and the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 2004, I do support the amendment that has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. In doing so I wish to place on record my disgust at the way in which the Howard government has managed education in Australia since it came into power. Australian families could be forgiven for believing that the Howard government has a vendetta against teachers who teach in public schools, against parents who send their children to public schools and against the 70 per cent of students who attend those public schools.

speech.para: In the Shortland electorate over 80 per cent of students attend public schools. Under the Howard government, they have been continually disadvantaged. That is not right. Education should be quality education for all children. It should not be differentiated. It is an absolute disgrace that an Australian government would favour one section of students. Under this government, unfortunately, there has been a favouring of those students who attend private schools, particularly if that private school happens to be an elite private school.

The Howard government would have to be the most conservative government in Australia in the last 40 years. It has set about implementing its conservative agenda. Part of that conservative agenda it hopes to achieve through education, spending 70 per cent of the education budget on the 30 per cent of students that attend private schools. That is not acceptable. This government talks about choice and about providing choice to people to attend the school of their choice and to attend private school. I would argue that choice has to be real choice. Choice has to be choice that links into availability—availability of those elite private schools. I can assure the House that there is not one of those elite private schools within the Hunter or within the Central Coast of New South Wales, which is the area that the Shortland electorate covers. Choice to attend private schools also has an income association. Fees in some of these elite private schools are as high as $15,000 a year. It is well and truly outside the capacity of many families within the Shortland electorate and other electorates throughout Australia to be able to afford to send their children to these schools.

I have done a bit of research on the income levels of families whose children attend private schools and families whose children attend public schools. Both at primary and secondary level, public schools have a larger proportion of students who come from low-income families. In public schools 42 per cent of students come from low-income families, whilst in private schools that figure is around the 20 per cent mark. If you were to look at the elite private schools, that would be further differentiated. When I look at that and at the government's argument of choice and providing families and students with choice, I would argue pretty strongly that that choice is not real choice. A much smaller proportion of students in public schools come from high-income families than in private schools. In fact 47 per cent of students in private schools are from high-income families whilst only 21 per cent of students in public schools are from high-income families. It becomes a socioeconomic issue. It is all about fairness and access to education. If the government is pushing its funds into private schools, it is favouring private schools and 30 per cent of students—the majority of whom come from high-income families—attend those schools, it sounds to me very much like we have a very elitist system developing within this country.

King's School have had a 165 per cent increase in their funding over the period 2001-04 under the government's SES funding formula. I have to say that that does not sit well with me, particularly when I have schools in my electorate like Belmont High School. They have contacted me because they need over $3 million in major capital works over a three-year period. However, things have changed a little since I received their letter detailing the facts of what they need. There was a fire at the school and one of the buildings was completely destroyed. This has caused enormous distress for the teachers, the pupils and the families of those pupils. I would like to congratulate the school and everybody involved in that school community on the way they have worked together to try and get over the great drama and devastation that they felt at the loss of that building and the way that has interfered with students preparing for their HSC exams. Belmont High School also need a multipurpose centre, a performing arts centre, technology access, building modification, upgrade of staffing facilities, upgrade of electrics to sustain the IT expansion that is needed, paraprofessionals to help the teachers with the bureaucratic functions and allow them to concentrate more on what they are trained to do—that is, to teach the students—and additional general assistance to help in the maintenance of the school. They also need additional staff for support programs—programs that the Howard government is placing emphasis on. It is a school that is no longer fit for its purpose of C21 learning.

I would argue that the students who attend Belmont High School should not be disadvantaged in the way that they have been under this government. Warners Bay Public School is another school that contacted me. They have very limited resources, particularly in the language field, and they need more access to TVs and DVDs. The kinds of things that develop their learning and knowledge are probably a little more important than the cricket pitches, playing fields and extra swimming pools that have been built within some of the elite category 1 schools. They need more reading resources, covered walkways, PA systems and a full-time computer consultant. The list goes on and on.

It makes me very angry that schools in the Shortland electorate are going without, and will continue to go without under this legislation, whilst schools such as King's thrive. It is not about providing more playing fields and better sporting facilities; it is about ensuring that the students I represent in this parliament have access to a quality education, an education that will ensure they have equal opportunity in life.

Another indication of some of the differences in the level of funding is that, in the 2004 federal recurrent funding, public primary schools received $539 per student and the wealthiest private schools received $830 per student. In public secondary schools, the funding was $803 per student. In the wealthiest private schools, it was $1,099. I say that that is not good enough. I say that the students I represent in this parliament deserve an equal deal. They do not deserve to be treated as second-class citizens. The Howard government's approach to education is consistent with its general philosophy, its approach to life and what it believes should be the order—that is, if you have everything, you should have more; wealthier people in our community deserve more; if you are an average student from a wealthy family, you deserve the best education money can buy; if you are a brilliant student from a poor family, a working-class family or just an ordinary Australian family, you deserve a second-class education. The cake is for the wealthy and the friends of the Howard government and the crumbs from the table are for the 70 per cent of students who attend public schools—and it is 80 per cent of students within the Shortland electorate. I do not believe that that is good enough.

I do not believe that schools within the Shortland electorate should be disadvantaged to the tune that they are disadvantaged. If the Howard government gave the same amount of federal funding to public schools that it does to private schools, what would that mean for the schools in the Shortland electorate? For Belmont High School, it would mean nearly $3 million. For Belmont North Public School, it would be in excess of $500,000. For Belmont Public School, it would be in excess of $1 million. For Blacksmiths Public School, it would be in excess of $250,000. For Budgewoi Public School, it would be nearly $2 million. For Caves Beach Public School, it would be in excess of $1.2 million. For Charlestown Eastern Public School, it would be in excess of $700,000. For Charlestown Public School, it would be in excess of $600,000. For Dudley Public School, it would be in excess of $500,000. For Eleebana Public School, it would be in excess of $1.2 million. For Floraville Public School, it would be in excess of $1.3 million. For Gateshead Public School, it would be in excess of $400,000. For Windale Public School, which is the school in the most disadvantaged area in the Shortland electorate, it would be in excess of $700,000. There are many schools that I could detail, but if I do that I will run out of time.

But the message is that those 80 per cent of students who attend the quality public schools in my electorate, with the dedicated teachers and parents who work, run raffles and do everything that they can just to get the basic equipment for the schools, deserve the same share of the education dollar from this federal government as those elite public schools. In fact, they deserve more because they are struggling. The kids who go to those schools deserve the same opportunities in life as those children who go to the King's School, Shore or whatever elite private school it might be. Students should not be disadvantaged. Education is our future, and if we have one group of students getting a quality education and another getting a second-class education it is not very good for the future of Australia.

The Howard government's record in supporting public schools, as I have just demonstrated, has been appalling. It is worthwhile reviewing some of its performances since it was elected. It is definitely shown by private schools. I think I have demonstrated that most adequately so far. Some of the measures that have been introduced include the abolition of the new non-government school policy. There have been huge increases in funding to private schools. There has been the introduction of the new SES funding model, biased to the more wealthy private schools, and establishment grants to encourage the growth of private schools. I think that this is really a condemnation of the Howard government. What it has done to education since it came to power should be more than enough to see it voted out of office at the next election. We have heard the Minister for Education, Science and Training stand up here and make light of the real concerns of the people who come and visit me on a daily basis, people who are concerned about the fact that their school does not have the most basic of equipment. Their concern is that this Howard government is showing such a preference for the wealthiest schools, and that really makes me annoyed.

More than 50 of the wealthiest schools got an increase of $1 million over the last four years. Another thing I found quite interesting within the Central Coast area—in the electorate of Robertson, adjoining my electorate—was that there has been a decline in the number of students attending private schools. But that decline was not followed with a decline in funding to those schools; in fact they received an increase. Unfortunately it does not work that way for public schools, as we all know in this House. I think it is really important to note that over the years, as a nation, we have valued public education. Public education is the key to a successful future for this country. I think it is time that the Howard government rethought its approach to education with it spending so much money on students going to private schools and so little on those attending public schools. Public schools are inclusive; it is education for everyone. By investing in public education we are investing in democracy and in the future.

The Howard government's record speaks for itself. The sad thing about the Howard government's record on education is that it spells missed opportunity for Australia. The success of a nation is determined by the level of education and skill of its population. It should be quality education for all. We should be ensuring that the best and brightest students have the ability to fulfil their potential. They should be able to access education because of their ability, not because of their ability to pay. In the world we live in now, in a global economy, if we are going to be a successful nation it is so important that we have this educated and highly skilled work force, and that is only achieved by ensuring that our kids have the ability to get that quality education. We do not need a society where we have an underclass. We do not need a society that fits in with the Howard government's picture of the world.

The Labor Party recognises this, and that is why we have given the commitment to fund all schools based on need. Labor will significantly increase funds to public schools and redistribute money from the wealthy private schools to the needy Catholic and independent schools. We will ensure the certainty of a quality education for everyone. We will ensure that public education is not second-class education but is given the respect and resources it needs. Incentives will be put in place for the most experienced teachers to continue to work within the system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 and the related States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. I come to this chamber with a passion for local and community education. Very recently I had the fortune to walk 500 kilometres around my electorate over a period of 19 days. That walk was based on raising awareness of and funds for juvenile diabetes. At the heart of the walk were visits to 51 schools around the Mornington Peninsula, Westernport and Bass Coast. To see so many primary, secondary, government, non-government, Christian and ecumenical schools together in such a short period of time gave me a unique sense of the quality, worth and energy of education within my area. Whether it was Tootgarook Primary School, San Remo Primary School, Rye Primary School, Dromana Secondary College, Rosebud Secondary College or many of the other schools, there was a great commitment from the teaching staff, the students and the parenting community to the worth and quality of the education provided for students.

speech.para: Having looked at the schools in my electorate, I want to start my speech by talking about a very simple principle, and that is that a commitment made should be a commitment honoured. It is with great regret that I raise in the House the fact that it now appears that the Somerville Secondary College, which was promised two years ago by the Victorian government for delivery at the commencement of 2005, will not be built until 2006. Over 130 families have enrolled their children in the school. For the town it is a critical part of bringing and binding Somerville together—not just Somerville but also Tyabb and Baxter. The towns need that school. It is a school which was promised and to which the Commonwealth has committed and paid over $2 billion. That money is in the bank, waiting to be used, waiting for the school to be started.
