A newspaper from my electorate this week carried the heading `Delay on new high school'. The opening paragraph read:

quote.para: A secret briefing between council officers and the education department last week was advised that Somerville Secondary College will not be built until 2006.

speech.para: For two years now 130 families have relied on the promise that the school would be available. A community has relied on the promise of the Victorian government that a school would be available. That promise has been breached, the faith has been broken and the school will not be built. The school will be a year late. By then the $2 million will have sat there for three years with no action. A site which is bare, vacant, ready for action and ready for commencement tomorrow remains inactive. Not a sod has been turned; not a hole has been dug.

My message is very simple. It is the same message that the community will be giving out in a week. That message is: `Mr Bracks, keep your promise; build our school now.' Along with the Westernport Basketball Association, I will be holding a community rally for Somerville Secondary College on Sunday, 15 August 2004, between 1 p.m. and 2 p.m., at the Somerville Recreation and Community Centre—or the basketball stadium, as it is known. We will be doing that as a community, to lay down the very principle that a commitment given should be a commitment honoured. That is a very simple principle.

Within my electorate of Flinders we have a critical need for an educational commitment to be honoured. We have a critical need within the town of Somerville and the related towns of Tyabb and Baxter for the Somerville Secondary College to be provided now, not just for the students but also to provide the missing link in the development of Somerville as a close-knit and tight community. It is a critical need. It was one which was promised two years ago. It was one which we have been assured repeatedly will be delivered, and it will not be. We will do all that we can to ensure that the students, parents and residents of Somerville have that school and that it is delivered now—in time for 2005. Anything less would be an utter and total breach of faith.

Against that background, I want to look at the larger picture presented by these bills. These bills jointly achieve a very simple thing: they help to deliver $31.3 billion for schools, from the Commonwealth, over the coming quadrennium. It is an increase of $8 billion over the current quadrennium, or four-year period. It is the largest funding commitment to Australian schools in Australian history. Above all else, it enshrines a series of principles. The first principle is that parents have the right to choose the type of education and the type of school that they want for their children. The second is that every child is entitled to some form of assistance from the government in the process and passage of education.

We do not impose on children from upper income families barriers to going to state schools. We do not impose penalties on children who attend Catholic or other non-government schools. But we do fund on the basis of need; we do recognise on the basis of need. That is why, on a per child basis, there is a dramatically higher proportion of public funds which go to fund public education. It is a simple, clear, undeniable fact. It can be obfuscated and abused, but the fact is simple: on a per capita basis the overwhelming balance of funds goes from public sources to public schools. That is right; it is proper. It is not proper that there should be no funding at all. It is not right that there should be no funding for entire groups of students, many of whom come from double-income families where both parents are working hard simply to help their children attend the school of the parents' choice. The third principle is that the legislation strengthens schools and builds national consistency. The fourth principle contained in this legislation is that it renews the government's commitment to school education for the next four years.

Looking at the reality of what is proposed in these bills, I simply want to highlight a few key points. Firstly, as I mentioned, there will be $31.3 billion for schools across Australia over the period 2005-08. Secondly, there is a significant increase in state school funding in the next four years. There will be $9.8 billion in supplementary funding to state governments for schools, an increase of $1.9 billion. Of that, $7.2 billion will be in recurrent grants. That is a 28 per cent increase over a four-year period in recurrent grants. That is a great step forward. Thirdly, on the Catholic school front, we will see the delivery of $12.6 billion over the next four years to the neediest of the non-government schools. As a result, Catholic schools will receive $362 million more as a collective. I think that is a tremendously important initiative. Fourthly, there will be an increase in funding for independent schools. Fifthly, in terms of special purpose grants, there is an increase in funding for literacy and numeracy, on the basis that they are the foundation of learning and knowledge going forward. Those are the important steps that are contained within these two legislative actions.

I came to this House with a passion for and commitment to education. I recently had the opportunity to visit, in one three-week period, 51 of the schools within my own electorate and to work with kids who contributed so much to other children by fundraising for juvenile diabetes. I am proud of their work, and I commend them, whether they are from Dromana secondary, Rosebud secondary, Kooweerup secondary or any of the other many schools in the electorate. But I conclude by noting that there is a gap. Somerville secondary college needs to be built. The community deserves to have it built. It was promised that it would be built. It should be built. For that reason, I say to the Victorian government: honour your promise and build our school now.

talk.start.para: —In his announcement Schools Assistance (Learning Together—Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004, the Prime Minister made a great fuss in this chamber about every school in Australia having a flagpole. That was to be one of the conditions for receiving federal funding. That statement caused me a great deal of worry because many schools in the Fowler electorate, which I represent, do not have a working flagpole. They have an Australian flag and they display it proudly, but, for reasons that I will explain, they do not have a working flagpole.

speech.para: I should add that schools in the Fowler electorate are among the most disadvantaged schools in Australia. They have high numbers of children from low-income families, they have high numbers of children from families that do not speak English at home, and there are many children who are living with only one parent. In a lot of cases, they are living with grandparents. So I was alarmed by the announcement which could mean that those most disadvantaged schools in our system could miss out on federal funding. That would be a tragedy. But what the Prime Minister's announcement shows is just how wrong this government's priorities are and what a disaster they are for children in many parts of Australia.

To explain why, I should tell the House a story told to me about a typical school and its flagpole. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, members can provide an Australian flag to schools and other organisations in their electorate. The member was happy to meet the request of the principal of a local school, who phoned to say that she had arranged for a new flagpole to be erected at the school. She asked if the member could attend a special function to present an Australian flag and to have the flag raised on the new flagpole. When the appointed day came along, the member arrived at the school, where he was met with some very disappointing news: the previous night, a less than civic-minded citizen had cut and removed the rope from the flagpole.

The ceremony went ahead, with the member presenting the flag to the school, but, as the students could not raise the flag, they proudly held it out for the assembled students to see. As the story goes, it was one of those wonderful occasions when the children sang Give Me a Home among the Gum Trees and the lovely Bruce Woodley song I am Australian. I will not sing the song—I have a shocking singing voice—but I am sure you know the words, and I am sure those words bring a lump to your throat too. Of course, the children also sang the national anthem.

The principal was very upset and was determined to have a working flagpole. To replace the rope cost only a few dollars, but the problem was how to get the rope through the pulley at the top of the flagpole. While some of the year 6 students volunteered to climb the pole, the principal ruled that out as it could be too dangerous. So, from the school's minor maintenance budget, the principal paid for a new rope and the hire of a cherry picker to replace the stolen halyard at a cost of over $200, and for a few days the school proudly flew its Australian flag.

Members might have already guessed what happened next: the same or another less than civic-minded citizen returned to the school to cut and remove the rope again. The principal was in despair. What should she do? She could have spent another $200, knowing that almost certainly the rope would be stolen again. More importantly, she could think of many other urgent projects to spend her minor maintenance budget on—things which affected the safety of students and staff, or repairs to much-needed equipment. Wisely, she chose to leave the flagpole ropeless. She placed the school's Australian flag on the stage of the school's small assembly room, where it still flies today safe and secure.

When I visit schools for their end-of-year assemblies, the Australian flag is there in the hall. The children sing Give Me a Home among the Gum Trees, they bring a lump to my throat when they sing `I am, you are, we are Australian,' and of course they sing the national anthem. They are proud and patriotic schools—but many do not have a flagpole. The teachers are some of the most dedicated that I have met—but their schools do not have a flagpole. The students work hard to overcome their disadvantages and they achieve good results—but their schools do not have a flagpole. The minister would have us think that these schools do not deserve federal funding. That tells me a lot about how wrong-thinking the legislation we are debating tonight is.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Last Wednesday evening, a full house of 300 locals gathered at the Geebung Zillmere RSL Memorial Services Club to talk about prostate cancer with specialist urologist Dr Peter Heathcote and the Queensland Institute of Medical Research's Christine Borthwick.

speech.para: The aim of the evening was to put the facts on the table and take the mystery out of what is too often secret men's business. I wish to thank the Geebung Zillmere RSL club for providing the rooms for the evening. I guess we were all surprised by the huge turnout, with about 50 people standing in addition to the 300 that were seated. The success of the night shows there is an incredible interest and quest for knowledge out there for information on prostate cancer. While the audience was mainly 300 blokes, there were about 30 wives, girlfriends and daughters attending. I know from the calls coming into my office that many wives and partners were just as enthusiastic about the event as the men were.

At my invitation, Dr Peter Heathcote agreed to speak at the forum, in an effort to spread the word amongst a key group at risk—men over 50. Men over 50 with a first-degree relative who has had prostate cancer are three times more at risk than men on average. On average, one in 10 men will experience prostate cancer and, on average, if someone has a first-degree relative who has had prostate cancer they are three times more likely to experience it. Doug Sparkes, a local who is fighting his own battle against prostate cancer, found the evening very informative. He said, `The thing with prostate cancer is that unless you are tested you may never know you have got it.' There should be more interest in prostate cancer and more information. He said, as we all know, that it is `as big a killer of men as breast cancer is of women.' That is a strong case for much more public awareness about both these dreadful cancers.

It was good to see many others come along, particularly family members. Sisters Karen Maguire and Michelle Eales attended for their father, who is also fighting prostate cancer. They said they came along in support of their family, so that they could better understand the disease and help their mum and dad. As Michelle said: `I'm a hairdresser and women come in all the time and will tell you about their problems, but that's not the case with men. A lot of men don't say how they feel, and they suffer in silence. Let me tell you, not talking about it doesn't help at all.' More information is needed, which is why the federal government will, I hope, in the not too distant future put its full weight behind a much needed public awareness campaign about prostate cancer in our community.

I would also like to remark on today's events. Today the Howard government has been forced to admit that it would have clawed back the promised $600 budget bonus for families after the election by cutting future increases in fortnightly family benefits. It is about time that the Howard government put Australia first, instead of playing politics with the lives of families and the financial support that goes to them. Through the cuts, which have been the centrepiece of this year's budget, the $600 bonus was to be eroded in five to seven years. I know that members opposite would not even be aware of the sneaky clawback clause that was put into the legislation. So now, after months of denying there was a clawback, the Minister for Family and Community Services was today back-pedalling, saying special legislation is now required—admitting what Labor has been saying for months and admitting to the Senate that special legislation will be required to stop this sneaky clawback.

Despite the minister's weasel words, it is clear that the government always intended to claw back benefits after the election. The clauses contained in the legislation rushed through the parliament after the budget would not have been drafted in this way unless the government wanted a mechanism to claw back the payments after the election. The truth is that the Howard government wanted to play Santa Claus before the election, only to be Scrooge afterwards. The clawback shows the Howard government is up to its old tricks, using sneaky indexation clauses to claw back money from the pockets of ordinary workers.

This is yet another example of the Howard government putting its political interests before the long-term interests of Australian families. Australian families need a family payment system which is accurate and which delivers generous payments regularly and which does not leave them with a long-term debt. One in three of all Australian families have a debt in the family payment system—those debts are currently averaging $900. Because of the 27 payments in this financial year, next financial year that average debt could head to $1,300 and upwards. It is yet another example of the Howard government not being frank with Australian families about the extent to which its family payment system gives them debts. That is why we need a Latham Labor government committed to generous, timely and regular family payments which substantially eliminate the risk of debt in the family payment system.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on behalf of the Hunter After Hours GP service, which has been running in my local area since 1999. By way of background, in 1997 I was approached by local doctors to help establish an after-hours medical service near Maitland Hospital to provide medical treatment and advice and. in particular, to reduce the out of hours pressure on the 237 local doctors. We were successful in gaining funding for a trial of the GP access after-hours service to be based at Maitland Hospital and later the service was expanded throughout the Hunter region and is funded by the Australian Government at $6.5 million each year.

speech.para: Since October 1999, almost 85,000 people have been through the service as in-patients, seeking treatment for lacerations, soft tissue injuries, allergic reactions, fractures, infections, foreign bodies in eyes, and colds and flu. Almost 67,000 people have obtained medical advice from the hotline, another 800 have had a home visit by a doctor, and there have been 580 funded transport operations to the hospital. This year alone, 40,000 patients have seen a GP after hours, 45,000 people have called the telephone hotline service for medical advice, 560 patients have received home visits from the GP service and there have been 330 funded transport arrangements to the hospital.

The after-hours GP service was and still is a good idea. I applaud the Howard government for giving it its start and for contributing around $12 million over the last four years. I believe in this service and am absolutely committed to it. When the contracts for the funding of this service were drafted, there was a requirement that an evaluation be carried out prior to the Australian government recommitting the funding.

I have no problem with a review of this service. All programs which receive Commonwealth funding and taxpayer investment should be evaluated to ensure that they are meeting the needs of the community and that they are cost effective. The issue is, however, that the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice say the service will be closed in March 2005 if funding is not renewed before the end of the year. Why? Because the contract also specifies, rightly so, that this service must not operate in deficit.

At the moment, without a commitment to funding beyond June 2005, the budget will blow out because the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice is prudently factoring in staff entitlements in the event of the service closing down. That truncates around 10 weeks of running costs from the current financial year budget. I want to see this service continue uninterrupted. It is a service that is popular with the patients and is used the way it was designed to be used—for ailments and injuries which cannot wait but do not necessarily need to be presented to an emergency room.

The Access After Hours Service is also useful for our local nursing homes. It means a doctor can visit a nursing home out of hours rather than a resident being transported by ambulance to the hospital. Tonight I am calling on the Minister for Health and Ageing to ensure that this service will continue to operate past March 2005. An evaluation of the service is due, but the results need to be taken on board. I do not believe there is enough time left to do this properly before the next budget, so I want the review to take place sooner rather than later to give both doctors and patients some security with the service. It has been a great model of service to patients and support to doctors. In a regional area this service is something we can be very proud of and should continue to support. However, I have been personally disappointed with the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice and their personal attacks on me in the Hunter media on this issue, despite the fact that I have always supported and will continue to support this service. Why? Because it benefits my constituents and the practitioners alike. Of the 85,000 people who have used this service, around 10 per cent live in Paterson. The other 90 per cent come from the Hunter, Shortland, Charlton and Newcastle.

I ran into the Minister for Health and Ageing yesterday and mentioned the `intense and nonstop efforts of the Hunter Labor MPs', as printed in the Newcastle Herald, attributed to Dr Arn Sprogis from the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice. He said he had a couple of very soft letters but had not been contacted personally by the above mentioned members. I am disappointed but not surprised. I stand here alone, defending the access to the after hours service. Again I say that this valued after-hours GP service provides a necessary and quality service that meets the requirements of my constituents. In conclusion, on behalf of my constituents I call on the minister to listen to the Hunter community, evaluate the service now and keep providing the funding to keep it going beyond March next year and operating in confidence.

talk.start.para: —This Friday marks the annual Jeans for Genes Day, a day which is very well known to all of us for promoting the recognition of rare genetic disorders and for raising awareness about the need to conduct research and find cures for people who suffer from rare genetic conditions. Tonight I want to talk about a family in my electorate of Calwell whose little boy Sammy Joe Liistro suffers from a rare genetic disorder called trichothiodystrophy. It is so rare that Sammy Joe is one of only 14 children to have this condition in Australia. Sammy Joe's mother, Maria, recently came to see me to seek my assistance in her battle to raise awareness about her son's condition and to also hope to pursue a better quality of life for him. Maria has written a letter to all federal members of parliament and she has asked me to read this letter. It states:

quote.para: Dear Members of Parliament

I am writing this letter as a parent of a child who has a critical illness in the form of a rare genetic illness called Trichothiodystrophy, which means that any exposure to UV light is potentially fatal due to the severe irreparable damage that it causes. This exposure to UV light breaks down his DNA killing the cells and destroying his immune system. This impact on his immune system means that he is susceptible to frequent infections, which have often led to hospitalisation and on occasions have placed Sammy Joe in a critical condition. The effects of Trichothiodystrophy are fatal and as a result my son's life expectancy and quality are greatly reduced. If he goes out into the sun he screams with pain, his hair falls out, his skin blisters, he becomes nauseous and becomes bedridden. (This happens even when my son is fully clothed)

After 14 agonizing years I went to the United States, which finally led to the correct diagnosis of this disorder. Sammy Joe finally received the medical care that he needed. The medication that the American doctors prescribed had a remarkably instantaneous impact on my son's life. Upon arriving back to Australia I found that Sammy Joe was continually let down by the Australian medical system to the point that his current quality of life was at risk to the level that a further deterioration could lead to death. It further frustrates me that the simplest of medical care in the form of the correct medications for my son is currently in jeopardy because of doctors' lack of understanding. The doctors here are failing to follow up on the most basic medical advice given to them by the experts in America. It has been noted by a leading Geneticist that we have reached the limits of our current medical knowledge and that there isn't enough funding to do research on this disorder. There are 13 other children in Australia that are suffering from this condition.
This situation needs to change immediately. It is not acceptable and I'm not going to put up with it. Research needs to be funded right now to alleviate the suffering of children with this condition.

speech.para: Two years ago in this House we debated and voted on the stem cells research bill. Many members who supported this bill, and I was one of those members, did so because we believed that this legislation would give people like Sammy Joe Liistro hope of finding a cure for their rare genetic disorders. I hold faith and look forward to Australian medical scientists, like their counterparts in America, being able to continue to conduct the necessary research into rare genetic disorders such as trichothiodystrophy so that cures can be found for kids like Sammy Joe Liistro.

Sammy Joe Liistro is a special child, but he also has a very special family and, indeed, an extraordinary mother. Maria Liistro wants her son to have the best possible quality of life: to be able to get out of bed every morning, to enjoy life, to attend school and, as Sammy Joe constantly says to her, `to make the hurt go away'. Efforts have been made to improve Sammy Joe's quality of life, but it is obvious that more research is required into this very rare genetic disorder. I would like to encourage Australian scientists, doctors and geneticists who are interested in conducting research in this area to take a particular interest in trichothiodystrophy because, even though only 14 children may suffer from this condition in this country today, it is so difficult to diagnose that it is possible that a lot of other kids may have this condition and go undiagnosed. Incidentally, as rare as it is, Australia is the only country in the world that has such a great number of people suffering from this genetic disorder. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, if I illegally accessed your bank account, I would be charged with a criminal offence and probably jailed. The reason for me saying that and rising here tonight is to illustrate and raise within this forum the way in which the Child Support Agency is—criminally, in my view—not only removing money from people's bank accounts but not allowing those people to undertake the process that is built into legislation to prove to the Child Support Agency within a 28-day period that they do not owe that money.

speech.para: The Child Support Agency are not only taking the money out of the bank accounts of individuals; they are actually giving it to the payee before the payer—who has had it removed from his account in this case—has an opportunity to prove that it did not need to be removed nor was it in fact appropriate and legal to remove it. Let me read to the House a letter from one of my constituents. I have in fact written to the appropriate minister about this constituent and another constituent. This particular letter is to the Child Support Agency. I will not refer to the constituent, nor will I refer to the constituent in the second case. The letter reads:

quote.para: I object in the strongest possible terms to the heavy handed tactics that you have applied to me in your THEFT of my tax return that you advised me of last week.

I received a letter from your agency dated 10th July, 2004 in which you gave me 28 days' time in which to lodge an objection to your assessment of alleged monies owed by me to the ex-wife of $4,766.71. I lodged my objection today—

speech.para: today being 23 July—

quote.para: well within this twenty-eight day period. Today I also received written advice from your agency that you have already taken MY tax return of $2,895.14, and paid the ex-wife this amount before the expiry of the objection period. I would have thought that you would have at least held this in trust until such time had elapsed to even see if I lodged an objection, and then after that until you assessed such an objection. To add insult to injury I also paid last month's Child Support today, too. My calculations clearly show that I only owe the ex-wife $621.90 as you will see when you get that correspondence.

I want to know how you propose to pay the balance back to me in a lump sum now that you have already paid out the money. I immediately rang your agency and spoke to someone who only identified himself ... as Joel. He told me after speaking to a supervisor that my tax refund had already been paid to my ex-wife, and that there was nothing that I could do about this. He also told me that the $2,895.14 that you have STOLEN from me may be able to be recompensed month by month at the rate of say $40 per month. (What a joke). If this happens I will simply not pay any Child Support until such time as you catch up with what you owe me. If you can remove funds in a lump sum like this then I consider that I am well within my rights to do likewise.
I now DEMAND that you re-assess this matter and write to me advising me of what you propose to do to rectify this matter.

speech.para: It gets worse. Another person who believes that he is not in arrears had $9,000 removed from his bank account. I believe the Child Support Agency has been grossly negligent in that case by failing to acknowledge my constituent's complaints, failing to properly consider the court orders imposed in 1989 before imposing additional child support payments on him, losing court documents sent to them and then claiming this large sum of money as arrears from his bank account without proper authority. The CSA is still to examine these court documents—the ones that my constituent sent in 1997—but the CSA conveniently lost those documents. It needs to have them to determine whether or not my constituent in fact owes money and whether his payments have been calculated correctly. I firmly believe that, under the orders put in place by a court in 1989, the constituent, since he left work in 1990, should only have been paying a certain amount of money and not what the Child Support Agency said he should be paying. Rather than being in arrears, based on that information I am assuming that my constituent has in fact paid more than the court requires him to. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to register my disappointment with some local Tasmanian Liberal senators in response to the so-called energy white paper, Securing Australia's energy future, which I think should be more aptly named Securing Australia's traditional energy future. What disappoints me is that not only have they sought to be straight out apologists for this rather regressive energy white paper but they have also undermined the actual renewable energy industry in Tasmania, most notably wind power and hydro. I am speaking particularly about Senator Abetz and my more local Liberal senator, Richard Colbeck.

speech.para: I noticed very early in the piece, around 1 July, that Senator Abetz as per usual went on the ABC as an apologist for the government without consideration of the facts of the case in relation to the government's refusal to accept the recommendation of the Tambling report to increase and/or at least maintain the current MRET level until 2010 and even beyond. Senator Abetz suggested that employment in the agriculture, fishing, quarrying, mining and forestry sectors in Tasmania would be adversely affected by an increased MRET losing up to—he claimed—2,400 jobs and up to 113,000 jobs Australia-wide. Not only are these figures totally and utterly exaggerated but at no time do we actually get a quotation of the source for these figures. What is also disappointing is that Senator Colbeck later in the piece regurgitated these exaggerated, unsubstantiated figures.

The irony of all of this is that the energy in the sectors mentioned is predominantly derived from diesel, as people in this House no doubt know, and it bears no relationship to MRET. Yet, of course, Senator Abetz goes on his merry way to purport these outrageous claims about so-called job losses if there is an MRET increase. Senator Colbeck continued this perverted presentation of potential job losses and also alleged substantial increased costs in electricity in a report in the Advocate newspaper of 29 July. He said that an increased MRET would mean higher electricity prices for Tasmanian households and businesses. Senator Colbeck said:

quote.para: The European experience had shown that an increased MRET of up to 20p.c.—

speech.para: yet the MRET increase that was being discussed was five per cent, but he said 20 per cent—

quote.para: delivered power prices up to 3.6 times more than in Australia.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: So if a Tasmanian household has an average annual power bill of $1500, under a 20p.c. MRET level that exists in Denmark, they could possibly face a power bill of about $5400.

speech.para: Further, he said:

quote.para: And under an 8p.c. MRET level that exists in Germany they could possibly face a power bill of about $3750.

speech.para: So what we have is a completely different MRET system in Europe and different energy costs. When this is then compared to Tasmania and current electricity prices, he comes up with this gobbledygook. I recommend that Senator Colbeck and Senator Abetz go and look at some of the information and references available to assist them to come to a more considered estimate of the non-job losses that would result from an MRET increase of five per cent and also the noneffect on GDP. Also, of course, they would see a potential convergence of cost in energy with coal and gas by 2020 if we had an MRET increase, even to the level of five per cent. I suggest that they come and see me and I will give them at least three or four good references that they can use instead of undermining an important industry in Tasmania. Undermining the strong possibility of a blade manufacturing plant on the north-west coast of Tasmania is what it means if the MRET is not increased—(Time expired)

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
Mr BILLSON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to rise tonight in the few minutes that are available before stumps at today's sitting of parliament to talk about how the government's Medicare enhancement package is delivering benefits for the community that I represent. It comes as no surprise to anybody that I am particularly interested in this matter. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, the community that I have the great honour to represent is a growing area in terms of population influx, particularly in the Langwarrin area and Mornington East. We are seeing an increasing population at a time when we are frankly struggling to attract new doctors to our area as a consequence of this doctor shortage that has placed some pressure on some of the health services and particularly on the current doctors in our area to provide for the level of care local residents rightly expect and seek.

speech.para: Fortunately, the measures to enhance the Medicare system that the government has implemented are very responsive to those local conditions. Incentives to attract doctors to our community to either join an existing practice or relocate or establish a practice in our area is seeing doctors coming into our community and adding to the stock of talent that we have available to service local health needs. The incentives for practice nurses, as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, are a great way of making sure that doctors are doctoring. Practice nurses can attend to other issues such as wound management, taking blood pressure and histories of some patients and immunisation tasks.

The safety net itself sees a great deal of support and peace of mind provided to people with chronic illnesses or some quite significant health incident that sees out-of-pocket non-hospital expenses. This feature has been with the Medicare system ever since it was introduced. It is a feature that Labor has just been happy to see continue and roll on, but it is a feature that has often cost some members of our community quite an amount of expense. There is now a safety net in place to assist citizens that have those health requirements and incur those out-of-hospital, out-of-pocket expenses.

The increased rebate for GPs when they are treating concession card holders and children is also delivering benefits. Incorporating other practitioners—physiotherapists, dentists and the like—in a GP managed care plan for a chronic illness or condition is another positive measure. All of that good work is going on at a time when the Labor Party wants to talk about access to doctors in my community without offering anything at all that would actually bring about change. In fact, I would say that the Labor health policy is a placebo. There is no active ingredient whatsoever to respond to the actual conditions on the ground in the community that I represent.

Simply paying everybody more of a rebate is not going to see doctors in inner Melbourne or on the North Shore of Sydney choose to come and settle in the greater Frankston and Mornington Peninsula area. You are more likely to get a bulk-billing consultation in inner Melbourne than you are in my community because of the increased number of doctors for the population in those areas. Simply paying everybody more as a doctor's consultation subsidy through the Medicare system is not going to encourage doctors to change where they are located. That is what the Labor Party seems not to understand, but it is something that the community that I represent very much recognises. While the Labor Party are masquerading some concern, they are not offering anything that will actually make a difference.

Worse than that, right at this very moment the Labor Party at a state and federal level are actually undermining the work that many of us are putting in to improve health services. I talk about the after-hours access to GPs program. The federal government has asked the state government to identify service centres that should attract some of that financial assistance. The Frankston Medicentre, which has been operating for two decades quite successfully and which is now experiencing some financial pressure as it has to attract doctors to participate in that program, was on the original submission from the Bracks government. But guess what happened? It has fallen off. The Bracks state Labor government, with either the adherence or the indifference of local state members of parliament, has seen the Frankston Medicentre fall off, to be replaced with the Williamstown Hospital in the Premier's own electorate. Either that is an appalling oversight or error, or it is just simply playing politics with the health needs of our community. I call on the Labor Party to either get out of the way or support my work to improve access to health services for the Dunkley community.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —In a very short period of time Australians will be asked to go to the polls. Many issues are very important to them, but one of the issues which I believe will be uppermost in the minds of many when they cast their vote, especially the people in the electorate of Oxley, is the future of Australia's education system. All Australians quite rightly expect an education system that is second to none. That is why we in the Australian Labor Party have always been, and always will be, committed to building and maintaining an education system that is world class. Labor believes in providing quality education for all children, regardless of the school they attend, because a first-rate education is essential to ensure that Australia fosters a nation of achievers who will lead us throughout the 21st century. That is great news for the schools in my local area, which will benefit greatly under the policies of the Australian Labor Party.

speech.para: I recently received a series of letters from some of my constituents who are concerned about education funding. They indicated to me that a quality education system is extremely important to them. I agree with them. Let me assure these people, and indeed all the people of my electorate, that everyone in the Australian Labor Party considers a quality education system to be of paramount importance. A Latham Labor government would ensure that all schools in the Oxley electorate, and in fact in Australia, receive the funding they need to deliver the best outcomes for educating our children. That is why Labor will introduce a needs based funding system whereby all schools—government and non-government—strive to reach a strong national standard for resources and results. Our funding system will be good for all schools, regardless of where they are from. We will not be setting sector against sector. We will not be setting school against school. We will not be setting public against private. We will guarantee to maintain the overall level of funding for non-government schools. Labor also supports parents who choose non-government schooling for their children. It will provide public funding to all schools. Labor introduced major federal funding for non-government schools in the 1970s, and it extended this commitment through further increases under the Hawke and Keating governments. A Latham Labor government will continue that tradition.

In the not too distant future Australians will be asked to choose between a tired, out-of-puff and out-of-ideas government, led by John Howard and Peter Costello, and a new, fresh approach to government that will provide opportunities for all Australians under the leadership of Mark Latham. When it comes to education, the differences between the two choices are stark. Labor will deliver a first-class education system—and it is widely acknowledged that Labor is the party for education. In contrast, under John Howard's education policy many kids will miss out on a good education because their parents simply cannot afford it. For John Howard, the chequebook is more important than the textbook. For us in the Labor Party, all kids are equal, all schools are equal and everyone should have the same opportunities—opportunities based on merit and hard work and not based on the size of their chequebooks or the limit on their credit card.

talk.start.para: —I rise this morning to speak about an area of environmental significance in Croydon North in the Casey electorate. Warrien Reserve was recognised by state and federal governments decades ago as a vital area of urban environmental concern, containing many native plants, birds, insects and animal species. Its committee of management and hard-working volunteers have protected, preserved and worked to enhance the area for more than 50 years. It has received numerous state and federal grants over that time. Recently, work has focused on preserving the habitat to protect a rare and endangered frog that has been discovered in the reserve.

speech.para: The preservation of the habitat of this area is now being threatened by inappropriate development, which is planned to occur on adjacent land next to the reserve. The history of this sorry story and the planning process involved at Bonnie View Road in Croydon North reads like a nightmare. In 1999 a subcontractor for Remington Homes, also known as Pivotel, illegally clear-felled and totally moonscaped more than 6,000 square metres of land that had been purchased. They did so without any permits whatsoever. In 2001 the subcontractor was convicted and fined $8,500 for that act. Video and photographic evidence taken by residents on the day shows urban environmental butchery on a massive scale. The council officer seeking to prevent the illegal act, who was just trying to do his job, was physically assaulted and removed from the site.

The story gets worse. Just a few weeks ago the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal approved a 17-unit development on the site, overriding the Maroondah council and the views of the residents. It did so in spite of the illegal clear-felling and took the view that, because the land was now clear as a result of the illegal act, the development could go ahead. This muddle-headed logic does not just ignore illegal acts but actually rewards them. I believe the VCAT decision at Bonnie View Road was absurd. I believe it should be looked at again and overturned. Clearly, if the law in the case is defective, the state government and the planning minister at the state level, Mary Delahunty, should step in and rectify the deficient law so that planning processes do not reward environmental butchers of the type that we have seen. I would like to place on record my support for and admiration for many of the residents from the Warrien Reserve committee who have worked so hard over many years and will continue to work hard to preserve that environmental area—people like Paul and Marie Ward, David Pockett, Helen Moss and Keith Roper.

talk.start.para: —Today I again stand up for Concord Repatriation General Hospital in my electorate of Lowe and for all of my constituents, particularly the 9,972 constituents who have signed my petition calling on the Minister for Health and Ageing to grant Concord hospital a licence for a Medicare-eligible magnetic resonance imaging machine. Unless the Howard government grants Concord hospital one of the remaining 20 MRI licences it announced almost two months ago on 9 June 2004, outpatients from my electorate will continue to be denied reasonable access to this fundamental health service.

speech.para: The 130,000 constituents I represent in Sydney's inner west deserve nothing less than fair access to the MRI machine shortly to be installed by the New South Wales government. That is why on 20 February this year the shadow minister for health, Julia Gillard, the state member for Drummoyne, Angela D'Amore MLA, and I visited Concord hospital for the announcement that a Latham Labor government will immediately grant Concord hospital an MRI licence.

Those in the chamber will no doubt recall I have consistently raised this issue for more than two years. On 15 May 2002 I asked the then Minister for Health and Ageing, Senator Kay Patterson, to grant Concord hospital an MRI licence after visiting the hospital at the request of the then chief executive officer, Mr Matthew Daly, and the head of radiology, Dr Lloyd Ridley. Dr Ridley, in particular, explained the benefits of this equipment to me and asked me to investigate the possibility of Concord hospital receiving a licence to provide this important MRI service.

Sadly, for two years the Howard government has refused this request. Again and again I have asked the government to grant Concord Repatriation General Hospital an MRI licence and allow it to provide Medicare-eligible MRI services. In answers to my questions on behalf of Concord hospital on 19 August 2002, 22 October 2002, 14 May 2003, 8 September 2003, 6 November 2003, 11 February 2004, 11 March 2004 and 11 May 2004, the government has over and over again failed to give any indication that it will grant the MRI licence.

Today I report that last week the government cynically tried to deceive the people of the inner west by circulating a leaflet titled `MRI machine for our local hospital' that claims the Howard Liberal government will issue an MRI licence for our local hospital. Even if you can assume the Liberal Party is referring to Concord hospital, this is nothing more than a dishonourable attempt to salvage the government's credibility on this issue by deliberately misleading my constituents. The Liberal Party bosses, who have no doubt forced my Liberal opponent to put his name to this piece of nonsense, should hang their heads in shame.

Today I have asked the minister to explain whether or not a decision on the MRI licence has been made, who has been informed of this decision and when it will be announced. Why will Concord hospital and the 9,972 constituents who have signed my petition be the last to know? I conclude by thanking everyone who has supported my campaign on this issue for the past two years. I particularly thank Mary Venchiarutti, John Pasqua and Diana Brough from Concord's radiology department, Nigel and Caroline Freeman from Strathfield's Foot Fix Clinic, the Inner West Courier and the tireless Milka Valdivia for their support throughout this campaign. On their behalf, I again ask the government to stop playing politics and immediately grant Concord hospital an MRI licence.

talker.name: Entsch, Warren, MP
Mr ENTSCH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —I raise a matter that is critical to our environmental future. Far North Queensland is currently under attack from a plague of common or Indian myna birds, a bird listed in the top 100 chart of the most invasive species in the world. This introduced exotic species is spreading at an alarming rate. Not only are the Indian mynas capable of wiping out most of our native bird species but they are a major threat, through parasites and disease, to many of our native mammal species which nest in tree hollows. Can you imagine a country without parrots, without sugar gliders and feather-tailed gliders? Unless something is done, this is the future that we face.

speech.para: Ideally, our state and territory governments could declare the Indian myna a pest, but they are reluctant to do so and it is not hard to see why: the costs would be quite substantial. Unfortunately, I am also getting the message that there are some in the Queensland state government who believe there is no known or proven method of efficient eradication—but really this is not an excuse to sit back and do nothing. There has to be a way of controlling and eradicating these birds, but it will take time and consolidated effort. Judging by the overwhelming response of the people of Leichhardt, they not only want to do something now but they are very keen to get involved and they certainly want to help.

Last week in Cairns I launched an Indian myna minimisation program, using a trap designed by Dr Chris Tidemann of the Australian National University. `Overwhelming' is the only word to describe the response received from the Cairns community—from local wildlife and environmental groups, the Cairns City Council and local businesspeople. These are people like Andy Anderson and Dick Bolton from the Bird Observers Club of Australia, and Ian Clayton, the environmental coordinator for the Cairns water and sewage treatment plant. Ian and his site manager, Vern Atkinson, are monitoring a trap that I set at Cairns sewage treatment plant, which is home to literally thousands of Indian myna birds. Bob Boneham, the owner of a commercial enterprise, Amalgamated Pest Control, in Cairns was actually one of the first to call me as soon as he knew that we had a trap that was designed to catch Indian mynas.

I have spoken to the minister for the environment and will be seeking funding to continue the research of Dr Tidemann into the development of a trap capable of catching an entire roost of up to 1,000 birds at one time; and I will be calling on my fellow members of parliament to recognise the very serious environmental problem that needs to be taken up to fight to control the Indian myna bird, not just in Cairns but also right throughout Australia. I will be calling also on state governments to assist. They must assist by declaring the common Indian myna bird a noxious pest and start to put their hands in their pockets, not sit back and say, `No, there's nothing we can do, because it's too hard.' We have to do it and we have to do it now. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I, like many members of this parliament, have had numerous complaints made to me since the introduction of the government's so-called Medicare safety net. My office has been inundated with complaints, and when I am in shopping centres people are constantly approaching me and telling me how the system does not work for them. The complaints that I receive from people are that they will never become eligible for the safety net because the number of times they visit the doctor will not bring them to the $300 or $700 safety net limit. I have also received complaints that doctors are restructuring their fees to take advantage of the safety net. I also receive complaints from people who do not understand the system and feel that they are being misled by the government.

speech.para: But no complaint I have received is worse than the one I am going to share with the House today. A pregnant woman, Marie, who lives within the Shortland electorate, has emailed me her concerns about the new Medicare safety net. She starts by pointing out to me that this was designed to ease the medical burdens on families. She is a young woman who is on maternity leave after having her third child, and they are really struggling for dollars. As a family with young children they visit the doctor and pharmacies quite regularly and their medical expenses are high. She registered with the Medicare safety net as soon as the legislation passed through this parliament and was most disappointed when she found out that she would not qualify for it immediately, simply because she has deferred her family payment costs from Centrelink until tax time. She did this because she was constantly being sent debts. Due to the unworkable nature of the system, she thought that it was much better to deal with it that way.

So, because she is getting her family tax payments in that manner, the system does not recognise that she is receiving family tax payments and she will not be eligible to receive the safety net until 2005. She has already incurred over $300 in medical costs and she feels that this is very unfair. In 2005, she will be in exactly the same position because, once again, she will not be eligible until she puts in her tax return. She feels this is very unfair on families. It is another example of the government disregarding families and also an example of the unworkable nature of the Medicare safety net. It is proof why the government needs to embrace Medicare and increase bulk-billing—not undermine the system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to follow on from my previous remarks in recognising some important environmental volunteers in the electorate. But, before I do that, I will respond to the previous speaker. I trust that the previous speaker will not in any way mislead her constituent and that she will email her constituent back with Labor's policy on the safety net, which is to abolish the safety net from day one of a Latham Labor government. It is all very well for the previous speaker to come in here and talk about the safety net and the ability to access it in time, but the bottom line is that the Labor Party will abolish that safety net. They will remove it from hundreds of thousands of families who have signed up and are accessing it at the moment. They will take away a financial benefit in the health system from families and people right across the board.

speech.para: I will now follow on from my earlier remarks in recognising some environmental volunteers. I mentioned Warrien Reserve in my earlier contribution. I would also like to mention some important work that is going on at the nearby Hochkins Ridge Flora Reserve, where a similar group of volunteers are working very hard to enhance that urban bushland. They have worked hard over a number of years but have recently put together, with the aid of some federal government funding through the Envirofund, a detailed pamphlet outlining many of the native plants and wildflowers and listing some of the dangerous introduced weeds. This pamphlet includes many photographs taken by Helen Moss, who is a dedicated environmentalist in the area. The pamphlet is designed as an educational tool and has been distributed to all of the nearby schools.

This is an example of some very practical environmentalism, where some of the hardworking volunteers have sought, with the assistance of a partnership with the federal government, to spread the understanding and knowledge of the local environment so that people in Croydon North and in the Casey electorate can be environmentally aware and know of the very strong environmental areas that are there that can be witnessed. For the schoolkids to have such a pamphlet is fantastic. It is a tribute to all of those who worked to put it together. It is a first-class publication, and I hope that it can be a model for many other environmental groups not only throughout the Casey electorate but also throughout the Dandenong Ranges and the rest of Victoria.
